column2: LEAD: Candace Ingals, the daughter of Mary L. Ingals of Washington and E. Fletcher Ingals 3d of Glenbrook, Nev., was married in Washington yesterday to Saulius P. Valiunas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Valiunas of Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Dr. John C. Harper performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John's Church in Lafayette Square.
LEAD: Ninth Avenue will be closed today from 37th Street to 57th Street from 9 A.M. to 7 P.M. for the Ninth Avenue Food Festival.

LEAD: IN the six months since J. P. Morgan & Company began moving into its new 47-story headquarters building at 60 Wall Street, its staff has continued a game of musical chairs that became routine during the 80's in the tumultuous world of investment banking, where multimillion dollar deals are struck in hours and new lines of business are established in days.

LEAD: The Appalachian town of Hamelin, Tenn. (population 900), doesn't know whether it's coming or going, in Sharyn McCrumb's IF EVER I RETURN, PRETTY PEGGY-O (Scribners, $17.95), what with the murder of a local teen-ager and the high school reunion of the class of 1966 both happening in the same week. In truth, the identity confusion and general anxiety stirred by the reunion seem to have the more disorienting effect on the generation of Hamelin that lost its innocence during the Vietnam

LEAD: THE New Jersey economy softened considerably in 1989. But the existing inventory of office space was reduced, since new construction was minimal. There are many economic-development professionals who have said that this moderation in the level of development activity has been for the better.
LEAD: Whether the props, fixtures and furniture at one of the nation's most influential retail-display concerns are inspired by Madonna or ancient Greece, the goal is the same: to sell clothes.

LEAD: For most of Ladysmith Black Mambazo's late set Tuesday night at S.O.B.'s, the 10-man chorus from South Africa seemed untouched by the last few years, when it was brought to worldwide attention after its appearance on Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' album. The set included the first song written by the group's leader, Joseph Shabalala (in 1965), as well as songs from its new album, ''Two Worlds, One Heart'' (Warner Brothers).

LEAD: The Bethel Chapel in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Emily Ewing Ford, a daughter of Enfield Berry Ford of Riverside, Conn., and Margaret Ford Cowan of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., to Edward Bassett Daeschler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Daeschler of Short Hills, N.J.

LEAD: Two photographs were transposed last week in the Headliners column. A picture of Frank Herbert Reed, the recently released hostage, was at the top of the column. Senator Dave Durenberger of Minnesota was pictured at the bottom.
LEAD: FIGHTING FOR PEACE Seven Critical Years in the Pentagon. By Caspar W. Weinberger. 464 pp. New York: Warner Books. $24.95.
LEAD: A STONE OF THE HEART By Tom Grimes. 131 pp. New York: Four Walls Eight Windows. $15.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When Bucky Dent played for the Yankees in the turbulent days that gave birth to baseball's Bronx Zoo, he studiously avoided involvement in the mad, mad world of George and Billy and Reggie. Ron Guidry, Willie Randolph and Dent were the best at remaining quiet and aloof from the daily turmoil.
LEAD: ANNIVERSARY WALTZES

LEAD: The Justice Department has reached agreement with East Germany for access to that country's World War II archives, a move that investigators say could result in important new prosecutions of Nazi war criminals living in the United States.

LEAD: For This Week: Now that the weather has settled down, everything can go into the ground, especially seedlings of tomatoes, peppers and eggplants; if the ground is truly warm, bean and corn seed can be planted, but if the ground is too cold, these crops will rot in the ground; wait. Last call to prune spring-blooming plants.

LEAD: At least 12 prominent pro-democracy advocates have been arrested in Kuwait in the last few days. The moves have dealt a blow to a democracy movement that emerged with surprising force in the country at the start of the year.

LEAD: Dr. Suzanne D. Conzen, a daughter of Salome B. Conzen of New York and Willibald H. Conzen of Verona, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Timothy W. James, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Douglas H. James of Norwich, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro officiated at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

LEAD: Amy J. Lapkin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Lapkin of Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening to James E. Frank, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Frank of Englewood, N.J., by Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson at the Westbury Hotel in New York.
LEAD: The Parliament of Lithuania inconclusively debated how far the republic was willing to retreat from its declaration of independence. Page 16.
LEAD: Amid demands that importing of Canadian caribou be halted, a new herd of caribou has been released in a forest near this northern town.
LEAD: A man who appeared to be drunk walked into a college cafeteria and opened fire with a revolver on Friday, killing one college employee and wounding another, the authorities said.
LEAD: THE BIG CHAMPAGNE HOUSES IN FRANCE KEEP these fellows around for parties - heaven knows what they do the rest of the time - to saber the tops off bottles.

LEAD: Q. A few months ago, the temperature in my cellar fell well below freezing, and some latex paint that I had there froze. Is there some solvent or liquid I can add now that will liquefy the paint and make it useable again?

LEAD: Herbert Friedman of New York has announced June wedding plans for Andrea L. Echikson, the daughter of the late Lee Friedman, and Tom A. Bernstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bernstein of Bedford, N.Y.

LEAD: The Bensonhurst and East New York sections of Brooklyn struggled to return to normal yesterday in the wake of a racially charged murder trial that ended in an outburst of raw emotion on Friday night.
LEAD: The 1991 model Ford Escort hatchbacks and station wagons are the most significant new cars from Ford Motor Company in at least two decades. -Thomas J. Wagner

LEAD: Your article implies that the professors interviewed exert great influence over students. The next time you choose to investigate Harvard Law School, I suggest you shift your focus from the ivory tower to the campus below.

LEAD: OUTSIDERS FIRST SUSPECTED THAT SOMETHING UNUSUAL WAS AFOOT in Trenton, the sleepy capital on the bank of the Delaware River, several hours before Jim Florio took the oath of office as the 49th Governor of New Jersey.

LEAD: I come from a funny family. We have a lot of family jokes. Most of them are purely silly, such as the name Treddy I. Biotical, which stemmed from a made-up disease, which in turn stemmed from something else too long and silly to explain. But one of our jokes, initially, did not even remotely resemble a joke.

LEAD: Let's see if we've got this right. Ben Johnson was hauled into Olympic headquarters in the middle of the night, deprived of his gold medal for having performance-enhancing steroids in his system.

LEAD: The New Jersey Ballet Company made a pleasant impression on Wednesday night at the Triplex Theater. A concern for technical accuracy and proper placement was evident throughout the evening. But the dancers were also aware that ballet is an art of the stage as well as the studio, and they performed with theatrical assurance.

LEAD: Louise Melchor Gilbert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Neely Gilbert Jr. of Statesville, N.C., was married yesterday to George Clemon Freeman 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Freeman Jr. of Richmond. The Rev. Grant McGuffin Sharp officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Statesville.

LEAD: The two most obvious facts of Hawaii are the huge sluttish pleasures of its Nipponized beachfront hotels and, in great contrast, its rugged landscape of craggy volcanoes and its coastal headlands, where lava has been pounded by heavy surf into black spikes. Hawaii is smooth, but it can also be rough.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Two months after taking office, President Fernando Collor de Mello is fast approaching the moment of truth for his plan to integrate Brazil into the world economy.
LEAD: BLACK AND WHITE Written and illustrated by David Macaulay. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $14.95. (Ages 7 and up)

LEAD: ''I think our discussions have resulted in some real accomplishments, and the progress we have made here makes me optimistic that we will have a productive summit in Washington.'' - Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. [18:4.]

LEAD: Fueled by new laws and stiffer sentences endorsed by an impatient public, the states' prison population grew more than 10 percent last year and began to overwhelm even states like Washington, which had been among the few to avoid overcrowding.

LEAD: AS a college student in Philadelphia, she spent hours at a splattered easel, painting canvases with bold strokes of abstract design or delicate lines of portraiture. As a married mother of three in Kentucky, she sketched patterns at the kitchen table in the evening and sold down comforters out of an old bakery during the day.

LEAD: English and American examples of the turn-of-the-century Arts and Crafts style have rarely been exhibited together since the style was revived in the late 1960's, even though the movement in this country grew out of William Morris's antimachine proselytizing in mid-19th-century England.

LEAD: *4*INDEXES OF HOUSING COSTS/N.Y.-Northeast N.J. area* % change from % change from Apr. Mar. Apr. 89 Rents 157.6 0.9 6.4 Homeowner'sososts 163.4 0.7 8.1 Fuel and utilities 101.7 -0.2 4.0 *4**Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, *4*Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, *4*Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.

LEAD: ''Strapless,'' which was shown as part of the 1989 New York Film Festival, opens today at the Plaza and at the Chelsea and Worldwide Cinemas. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 23, 1989.

LEAD: Victoria Stafford Falk, a daughter of Mrs. William J. McDonough of Chicago and Ralph Falk 2d of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday to Peter Tead Michaelis, a son of Michael Michaelis of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Diana Tead Michaelis, at the Bedford (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev.

LEAD: George Romney, the former Michigan Governor who is now the director of the National Center of Voluntary Action in Arlington, Va., spoke to Drew University's 495 graduates yesterday on the benefits of volunteerism.
LEAD: Special Today: Sophisticated Traveler/Mag. Pt. 2 Special Today: Commercial Property/Section 10A

LEAD: Christopher Lloyd, the wild-eyed character actor whose performances as the visionary time traveler Emmett Brown in the ''Back to the Future'' movies have won him the kind of attention usually reserved for leading men, has been making films for 15 years, since his first role as a member of the Asylum Ensemble in ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.
LEAD: THE FUGITIVE By Pramoedya Ananta Toer. Translated by Willem Samuels. 171 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

LEAD: Pernell Whitaker showed his quickness and ring cunning. Azumah Nelson showed his age. As a result, after 12 rounds at Caesars Palace here tonight, the 26-year-old Whitaker scored a unanimous decision over the 31-year-old Nelson to retain his International Boxing Federation and World Boxing Council lightweight titles.

LEAD: Hong Kong, Britain's rich capitalist colony that sits at the tip of mainland China, is a sparkling monument to hard work and high living. And for a panoramic view of this restless, energetic entrepot, and a close-up look at the unabashed luxury for which it is famous, few places can rival the imposing Lobby Lounge in the five-star Regent Hotel.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: By Pa and Ma I'm daily told To marry now's my time, For though I'm very far from old, I'm rather in my prime. They say while we have any sun We ought to make our hay - And India has so hot a one, I'm going to Bombay! Thomas Hood's famous ditty, ''I'm Going to Bombay,'' embodies just one aspect of the great 19th-century saga of British imperialism.

LEAD: ANTARCTICA Written and illustrated by Helen Cowcher. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 8) A TALE OF ANTARCTICA Written and illustrated by Ulco Glimmerveen. 32 pp. New York: Scholastic. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) BIRDS OF ANTARCTICA The Adelie Penguin.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Hatterer of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Julie Anne Hatterer and Dr. Michael Lawrence Gelb, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Gelb of New York.

LEAD: Clinton, Conn. $140,000 44 Jefferson Circle 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 24-year-old raised ranch; workshop on lower level, 2-car attached garage, 0.67 acre; taxes $2,106. Guilford, Conn. $400,000 Laurel Cliffs 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; mud room, family room w/fireplace, patio, 2 acres; taxes not yet assessed.

LEAD: I was working as a newspaperman when I was drafted into the Army during the Korean War, and I decided to write a continuing column about it for my paper called This New Army, which was what everybody was calling that same old Army in those days. I wrote about how unbelievably stupid sergeants and corporals were, how unspeakably dreadful Army food was and how very peculiarly the general behaved when he noticed

LEAD: No one could have predicted that a world-famous star of westerns and police action films would make his first screen appearance here dressed in pink coat, high boots and riding breeches, a country gentleman ready for the fox hunt. And no one could have guessed that a venerable film maker whose work is known for its rigorousness and ferocity would bring forth a gentle, even childlike collection of fairy tales.
LEAD: Cam Neely in full windup at the face-off circle. Brian Propp unchecked and unobstructed from the blue line. Craig Janney in flight across the slot with the puck.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ornstein of Greenwich, Conn., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter, Holly Anne Ornstein, and Robert Mitchell Carter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Carter of Scarsdale, N.Y.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Last week, Ann B. Hopkins was celebrating, smoking cigarettes, drinking beer, making jokes and otherwise acting thick-skinned, the way she has through seven years of litigation over her right to be a partner in a big accounting firm. It was just that unfeminine posture that had led the firm to reject her, a Federal judge had found, and because of that the firm would have to take her back.
LEAD: ''Call me, Ishmael. We'll do lunch.''

LEAD: It's called Off-HOllywood Video: Independently produced feature films, social documentaries, videos of fine and performing arts, or any other category of special-interest programming - much of it educational - that rarely gets into video stores.
LEAD: Curtis Strange solved the swirling winds today to shoot a one-under-par 69 and tie Ben Crenshaw for the lead going into the final round of the Southwestern Bell Colonial tournament on Sunday.

LEAD: As a wife, mother, professional nurse and teacher, I say it's time the women's movement supported the importance of the work of women like me. Instead, many feminists of this revolution have tried to persuade me and my peers to abandon our ''women's work.'' As a result, the exhilaration I felt in my 1970's consciousness-raising groups has turned to ashes.

LEAD: When I visit Marseilles it is for a cure de poisson, for the city is a fish lover's paradise unequaled in France. At the tip of the Vieux Port, along the weather-beaten Quai des Belges, the city awakens to the familiar cries of the fishmonger. It's a rough and ancient symphony as fishermen, their wives and their children, begin to set out the daily catch.

LEAD: When New York's long-overdue budget received final approval at 4:01 A.M. today, state lawmakers congratulated themselves for having found a solution to the worst financial problems that the state has seen in more than a decade. But critics both inside and outside government say they fear that, even though the budget includes the largest tax increase in the state's history, it will not guarantee balanced budgets in coming years.

LEAD: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some Indian and Middle Eastern restaurants open for Sunday dining. Al

LEAD: Should it matter to us where a talented and rich and aging baseball player plies his trade? Should it matter whether a rich and controversial owner is leveling with the public when he says he opposed the player's trade despite a decade of rancorous disputes with that player? Should it matter whether the owner's aide insulted the player or merely showed insensitivity typical of employers who are ditching a once-valued employee?

LEAD: A study by the National Academy of Sciences has urged the mandatory use of trapdoors on nets used on shrimp boats in the Gulf of Mexico and South Atlantic to protect sea turtles that are swept up in the catches.

LEAD: Maj. Gen. L. Gordon Hill, retired, a former chief of public information for the Army and its main press spokesman in Saigon in the late 1960's, died of cardiac arrest on Friday at Fairfax (Va.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Burke, Va.

LEAD: Dr. Nancy A. Carlson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Carlson of Boston, and Dr. John M. Fisher, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John Fisher of St. Albans, Vt., were married yesterday in Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. William Eddy performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: For some time now, business has been bleak at the Radiance Boutique. And it's starting to wear on owner Ruby Golden, who for 18 years made a good living in the competitive world of retailing. ''I'm not doing well at all. I hate you to print that. But it's the truth,'' Ms. Golden said. ''And I'm not doing well because there aren't enough stores here.

LEAD: Once upon a time - more than 120 years ago - a small East Texas river town called Jefferson was thriving as steamships carried cotton and timber down the Red River to the Mississippi and thence to New Orleans. Then one day, the railroad magnate Jay Gould (no relation to this writer) came to Jefferson.

LEAD: The program of works by George Balanchine that the New York City Ballet offered Thursday night at the New York State Theater came close to being an all-concerto night. Of the four items, only ''The Steadfast Tin Soldier'' was not set to a concerto. Fortunately, the ballets were so varied that the evening never grew musically or choreographically monotonous.
LEAD: Kristina Baker Olin and Arthur Joseph Santry 3d were married yesterday at the Homestead in Hot Springs, Va. The Rev. Kirk Ballin, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Jack Armstrong pitched a four-hitter to become the major leagues' second seven-game winner and Rolando Roomes hit a three-run homer as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-0, tonight.

LEAD: Q. A few months ago, the temperature in my cellar fell well below freezing, and some latex paint that I had there froze. Is there some solvent or liquid I can add now that will liquefy the paint and make it useable again?

LEAD: Virginia Spahr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Spahr of Malvern, Pa., and Matthew Medbury Keator, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerrit M. Keator of Stamford, Conn., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Howard Friend, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.
LEAD: To the Editor: Publishing Deborah Blumenthal's article (Travel, March 11) urging consumers to compare prices at airport duty-free shops is a real public service, as my experience proved.

LEAD: Nearly a year and a half after ascending the Chrysanthemum Throne, Emperor Akihito has become entangled in an old dispute over Japan's responsibility for World War II reminiscent of the issues that many hoped had been buried with the death of Emperor Hirohito.

LEAD: Deborah A. Devine, the daughter of Mrs. John P. Devine of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Mr. Devine, was married yesterday to Edward M. Caruso, the son of Mary Caruso of Wayne, Pa., and Edward R. Caruso of Phoenixville, Pa. Msgr. Harrold Murray and the Rev. Patrick McLaughlin officiated at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills.

LEAD: HEY! GET OFF OUR TRAIN Written and illustrated by John Burningham. Unpaged. New York: Crown Publishers. $14.95. (Ages 5 and up) THE GREAT KAPOK TREE A Tale of the Amazon Rain Forest. Written and illustrated by Lynne Cherry. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.
LEAD: In Brazil, where it never snows, the equivalent of a flamingo on the lawn was once a penguin on a refrigerator.

LEAD: For American yachting enthusiasts, the Caribbean is still the most popular destination, particularly the Virgin Islands, the Grenadines and, for those hearty sailors eager for lots of sea, the stretch between Anguilla and St. Lucia. The ideal way to travel these waters is in a chartered boat, since there is a large selection available year round.

LEAD: Two years ago, the singer and songwriter Michael Smith was working as a clerk for Time magazine in Chicago and playing occasional dates in folk clubs when Frank Galati of Chicago's Steppenwolf Theater Company dropped in one night to hear him perform.

LEAD: The word ''supermarket'' seems an ugly one to place next to the performing arts, but it can be applied admiringly to the finale of the Bang on a Can Festival. A series of new-music events that began on May 4 at the RAPP Arts Center in the East Village ended with four concerts last Sunday that in essence ran one into the next.

LEAD: Storrs Heathcote Lamb, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawton Storrs Lamb of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., to Edward Troutman Cote Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cote of Ligonier, Pa. The Venerable Robert A. Bryan, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Baseball

LEAD: Alarmed that housing costs in Suffolk County were driving moderate-income families away, officials in the Town of Southold adopted a new zoning policy in 1986 aimed at cutting the cost of new homes. It is finally paying off: Ground was broken this month for a project offering eligible families 28 half-acre homesites in Southold Village for $30,000 each.

LEAD: AMONG Israel's best-kept secrets are the guesthouses of its kibbutzim. About 25 kibbutz-operated hotels and holiday villages set up by these collective settlements are scattered throughout the country, from the northern Galilee to the Negev, from the Mediterranean to the Jordan River. They offer visitors a chance to escape the crowded cities and relax in an informal and intimate atmosphere.

LEAD: Claudia Farb of Manhattan used to spend her days off imagining ways to escape New York's smothering summer heat. When Ms. Farb, an assistant research scientist at New York University, learned of a company that was seeking guides to lead bicycle tours on weekends and vacations, she oiled her 10-speed and applied.
LEAD: Talk to Phil Jackson about Michael Jordan's staggering scoring numbers this season, and the Chicago Bulls' coach says, ''That's our Michael.''

LEAD: To the Editor: Having just returned from three months in a relatively small town smack in the middle of Minas Gerais, I must say that being anywhere in Brazil now, thanks to the changes being implemented almost daily by the new Collor Government, is to participate in a thrilling moment in history.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THIS is commencement season at colleges and universities around Connecticut, when graduates think about diplomas, college officials worry about the weather and distinguished scholars get ready to don peculiar outfits.
LEAD: In the end, the hate was there in the courtroom, just as it was there on 69th Street in Bensonhurst on the August night when Yusuf K. Hawkins was shot to death.

LEAD: THE administration at Columbia Law School will either love or hate ''Guilty Conscience,'' depending on whether it is more interested in being seen as a school that produces clever lawyers or one that graduates ethical human beings.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Q. A few months ago, the temperature in my cellar fell well below freezing, and some latex paint that I had there froze. Is there some solvent or liquid I can add now that will liquefy the paint and make it useable again?

LEAD: Francesca A. Morselli, a daughter of Dr. Mario A. Morselli and Dr. Mariafranca Morselli of South Burlington, Vt., was married in Woodstock, Vt., yesterday to David S. Sinnott, a son of Betty Lou Sinnott of Duxbury, Mass., and the late Peter Sinnott. Canon Donald Boyer and the Rev. Charles Davignon, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated jointly at St.

LEAD: Dealing With the Deficit - Sort Of If the suit doesn't fit, why lose weight when you can let out the pants instead? Budget negotiators appear likely to loosen the Gramm-Rudman deficit strictures and disregard the cost of the savings-and-loan bailout. They agreed on Thursday that cutting the budget more than $60 billion would risk a recession.
LEAD: THE rap on politicians is that they can't seem to think about anything but the next election. Not fair. This year they are focusing on the election after the next one.
LEAD: On the West Coast, sporty lightweight woven mufflers are often worn year round. The trend has now threaded its way east.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joel E. Smilow of Westport, Conn., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Susan D. Smilow, and Jeffrey D. Varsa, the son of Dr. Evelyn E. Handler of West Newton, Mass., and George Varsa of New York.

LEAD: A ticking time bomb with RJR Nabisco Inc.'s name on it is wending its way through Federal court. It's a lawsuit filed by Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and Jefferson-Pilot Life Insurance Company which, if successful, could force the refinancing of some $5 billion in outstanding RJR Nabisco debt and allow some disgruntled bondholders to get their money back.

LEAD: At the end of the first act of David Henry Hwang's ''F.O.B.,'' there is a mirthful eating scene that summarizes the conflict between an American-born young man of Chinese descent and a newly landed immigrant, fresh off the boat (F.O.B.) from China. The newcomer, played by Dennis Dun, pours a jar of fiery hot sauce over his dinner and eats it as if it were the most savory of delights.

LEAD: There's a world of luxury afloat ot there, on the balmy seas of the Caribbean, the Mediterranean and the Polynesian pacific. The water is calm, the sun is warm and islands beckon in the distance. The conveyances are beautiful boats, some with teak decks and spanking white sails, some with powerful motors and streamlined chassis.

LEAD: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Cynthia M. Tripp was married yesterday to David H. Swanson. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth B. Swanson, the bridegroom's brother, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A chart last Sunday on April 13 with the All About column misstated the 1989 market share of the Church & Dwight Company's Arm & Hammer Dental Care toothpaste. The product's market share was 3 percent, not 0.8 percent.
LEAD: October wedding plans for Lynn Anne Pantano and Stuart Charles Dale have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Lester L. Coleman and Carl A. Pantano, both of New York.

LEAD: A photograph shows a fully dressed young woman crouching near a urinal, her left wrist handcuffed to a pipe, while a group of young men look on. There is a smile on her face. The woman, 19-year-old Gwen Marie Dreyer, was a second-year midshipman at the United States Naval Academy here until she resigned last month.

LEAD: Irene W. Bruynes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cees Bruynes of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday at the Second Congregational Church to Mario A. Ponce, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Mario P. Ponce of Glen Ridge, N.J. The Rev. T. Merton Rymph performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Ben Hogan avoids reflecting on the particulars of his magnificent career, even though they happen to include four United States Open victories, five other major championships, and a reputation as the greatest shotmaker who ever lived.

LEAD: An obscure cruise missile with the odd name of Tacit Rainbow almost managed to unravel all the progress that American and Soviet negotiators achieved in their four days of arms control talks in Moscow, a senior Administration official said today.

LEAD: BY THE TIME I MOVED OUT OF MY New York apartment last year, I had filled 12 large boxes with molds for steamed pudding, terrines for pate en croute, 300 tartlet pans, muffin tins in every shape and size, a set of wedding-cake pans, an arsenal of knives and 15 ice-cream scoops.

LEAD: Eduard Tubin is one of music's loners. Estonian by birth, the composer spent the last half of his life in Sweden. He followed no fashions, belonged to no school. When he died in 1982, he left a legacy of 10 symphonies, two operas, two ballets and a variety of concertos, cantatas and works in smaller forms.
LEAD: In general, accountants and musicians have little in common. Yet they agree on the importance of the bottom line.
LEAD: Arie Luyendyk was jubilant, Al Unser Jr. was stunned and Emerson Fittipaldi remained on the pole for the Indianapolis 500 on May 27 after the first-round qualifications finally ended today.

LEAD: Maria T. Christel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert R. Christel of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Norman Mansson, a son of Mrs. Martin S. Mansson of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and the late Mr. Mansson. The Very Rev. Stephen H. Gushkee officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Woodbury, Conn.

LEAD: John Smiley, a left-handed pitcher for the Pittsburgh Pirates, broke his throwing hand yesterday when he slammed it in a car door as he was going to Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium. The Pirates placed Smiley on the 21-day disabled list. Smiley has a record of 3-3 with a 3.37 earned run average in 45Z innings.

LEAD: We found James Wickenden's article on what parents should do ''When the College Says No'' (Opinion page, April 15) most interesting and potentially very useful for the parents of college-bound students -especially those students who have applied to the most competitive schools.

LEAD: Lynn Jennifer Griffo, a daughter of Betty A. Griffo of New City, N.Y., and Henry P. Griffo of Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Jay Mark Sackman, a son of Michael Sackman of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Lulu R. Sackman. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard officiated at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New

LEAD: For someone who won 8,833 races and $123 million in purses in a 40-year career as a jockey, Bill Shoemaker seemed surprisingly nervous before the fifth race at Hollywood Park on Friday. That was because, at the age of 58, Shoemaker was making his racing debut as a trainer.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The concept of cyberspace, which first gained popular appeal in a 1984 science-fiction novel, is so radical that even today few people agree on its definition. Some describe cyberspace as an infinite, computer-generated artificial world where humans experience an approximation of reality. There, geographic distance is irrelevant and participants can see, hear and even touch objects that exist only as computer data - pure information.
LEAD: Jesus hangs on the cross, nails driven through his feet and hands, his side pierced, his body limp and stained with blood.

LEAD: The six Jesuit priests of the University of Central America who were slain in El Salvador last November and those who continue their mission were especially honored yesterday at the 145th commencement of Fordham University.

LEAD: IN a sunlit basement studio at Kings Highway Elementary School in Westport, Karen Ernst, an art teacher, asked a group of third graders to write about the ways art has touched their lives. Without hesitating, Josh Drimmer sequestered himself at an empty table, sat pensively for a moment, then opened his notebook and scribbled:
LEAD: Congratulations on your award!

LEAD: On the March morning when the Mets finally opened spring training after the 32-day lockout, Davey Johnson stood in front of the third-base dugout at the Port St. Lucie Sports Complex. And as Johnson spoke, Darryl Strawberry, hatless in the sun, was moving slowly in the middle of the pack along the third-base line toward home plate.

LEAD: GETTING a computer and a printer to work together should be simple, and it often is. At other times, it can be a frustrating process indeed.

LEAD: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable television company, said yesterday that it was again altering the form of its planned spinoff of assets. Under the new plan, Tele-Communications said it would spin off part of its assets into a separate business.
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a novel treatment for mild bladder cancer that involves flooding the bladder with a live bacteria used in tuberculosis vaccines.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about proposed military spending cuts misstated a Bush Adminstration proposal in some copies. The Administration has proposed cutting military spending by 10 percent over the next five years, not 10 percent a year.

LEAD: A hereditary Islamic leader, the most senior and influential opponent of Indian rule in Kashmir, was assassinated in his home in the state's capital today. When 100,000 angry mourners followed his body through the streets of the city, security forces opened fire, killing at least 30 people and wounding some 200, according to hospital doctors.

LEAD: The bankruptcy trustee for the Delaware & Hudson Railway accepted a $25 million bid for the carrier last week from Canadian Pacific Ltd. Under the agreement, Canadian Pacific will either run the Delaware & Hudson or underwrite its operation by the trustee, Francis P. Dicello, who has been overseeing its operation since February while trying to sell the freight line, which runs from Montreal to Washington and from Albany to Buffalo.

LEAD: Six months ago Jiri Dienstbier was shoveling coal into a furnace for the Prague subway system. Now, as Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, he is putting forward a plan to help the Soviet Union and the countries of Central Europe move to market economies.

LEAD: A new graduate of Smith College and three of his family members were killed in a crash on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway today as they drove home from commencement ceremonies, the police said. The state police identified the dead as Bing Kwan, his wife, Miu, and their two children, Albert, 21, and Jaime, 22.
LEAD: Stanley S. Arkin, a prominent trial lawyer in New York, said yesterday that he and two partners would join the firm of Chadbourne & Parke in July.

LEAD: ON a wind-swept point of black lava jutting into the Pacific Ocean, a small band of scientists and entrepreneurs is generating electricity, raising lobsters and growing strawberries using cold water from the depths of the sea.

LEAD: A surge in income tax payments helped the Government set a record budget surplus of $42.52 billion in April, one month after a record monthly deficit, the Treasury Department reported today.

LEAD: Reviving ancient operatic comedies like ''La Dori'' sets up a struggle between archeology and entertainment that can scarcely be avoided. The Mannes Camerata and its director, translator and adapter, Paul C. Echols, are in the midst of a five-performance run of Antonio Cesti's stage piece. To make this mid-17th-century rat's nest of love affairs and sexual confusions intelligible for late-20th-century audiences is a job in itself.

LEAD: THE super middleweight match for new professional boxers at Gleason's Arena in Brooklyn is raucous and bloody, the way the crowd loves it. Many of the punches glance off the boxers' sweaty bodies, but once in a while a glove hooks through the air and connects solidly with an opponent's head. As the stunned fighter regains composure, electrified fans jump to their feet with a stream of cheers, jeers and hoots.

LEAD: AT a rate of more than 200 volumes a day, books in the Library of Congress, the largest library in the world, are turning to dust. But after a decade of research, accidents and administrative delays, the library reports that it is about to take a major step toward stopping the rot.

LEAD: Edward Steitz, an authority on the rules of basketball who helped introduce the 3-point shot to college and international competition, died yesterday morning at the Baystate Medical Center in Springfield, Mass., after suffering cardiac arrest at his home in East Longmeadow, Mass. LEAD: Comet Austin, a visitor from the outer reaches of the solar system, will make its closest approach to the Earth on Friday, when it is expected to come within 22 million miles. LEAD: A semiconductor industry innovator who is highly critical of the United States' strategy for competing with Japanese chip makers will introduce a machine today that he says could dramatically improve this country's ability to keep pace with Japan in the mid-1990's. The machine is at the center of a debate over whether it is the correct technology for the 1990's.

LEAD: In the late afternoon, the Mets closed the doors to their clubhouse so they could try and sort out their differences in a season that has gone awry. In the evening, they did what their manager said they have needed to do all along. They won. It was so simple, so thorough and so convincing that it made you wonder why they hadn't held a players-only pregame meeting weeks ago.
LEAD: The United States economy will skirt a recession through 1991 and set a postwar record for the longest period of business growth, the nation's top business economists predicted today.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation named Lawrence W. Baker general manager for its Jeep/Eagle division, responsible for marketing, advertising and merchandising. He switches jobs with Martin R. Levine, who becomes general manager for the Dodge car and truck division. Chrysler also appointed Ralph A. Sarotte director of multi-brand marketing programs, responsible for media budgeting and corporate advertising.
LEAD: In a sign of its deteriorating financial condition, Greyhound Lines Inc. offered today to repurchase most of its $225 million in publicly held notes for about $90 million.
LEAD: The demobilization of the contra army remained clouded by confusion today amid conflicting declarations about whether guerrilla commanders would fulfill their commitments to disband their army.

LEAD: Two juries have now spoken in the trial of two whites from Bensonhurst accused in the racial killing of a black youth, Yusuf Hawkins. The case has riveted public interest and offered a compelling moment for New York's Legislature to address the hate behind this and similar crimes.
LEAD: A state Supreme Court justice today ruled against a Rockland County environmental group trying to stop a farm family from selling part of its farm for a housing development.

LEAD: TENNIS Maleeva and Paulus Lead Advance The top two seeded players in the European Open in Geneva, Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria and Barbara Paulus of Austria, won their first-round matches yesterday.

LEAD: President Bush threatens to veto a pending civil rights bill because his Attorney General says it would lead to hiring quotas. But nobody, including the Attorney General, has produced anything but speculation that it would. Indeed, the evidence is emphatically to the contrary.

LEAD: Not long after Cecil Fielder joined the Detroit Tigers in spring training, George (Sparky) Anderson asked how the 6-foot-3-inch, 230-pound first baseman preferred to pronounce his first name. ''Just call me Cess,'' he told the manager. That's Cess, as in success. With a major league leading 16 home runs, a .324 average and 37 runs batted in, Cess Fielder is the success story of this baseball season.
LEAD: Seth E. Schofield has been promoted to the post of president and chief operating officer of USAir Inc., the airline unit of USAir Group Inc.

The other 50, he was told, had been stripped of tires, two-way radios or motors by the departing administration of the Institutional Revolutionary Party.
LEAD: The 3-year-old scene lost one prominent runner but regained another yesterday when Champagne-forashley was retired from racing and Rhythm won his first start of the year.

LEAD: Three of the six defendants in the Central Park rape case were ordered yesterday to stand trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on June 13.

LEAD: The Supreme Court today upheld a Federal law requiring people convicted of Federal crimes to pay a ''special assessment'' into a fund for crime victims. The assessments, ranging from $10 to $200, generate about $125 million a year for the fund set up under the law, the Victims of Crime Act of 1984.
LEAD: How many carriers are enough? That depends not only on their intended use, but also on the dismal arithmetic of carrier deployment.
LEAD: New Yorkers can be excused for thinking that the State Legislature had nothing on its agenda this year other than passing a budget.
LEAD: Japan backed away today from its offer to harbor a group of Chinese dissidents trying to transmit pro-democracy messages to the mainland.
LEAD: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had amended its countersuit against Advanced Micro Devices Inc. about programmable logic devices.

LEAD: ''It's of great political value to show a fairly continuous presence on the high seas. Through port calls and exercises with friends in the region, the U.S. shows it is remaining engaged.'' -Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. [B8:1.]
LEAD: Sushi by Machine

LEAD: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation rejected a $1.82 billion offer from Pacificorp, saying the bid was too low. It was the fourth time Pinnacle rejected a Pacificorp bid for the holding company or for its Arizona Public Service Company subsidiary. Pacificorp, a utility company based in Portland, Ore., said it might make an offer to Pinnacle West's shareholders.

LEAD: In acquiring Mike Witt, the Yankees have once again tried to find a legitimate pitching leader, or at least bolster their starting corps. Even with his strong start last Saturday, though, Witt must still prove that he is not yet another part of the team's decadelong practice of finding pitchers whose success is behind them or nonexistent.
LEAD: A SHORT friend writes from Brooklyn Heights:

LEAD: Kurt Wallinger, the talented lead singer and songwriter of the British pop group World Party, is a musician who is deeply enamored of late-1960's rock icons like the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and Bob Dylan. And on the group's second album, ''Goodbye Jumbo,'' these influences have been blended into melodious, thoughtful songs that poke around in the embers of 60's pop utopianism seeking to stir up a few sparks.
LEAD: In this unusual urban classroom, there are no walls, desks or blackboards. Instead, students roam over five acres, washing wool, raking hay, collecting eggs and planting collard greens.

LEAD: Steffi Graf, the top-ranked female player in the world, and 16-year-old Monica Seles of Yugoslavia, who has won her last 24 matches, will be top-seeded at the $5.35 million French Open tournament beginning Monday, according to Women's International Tennis Association rankings.

LEAD: The Time Inc. Magazine Company said yesterday that it had established a new unit - Time Publishing Ventures - which includes the company's regional and special interest magazines, as well as worldwide development activity. Christopher Meigher was named president and chief executive of the unit, and he will remain an executive vice president of Time Inc.

LEAD: Herman Finkelstein, the former general counsel of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, died of a heart attack on Sunday in Grandview Hospital in Sellersville, Pa. He was 87 years old and lived in Sellersville.
LEAD: General Mills Inc. took Benefit cereal off the market last December when it did not catch on with consumers, leaving the company with 50 tons of unwanted flakes.

LEAD: President Bush has decided to renew China's trade benefits for another year, concluding that the potential harm to American companies and to reform-minded Chinese outweighed a desire to register disapproval of Beijing's human-rights record, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: The Economy

LEAD: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, appointed Martin A. Stein head of BankAmerica Systems Engineering. Bankamerica also promoted Eric Von Pingel, the director of the appraisal department of its real estate division, to senior vice president.

LEAD: Polly Peck International P.L.C. said it planned to increase its stake in the Sansui Electric Company Ltd. to 70 percent from 51 percent after merging two of its electronics subsidiaries into the Japanese group.
LEAD: A Lottery
LEAD: Never mind the new taxes and cuts in basic services forced by New York State's deficit.

LEAD: Speaking of death and ruination, has it been generally observed that the Democratic Party is now worried about the budget deficit? There is no surer sign of a party drifting toward the ultimate coma.
LEAD: A high-tech issue matching the Rangers against the Islanders is expected to be on the agenda next month when the general managers of the National Hockey League meet again.

LEAD: After weeks of avoiding the press and the public, MARLA MAPLES has a new role: spokeswoman for a jeans manufacturer. She will follow DONNA RICE and JOAN RIVERS in making television commercials and print advertisements for No Excuses jeans.

LEAD: For the second year, the fund that insures the nation's bank deposits declined, the Government said today. And at the end of last year less money was available to insure each dollar deposited than at any time since the fund began in the early 1930's.

LEAD: When BERNARD PIVOT announced that he was ending ''Apostrophes,'' France's most popular and influential television talk show, millions of viewers were stunned and disappointed. For more than 15 years every Friday in prime time Mr. Pivot (pronounced pea-VOH) engaged the world's leading writers in lively, often edgy encounters.
LEAD: The Acting Comptroller General, the legal adviser to Congress, says the Bush Administration has the legal authority to drop immigration restrictions on people infected with the AIDS virus.
LEAD: New York State's Education Commissioner said today that the state's public schools should adopt a far broader measure than standardized tests in assessing student performance.

LEAD: In a country destroyed by war, there are always melancholy voices to recall how things were before the bombs and the rockets started falling. But there are still glimpses of the magnificent things that stir an Afghan's heart, and one of these can be seen as the country's nomads begin their spring migration from their lowland winter pastures into the cooling altitudes of the Hindu
LEAD: The hits have been coming like paychecks lately for Bob Geren: about once a week. Unless there are a string of rainouts, that is a distressing notion for a starter in the major leagues.
LEAD: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev won't get a chance to see billboards that portray him promoting a Minnesota-made vodka when he visits here on June 3.
LEAD: Ann K. Soskis, a retired lawyer and social work administrator, died of cancer on Sunday at her home in Philadelphia. She was 85 years old and had lived in Brooklyn.

LEAD: Western nations are giving serious consideration to a West German proposal to combine divisions from different allied armies into new multinational units, officials at a meeting of NATO Defense Ministers said today.
LEAD: Regular physical exercise can be as effective as medication in treating moderately high blood pressure, a new study has found.

LEAD: Saying he was ''very, very confident that this is the right choice for this team at this time,'' Stan Kasten, president of the Atlanta Hawks, announced yesterday that Bob Weiss was the Hawks' new coach. Weiss replaced Mike Fratello, who resigned last month after the Hawks finished the regular season with a 41-41 record and missed the playoffs for the first time since 1985.

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY'S flower market district, a bright spot since the 1890's in the often dour countenance of midtown Manhattan, is fighting for its life under pressure from urban planners, developers and the high value of midtown land.

LEAD: Widespread teacher layoffs proposed for Boston's public school system cannot be based on reverse seniority alone because court-ordered racial hiring quotas must be met, Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. has ruled.
LEAD: Ross Roy Advertising takes a poke at conventional automobile commercials in its new television campaign for the Alfa Romeo 164, the first broadcast advertising for the luxury sedan.

LEAD: After a brief and violent outpouring of rage on Monday at the killings of seven Palestinians in a town about 50 miles to the south, the hills and Arab villages of Galilee that form an Arab pocket in Israel seemed spent of their passion today.
LEAD: American Airlines will take over Eastern Airlines' Latin American routes in four phases and at a lower price than originally announced, Eastern said. Eastern sold the routes to

LEAD: Their voices echoing through the cavernous vaults of a cathedral, the top leaders of New York State and City joined last night in urging citizens not to let the city drown in racial hatred and intolerance.

LEAD: Experiments have shown for the first time that human blood cells carrying foreign genes will zero in on tumors, researchers said today. The findings could open a new strategy for treating cancer.
LEAD: rrThe question was, Did Mark Spitz get his power in the pool from his toes?

LEAD: The longtime ban on cameras in Federal courts is being reconsidered, and Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist says he is amenable to experimenting with television coverage of Federal trial and appellate proceedings.
LEAD: The National Transportation Safety Board today called on the Federal Government to require that infants and small children sit in safety seats during airline flights.
LEAD: Bruce Zabriski changed clubs this year, moving from Oyster Bay to Fresh Meadow on Long Island, but his golf game has remained constant and at a high level.
LEAD: The Lakers' Magic Johnson was voted the most valuable player in the National Basketball Association for a third time, but the first-place balloting created some controversy.

LEAD: Around the Capitol in Trenton some people have been calling the Chief Justice of the state ''Cecil B. Wilentz'' since his decision to block the producers of ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' from filming a scene at the Essex County Courthouse here.

LEAD: In a rebuff to the Bush Administration, the House of Representatives voted tonight to cut military aid to El Salvador by 50 percent. But minutes later the decision was voided when the House defeated the overall bill authorizing funds for El Salvador and other countries.

LEAD: Moving to take advantage of Brazil's plan to sell state-owned companies to private investors, Midland Bank P.L.C. is setting up a $1.5 billion fund of Brazilain bank debt to trade for shares in these converted enterprises.
LEAD: Billy Idol's Changes

LEAD: A former editor at The Wall Street Journal filed suit yesterday against Dow Jones & Company, the paper's owner, seeking $12.6 million in damages on the ground that his reputation has been severely injured because the paper wrongfully dismissed him on May 2.

LEAD: One of New York City's larger capital investments may also be one of its most underused: 1,000 school buildings open only part of the day, part of the week. A creative suggestion from a mayoral study panel would use them better to rebuild communities and fight drugs.

LEAD: Every few years a white English singer is touted as a full-fledged soul singer, worthy of comparison to black American compeers. The 23-year-old Lisa Stansfield is the latest such contender, and by far the best. At the Ritz last Wednesday night, she proved to a packed house that the sinuous, husky, emotionally supple singing on her debut album, ''Affection'' (Arista), was no studio confection.

LEAD: The cable television industry - from the people who provide the programs to those who manufacture the cable itself -have descended on Atlanta this week, more than 11,000 strong and flushed with the confidence that a decade of nearly unbridled success ought to confer.

LEAD: After months of negotiations and hearings, the New York City Council yesterday unanimously approved a bill intended to force the city to stop housing homeless families in barracks-style shelters in 16 months.

LEAD: Bush Administration officials told Congressional budget negotiators today that costs for bailing out the savings and loan industry could add $61 billion to the Federal deficit in the next fiscal year, which is about $11 billion more than the bailout cost estimated by the Administration just a week ago.

LEAD: The best the Chicago Bulls could offer the Detroit Pistons tonight was a third-period scare. The rest of the way, there was too much Piston defense, too much Joe Dumars and not enough Michael Jordan, and the Pistons came away with a 102-93 victory at The Palace.

LEAD: F.B.I. agents today searched two Northrop Corporation plants where parts for the Navy's FA-18 fighter-bomber are built, the company said. Ron Owens, a Northrop spokesman, said the company could not say what the agents were looking for at the plants in Hawthorne and El Segundo, Calif., or how the search might be related to an investigation.

LEAD: The accordionist Boozoo Chavis is chaos on two feet. A little bullet of a man, he runs around onstage, shouting and yelling. He sings salacious songs and tunes that feature his son Wilson barking like a dog. And he plays rock-hard zydeco music that shakes the walls of a club and gets dancers moving and shaking.
LEAD: On a four-block lot in Boston's South End, Kai Fok Lai crouches behind a wall of bedsprings, sticks and refrigerator shelving, working the soil with a spatula.

LEAD: YACHTING Victory Complete for Steinlager 2 The New Zealand yacht Steinlager 2 won the Whitbread Round the World race yesterday, completing an eight-month odyssey by sweeping all six legs of the event. Steinlager 2 reached Southampton, England, last night, a few minutes ahead of Fisher and Paykel, another New Zealand boat, ending the 3,837-mile final leg from Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
LEAD: The New York State Mortgage Agency offered a total of $130.74 million of homeowners mortgage revenue bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

LEAD: The White House today defended the key elements of the arms control deal that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d struck with Moscow last week, dismissing as groundless criticism from the Republican right wing that Mr. Baker made too many concessions.

LEAD: A Federal district judge has ordered the Government to disclose all events surrounding the abduction from Mexico to the United States of a doctor charged here with participating in the killing of an American drug agent.
LEAD: The State of Connecticut offered $250 million worth of special tax-obligation bonds to investors in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.

LEAD: A dozen companies in several countries, pushed by growing fears of terrorist attacks, are racing to build detectors capable of sniffing out even the best-concealed explosive. But the machines are not foolproof, and some technology is meeting resistance from the airlines, the biggest potential customer for the devices.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An 18-year-old man was indicted yesterday on discrimination and assault charges stemming from a May 13 melee in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn that left a Vietnamese immigrant seriously injured.

LEAD: In a city where politics is everything and everything is political, the can't-lose issue these days is education. Last year Mayor Richard M. Daley campaigned on it, won partly because of it and thought it so important that he created the position of deputy mayor to focus on nothing but the schools.

LEAD: The assassinated spiritual leader of Muslims in Srinagar was buried today in ceremonies attended by hundreds of thousands of Kashmiris. Separatist guerrillas, saying that the moderate Maulvi Mohammed Farooq was one of them in death, fired rounds from automatic weapons over his tomb, according to reports from the scene.

LEAD: New York City police officers will write fewer parking tickets, shifting the burden to Transportation Department agents, under a Dinkins administration plan to put more officers on the street to fight crime, city officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Childrens Defense Fund, told graduates of the New School for Social Research yesterday that with the end of the Cold War, the United States has ''a great opportunity to push children to the top of national concern.''
LEAD: THERE is probably no food more American. Not even apple pie.

LEAD: Responding to mounting criticism from the business community, the trustees who oversee the Financial Accounting Standards Board agreed yesterday to make it harder for the board to create new accounting rules.

LEAD: U.N. Moves to Hear Arafat The Security Council agreed to meet in Geneva to hear Yasir Arafat speak, sparing the Bush Administration a decision on his entry. Page A7. Airline Safety for Infants The National Transportation Safety Board urged the Government to require that infants sit in safety seats during airline flights.

LEAD: KATHLEEN TURNER, whose Broadway portrayal of Maggie in ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' has earned her a Tony Award nomination, will play the role again next season - on television. She will appear in an ABC version of the Tennessee Williams play, the network said yesterday.(AP)

LEAD: When Neil Bush, the President's son, was on the board of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver, he voted to approve loans worth $106 million to a business partner while failing to disclose their relationship, Federal regulators said today.

LEAD: About 30 manufacturers of personal computers said today that they would include the Microsoft Corporation's new Windows 3.0 program with computers they sell, a move that will help push the program toward becoming a standard.

LEAD: Dave Clark, given a chance with the bases loaded after a record-setting fifth intentional walk to Andre Dawson, singled in the winning run in the 16th inning today as the Chicago Cubs outlasted the Cincinnati Reds, 2-1.

LEAD: The House of Representatives approved the Americans With Disabilities Act today by a vote of 403 to 20; following are listings of the Representatives who voted against the measure and the Representatives who did not vote.

LEAD: An article yesterday about French Canadian business leaders in Montreal misstated the year that the separatist government of Rene Levesque took power in Quebec. It was 1976. In some copies, a picture caption with the article misstated the age of Jacques Menard, a vice chairman and managing director of a brokerage firm.

LEAD: The marquee at the Lyric Theater on West 42d Street often promises ''Two Horrifying Hits.'' But inside, once past the garish posters, the popcorn and video games, a theatergoer can look up at the wide arching ceiling and feel emanations of the performers who once played the Lyric and who helped to make 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth

LEAD: The United States Government has found ''possible irregularities,'' which may include kickbacks, in the Iraqi Government's purchases of American agricultural commodities, jeopardizing a $500 million payment guarantee that Iraq has requested from the Commodity Credit Corporation.

LEAD: When the U.S. swooped down on Panama last Christmas and captured Manuel Noriega, it pledged a model criminal trial. Prosecutors and defense lawyers have just struck a deal that fits another kind of model. It insures that his lawyers will be paid, apparently in return for agreeing not to demand evidence that might help their client and hurt the
LEAD: Just about everyone - players, coaches, fans and reporters - agreed that for the Edmonton Oilers to succeed tonight, they needed more hitting and offensive production from Mark Messier.

LEAD: Morris Levy, an owner of record companies and nightclubs who was under a Federal sentence of 10 years in prison on an extortion conviction, died of liver cancer on Monday at his home in Ghent, N.Y. He was 62 years old.
LEAD: Four former high school football teammates from Glen Ridge, N.J., were indicted today on charges that they sexually assaulted a retarded teen-age girl on March 1, 1989.
LEAD: The Belzberg family of Vancouver, British Columbia, said it was evaluating its investment in Armstrong World Industries after winning a seats on the company's board.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' the Petipa-Tchaikovsky classic that is the jewel in the diadem of 19th-century ballet, is also one of the most difficult works in the international dance repertory.
LEAD: Anthony F. Barry, the principal of Public School 42 in Chinatown for the last 15 years, died of cancer on Sunday at his home on Staten Island. He was 59 years old.

LEAD: An article on Saturday about an agreement on a New York State budget described aid reductions to colleges of the City University of New York incorrectly. The John Jay College of Criminal Justice will lose $3 million and New York City Technical College will lose $17 million.

LEAD: THE gravest problem facing Western companies hoping to advertise on television in the Soviet Union may not be Government bureaucracy, consumer apathy or the lack of programming. It seems to be exploding television sets.
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would keep three military electronics subsidiaries that it put up for sale in December, because no one had made an acceptable offer.
LEAD: It's already too late to book the Japanese Room at Antoine's Restaurant for the evening of Dec. 31, 1999. The room is being held for a client who is throwing a turn-of-the-century party.
LEAD: Prosecutors today sought to modify charges against an art gallery being accused of obscenity for exhibiting photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe.

LEAD: Bobby Manso, a sixth grader at Public School 94 in the north Bronx, was in trouble - again. He had been fighting with his classmates, cursing at teachers and making another play for attention by threatening to burn down the school and kill himself.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The antique conventions of Arkansas politics seemed durable enough at a recent Chamber of Commerce dinner here. Catfish and fiddle music were devoured in the warm twilight, and a state legislator handed out yardsticks emblazoned with his campaign slogans.

LEAD: The Bush Administration's plans to buy costly new long-range nuclear weapons are being challenged by a growing number of military experts and members of Congress. They say the country has a chance to save tens of billions of dollars by slowing the purchases and seeking an agreement with the Soviet Union to reduce nuclear arsenals drastically.
LEAD: Kevin Duckworth has made it clear that his broken right hand will not keep him from giving the Portland Trail Blazers a helping hand in the playoffs.

LEAD: Leonard Bernstein, who was to have conducted the opening concert on Friday at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., has canceled his appearance because of illness. The 71-year-old conductor said yesterday, in a statement, that he was ''recovering from a brush with pneumonia.''
LEAD: Dr. Charles Polk, a physician in New Jersey for more than 60 years, died of pneumonia on Friday at St. Elizabeth Hospital, Elizabeth, N.J. He was 98 years old and lived in Roselle, N.J.

LEAD: An editorial notebook Monday incorrectly reported that the Sabre Foundation, which sends books to Eastern Europe, has an associated foundation in Czechoslovakia. Its associated groups are in Poland and Hungary.

LEAD: It was quite a day for Adam Davidson, a 25-year-old graduate student in the film division of the Columbia University School of the Arts. On Monday, his first film, a black-and-white, 10 1/2-minute movie called ''The Lunch Date,'' won the prize for best short film at the Cannes International Film Festival in

LEAD: Representative Larry E. Craig won the Republican primary tonight in the race to succeed Senator James A. McClure, who is retiring, while Democrats picked a Boise businessman to seek to gain control of the seat.

LEAD: Movement toward compromise on the Baltic republics' campaign for independence stopped today, as Lithuania rejected demands to suspend its declaration of independence and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned all three Baltic republics that they must abide by Soviet law.

LEAD: The Security Council agreed on a face-saving formula tonight that would spare the Bush Administration the political hazards of allowing Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to enter the United States, or barring him.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: By the time their charter flight rose into the afternoon sky today, the only thing the Mets could remember about the trip was its conclusion. They had dismissed being swept in San Francisco and being in disarray in San Diego, and when they left for home, all they seemed to have packed away was sudden contentment.

LEAD: JIMMY BRESLIN returns in print tomorrow in Newsday. But he will be minus at least one newspaper that carries his syndicated column. The Oregonian in Portland has dropped the column because of the racial slurs Mr. Breslin aimed at a Korean-American woman, a Newsday reporter, who criticized one of his columns as sexist.

LEAD: The city so often seems all flash, splash and split-second obsolescence. But the truth is that it is the quieter, more unobtrusive sorts who get things done in New York City. They know and care for others. They put in exactly a lifetime of work without complaint. At their funerals, they are remembered as nice people.

LEAD: For Dalva Ferreira da Vitoria, wife of a building superintendent, Brazil's radical new economic plan means frozen prices in supermarkets here, a welcome respite after prices jumped 84 percent in March.

LEAD: Buoyed by a strong dollar and, for a time, by reports that the Government might have $50 billion in unspent appropriations to slash the deficit, stocks fluctuated broadly yesterday before ending with a modest gain, and a record.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A judge rebuffed defense pleas today and ordered that Christian Brando remain in jail on a murder charge. ''The court finds there is no basis for setting bail,'' Municipal Judge Rosemary Shumsky said. The defendant's father, Marlon Brando, sat stony-faced in the front row as William Kunstler, the civil rights lawyer, argued that the shooting of a house guest last week at the actor's home was an accident and that Christian Brando was drunk at the time.
LEAD: * Ramada International Hotels & Resorts, to Ketchum Advertising in Los Angeles, for its North America account.

LEAD: BTR P.L.C. agreed to buy a unit of the United Technologies Corporation for $200 million in cash. Through its Schlegel Corporation subsidiary in Rochester, BTR will buy the Global Automotive Sealing Systems Group from United Technologies, an industrial conglomerate based in Hartford.

LEAD: East Germany today accused a former top Communist official of squandering Government money, the first formal criminal charges to be brought against a member of the old regime. The official, 61-year-old Werner Krolikowski, a former Deputy Prime Minister, faces trial in an East Berlin city court on charges of abuse of trust, said Peter Przbylski, a spokesman for the state prosecutor's office.
LEAD: About 25 student protesters remained in the headquarters of he City University of New said they would not end their occupation until the university had met their demands.

LEAD: New York City is proposing to lower the fee it charges private garbage haulers to use the Fresh Kills landfill, reversing its commitment to prolong the life of the huge dump, while possibly giving the carting industry a windfall.

LEAD: A seven-year scientific battle came to a peaceable end yesterday for a Federal researcher who had asserted that high Government officials were misled about the feasibility of a proposed anti-missile laser and that he had faced reprisals for his outspokenness.
LEAD: EATING a high-fiber breakfast may help you eat less for lunch.

LEAD: Jim McMahon, the often-injured, charismatic and controversial quarterback who was released by the San Diego Chargers last month, is intrigued by a recent contract offer from the Philadelphia Eagles, according to Steve Zucker, his agent.

LEAD: The Metropolitan Greek Chorale, though missing a key element planned for its 25th-anniversary concert on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall, managed to pull together plenty of music anyway. The program offered one new work, Stabat Mater, by George Tsontakis, the chorus's conductor, and a new movement of another, ''The God Abandons Antony,'' by Nicolas Roussakis.

LEAD: The Xerox Corporation introduced a line of facsimile machines that use plain paper and double as copiers. John P. Lafferty of the company's information products division said many users prefer receiving facsimiles on plain paper. The machines are all made in Japan by the Fuji Xerox Corporation, although they were developed by Xerox engineers in the United States.
LEAD: The Coast Guard said today that 10 present and former enlisted personnel were under investigation in a widening inquiry into drug corruption at a station in the Florida Keys.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Thousands of Christians returned to their shell-pocked homes today as new measures were taken to stabilize a week-old cease-fire.

LEAD: The American Contract Bridge League defines a senior player as one who is 55 years old or more. On Feb. 27 more than 9200 seniors competed in a special event in clubs all across North America and one of the oldest players - perhaps the oldest - was the winner.

LEAD: Sock Shop International P.L.C. will close 58 stores, more than half its British outlets, to try to save the business, its administrators said today. The company closed its 17 United States stores in December. Closing 58 British stores out of 109 will mean cutting 150 jobs, the administrators said.

LEAD: For the first time in nearly four years since he admitted to insider trading, Ivan F. Boesky testified in public yesterday, providing details of the crimes he committed with an array of investment bankers and traders.
LEAD: A lengthy process under which Staten Islanders could seek state approval to secede from New York City was upheld yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

LEAD: Western nations are giving serious consideration to a West German proposal to combine divisions from different allied armies into new multinational units, officials at a meeting of NATO Defense Ministers in Brussels said yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A senior official of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Government accused India today of direct responsibility for the assassination in Indian-ruled Kashmir on Monday of the territory's most senior Muslim cleric, Maulvi Mohammed Farooq. ''It was a little rough at first,'' Mr. Frisell recalled. ''After Berklee music school in Boston, I went to Europe for a year to play. That was where I first recorded with Eberhard Weber, and I did a tour with Mike Gibbs, so I was playing a lot in Europe.

LEAD: President Bush indicated today that he would withhold normal trade status from the Soviet Union as long as the Lithuanian question remained unresolved. At the same time he confirmed that he was renewing such economic benefits for China despite Beijing's hard-line policies.
LEAD: The nation's top health official said today that states should license the sale of cigarettes in the same strict fashion as alcohol and that they should ban cigarette vending machines.
LEAD: Anti-Government protesters rioted in Gabon's two biggest cities on Wednesday, burning public buildings and property belonging to President Omar Bongo and aides, witnesses said today.

LEAD: Irving Jacobson, chairman of the Jacobson and Quails chains of men's clothing stores in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, died of liver disease yesterday at the Somerset Medical Center in Somerville, N.J. He was 65 years old and lived in Bridgewater, N.J.

LEAD: In the Kremlin corridors where the apprentices of the new Soviet politics roam, the question of questions today was why Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the putative master pol, seemed to be almost recklessly courting public rejection.

LEAD: ''Some say quality of life is best defined by spotless parks and litter-free roadways. But for me it is best exemplified by a happy, healthy baby or by a teen-ager with a diploma in hand and a sparkle in the eye.'' - Mayor David N. Dinkins. [A1:2.]
LEAD: DESPITE lenders' growing reluctance to finance leveraged acquisitions, two investment firms are betting that they can profit by buying stocks of companies involved in buyouts.

LEAD: The Ogden Corporation, which took a curious but successful route from heavy industry to the service field under Ralph E. Ablon, said yesterday that Mr. Ablon had relinquished the posts of president and chief executive to his son, Richard.
LEAD: * Guinness Import Co., to Carroll Raj Stagliano, for Bass Ale.
LEAD: President Bush ignited Democratic tempers in Congress today when he refused once again to address the public on the severity of the deficit problem or to offer proposals to solve it.

LEAD: Continental will start flying nonstop from El Paso to Mexico City on July 1, becoming the first major airline to fly directly from the border city into Mexico since the early 1980's. Travelers now have to go through Dallas, Houston or Los Angeles to get to Mexico City. Round-trip fares will range from $334 for a seven-day advance purchase for a weekday flight to $337 for a full-fare weekend flight.

LEAD: The Exxon Corporation oil-cleaners are back on the beaches of Prince William Sound, amid continuing disagreement about the extent of damage to the sea and the shoreline from the nation's worst oil spill.
LEAD: Bruce Zabriski today justified his reputation as one of the best professional golfers in the New York metropolitan area by winning the $100,000 Dodge Open for the second consecutive year.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate yesterday cleared the way for the construction of a 55-story office building that will be part of the Rockefeller Center complex in mid-Manhattan. The new tower - tentatively called Rockefeller Plaza West - would be on the east side of Seventh Avenue between West 49th and 50th

Recently, Mr. Menem moved out of the official residence in the Buenos Aires suburb of Olivos and into the home of his private secretary, MIGUEL ANGEL VI

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 401 to 21 by which the House of Representatives approved the clean air bill on Wednesday night. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the bill. Voting ''yes'' were 246 Democrats and 155 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 5 Democrats and 16 Republicans. Y is a ''yes'' vote.

LEAD: The next British election campaign has already begun, though nobody knows when the vote will take place - a year from now, or even two, when the mandate of the Parliament that was elected in 1987 will expire.

LEAD: Graf Bertel Dominique has resigned the advertising account of Paul Stuart Inc., after handling the Madison Avenue clothier for just several weeks. The agency said it had resigned the $2 million account because of creative differences.
LEAD: In votes on a series of amendments to anti-crime legislation, the Senate today took a generally tough stance in favor of capital punishment.
LEAD: Confidential memorandums about crimes were sent by New York City detectives to high-ranking police officials, a Police Department spokeswoman said yesterday.

LEAD: Dave Stewart became the American League's first eight-game winner this season, and Jose Canseco had four hits, including two home runs, as the Oakland Athletics defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 13-1.
LEAD: Burt J. Siris, a manufacturer of handbags, accessories and luggage, died of emphysema Wednesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 71 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Ivan F. Boesky testified yesterday that he had deducted from his income taxes half of the $100 million he paid to settle insider trading charges, kept millions in ill-gotten gains and illegally paid fellow prisoners to do his laundry.

LEAD: ADC Telecommunications Inc. said yesterday that it had named William J. Cadogan as its next president and chief operating officer. Mr. Cadogan, 41, led the company's recent expansion into fiber optics from the core business of providing telephone equipment.

LEAD: A grand jury yesterday indicted Hub Recycling Inc. and two affiliated companies in connection with a wide range of environmental and financial crimes relating to the August 1989 garbage fire that buckled parts of Interstate 78 in Newark.
LEAD: Lone Star Technologies had grand plans for turning around the American Federal Bank of Dallas after it bought the savings institution from the Government in late 1988.

LEAD: Girard Parnters L.P., the investment group seeking to gain control of the board of the Pic 'N' Save Corporation, said that if its nominees are elected they would create an advisory committee of representatives of institutional shareholders to recommend how to sell the company.

LEAD: The rules of racing in many states require that a horse who bleeds from the nose after a race or morning exercise is ineligible to race for at least 10 days.

LEAD: A chart yesterday recounting 60 years of major Federal firearms legislation omitted one measure. It was a 1988 Congressional ban on ''plastic'' guns, or firearms consisting of less than 3.7 ounces of steel; it required that all guns be detectable by airport X-ray machines.

LEAD: Congress Backs Latin Aid The Congress gave final approval to an emergency spending bill that includes $720 million for Panama and Nicaragua. Page A3. Noriega Deal Collapses In a setback to prosecutors, a judge said the Government's financing of Manuel Antonio Noriega's defense would be illegal.

LEAD: Deflating a recent impression that the economy was chugging along quite nicely, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that the sluggish economic growth that had set in last September had continued through the first quarter.
