LEAD: Bob Boone, the Kansas City catcher, has been put on the disabled list for the first time in his 17-year career.

LEAD: The Badal Roy Quintet is to open the Improvisations IV Festival with a program called ''Jazz India'' at 8 tonight at Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street. Mr. Roy, a tabla player, formed his ensemble last year to perform music that draws upon American jazz and African and Indian idioms.

LEAD: The Florio administration today proposed an overhaul of the school-financing law that would transfer tens of millions of dollars in state aid from wealthy suburban districts to middle-class and poor urban schools beginning in the 1991-92 school year.
LEAD: Russ M. Herman of New Orleans is a man enchanted with his work, as a recent ''president's page'' in Trial magazine amply attests.

LEAD: Augie Donatelli, a National League umpire for 24 years and the founder in 1964 of the Major League Umpires Association, died today. He was 76 years old. Mr. Donatelli died in his sleep at home, his wife, Mary, said.

LEAD: The Bank of Boston Corporation's debt ratings were reduced by Moody's Investors Service yesterday because of loan problems and a weak regional economy. The senior debt was reduced to a speculative-grade, ''junk bond'' category of Ba-1, from the investment grade of Baa-3.

LEAD: Music to commute by will be offered today at three popular sites of transportation. At Grand Central Terminal, from noon to 4 P.M., the Music Under New York Big Band will play jazz pieces by Roy Campbell, Cal and Zane Massey and others. At Penn Station, also from noon to 2 P.M., rock music from the 1950's and 60's will be offered by Doc Rock and the Transports.

LEAD: The nation's inner-city schools, already strained by the collapse of families and the wounds of poverty, will face another onslaught this fall -the first big wave of children prenatally exposed to crack.

LEAD: The thing you have to remember about time travel is that it's notoriously unreliable. Baggage is always being sent on to the wrong epoch, and return tickets are never guaranteed.

LEAD: Christopher d'Amboise, a former principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, has been named artistic director of the Pennsylvania Ballet, effective in August. Mr. d'Amboise, who is 30 years old, is also the founder, director and choreographer of the Off Center Ballet and a Tony Award-winning Broadway dancer.

LEAD: The VPI Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it had been deceived by Donald C. Carter, founder and former chief executive of the Carter Organization, about the value of Mr. Carter's proxy solicitation firm when VPI acquired it in 1987. VPI made the claims in a lawsuit seeking unspecified damages filed in United States District Court in New York.

LEAD: Japan Air Lines, Japan's largest airline and the Boeing Company's largest customer, said today that it had ordered 20 Boeing 747-400 jets and had taken options to buy 34 more.

LEAD: Roberta Soble, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Soble of Lido Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Eric M. Dochter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Dochter of Roslyn, L.I. LEAD: POKING fun at an old stereotype, Ted Chin, a rare Chinese-American advertising executive, likes to refer to himself as inscrutable. His friends laugh when he says it, for Mr. Chin is one of the most candid individuals in advertising. In an industry where criticism is usually given privately, Mr. Chin goes public.

LEAD: In an attempt to revive stalemated talks on expanding air travel between the United States and the Soviet Union, the Soviets requested today that the negotiations be resumed in Washington this weekend, American officials said.
LEAD: Just when riders of the East London line had resigned themselves to the pungent sweat-and-crush endurance test of subway travel, their noses sniffed roses.
LEAD: Albert Kindler, a real-estate broker and an investor, died of congestive heart failure on Wednesday at Tisch Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in White Plains.
LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that Lithuania could be independent in two years if the republic suspended its declaration of independence, Lithuanian officials said tonight.

LEAD: The next time somebody on the street is whispering urgently into a fast-food hamburger wrapper, think again. He or she may be a graduate of Learning Annex Course No. 523, ''How to Get Anything on Anybody.''

LEAD: Margaret J. Sedlis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Sedlis of New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Goldstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Goldstein of New York. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in New York.
LEAD: An explosion in a car today injured two members of a militant environmental group, and a member of the group said tonight police planned to file charges of carrying explosives against the two.

LEAD: When the Plaids, a mythical 1950's male quartet from eastern Pennsylvania, perform a piece of vintage kitsch like ''Three Coins in the Fountain,'' they don't merely sing it in smooth four-part harmonies that echo the Four Aces; they physically illustrate the lyrics with a painstaking literalness. LEAD: The rains of May have transformed the Hudson Valley into an ocean of green -green alfalfa waving in the breeze awaiting its first cutting for hay, green apple leaves, green tips of emerging corn, green leaves of strawberry plants. But if the soothing sight of pastoral green is not sufficient for visitors, the valley offers a variety of things to do this weekend, ranging from walking on the Appalachian Trail to attending an arts and crafts fair or visiting a bucolic museum.

LEAD: The war of words between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission heated up today as Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the S.E.C., and Wendy L. Gramm, the chairwoman of the futures commission, appeared before the House Energy and Commerce Committee's telecommunications and finance subcommittee.

LEAD: What happened to American art during the tumultuous, combative 1980's is a large and multi-faceted subject that will undoubtedly be debated for some time. But less than six months into the 90's, one of the first assessments has already arrived, in the form of the messy, provocative exhibition titled ''The Decade Show: Frameworks of Identity in the 1980's.

LEAD: The National Football League will examine the financial structure of the San Francisco 49ers at a hearing in mid-June to determine if the structure gives the 1990 Super Bowl champions an unfair edge. No specific hearing date has been set.
LEAD: Charles M. Wiltse, a historian and an editor of the papers of Daniel Webster, died on Tuesday at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H. He was 83 years old and lived in Hanover.

LEAD: Last September, Joe Morris broke his right foot in the Giants' final preseason game and sat out the entire season. Today, when most of the Giants' veterans reported for a minicamp, Morris returned to the field and learned that people had short memories.

LEAD: Chiat/Day/Mojo and Hans Brindfors Advertising, a Stockholm ad agency with which Chiat has had an informal personnel exchange program, yesterday announced plans to develop a network of jointly owned agencies in Europe.

LEAD: Poland's ambitious program to force-feed this country free-market capitalism has reached its most crucial juncture to date, with the Government simultaneously confronting serious labor unrest and skittishness among foreign investors.

LEAD: A combination of high-energy activities, tranquil outings and somber commemorations should entice people out of doors in Westchester County over the Memorial Day weekend. There will be flamenco dancing at Playland Park, pig racing at a county fair in Yonkers and an early-morning bird walk through a nature preserve on Long Island Sound.

LEAD: The Chilmark Management Corporation, an investment management firm in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., said it had bought more than 2.2 million shares, or more than 5 percent, of the UJB Financial Corporation, a banking company in Princeton, N.J. UJB, which owns United Jersey Bank, has been hurt by the slowdown in the New Jersey economy, but has remained profitable.

LEAD: Dr. Robert Turell, a physician and an educator at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died on Saturday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: This is a city awaiting the unknown. From the main roads to the east and the north, after five months of often-brutal fighting in the countryside, a rebel army is advancing.

LEAD: Among the harbor cities of Europe, Rotterdam does not have a high profile in the travel industry. People do not boast of having been there, the way they boast of having been to Hamburg, Marseilles or Genoa. Largely destroyed early in World War II, Rotterdam does not tempt the tourist.
LEAD: A Federal judge in Tampa, Fla., granted a defense motion yesterday that moved the extortion case of Howard Spira to New York.

LEAD: Two pianists who were in on the birth of rock-and-roll headlined the first two nights of the Piano Blues Who's Who, a three-part series presented at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights.

LEAD: The soprano Julianne Baird and the fortepianist Steven Lubin are to perform with the Classical Quartet in an all-Beethoven program at 8 tonight at St. Michael's Church, 225 West 99th Street. The program includes the Piano Quartet in E flat (Op. 16), the String Quartet in D (Op. 18, No. 4) and a group of folk-song settings.

LEAD: The Dutch artist Jan Dibbets is best known for a series of panoramas of land, sea and sky done in the early 1970's, at a time when Earth Art, Conceptual Art and photography seemed natural allies. By the time he moved to New York in 1968, he was looking at influential abstract modernists like Frank Stella and Kenneth

LEAD: Television portraits of composers, however well intended, usually walk an awkward line between being an introduction for the uninitiated and a brush-up course for aficionados. Time constraints militate in favor of musical snippets rather than uninterrupted performances. Careers and accomplishments are condensed, and analysis is rare.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 503 money market mutual funds increased by $94.70 million, to $381.41 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 159 institutional funds increased by $141.40 million, to $92.80 billion. The assets of the 242 general-purpose funds were down by $750.10 million, to $129.48 billion.
LEAD: Dang Viet Chau, a former Deputy Prime Minister of Vietnam, died of a brain hemorrhage on Monday in Hanoi, the official Hanoi radio said. No age was given.

LEAD: In an unusually outspoken clash between two Reagan Administration officials, Robert C. McFarlane has accused former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger of slander, libel and mean-spiritedness.

LEAD: Memorial Day weekend in Connecticut promises several untraditional events, including a hot-air balloon regatta in Bristol, a frog-jumping contest in Cornwall and sports-car racing in Lime Rock, as well as such traditional celebrations as a lobster festival in Mystic, train and boat rides in Essex and a parade in Fairfield.
LEAD: The Soviet Prime Minister detailed the Kremlin's plan for a ''regulated market economy'' that has little to do with market principles. Page A8.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A2-12 Economic benefits for Moscow will be withheld by the U.S. as long as the Lithuanian question remains unresolved, President Bush said. But he confirmed that he was renewing preferential trade status for China despite Beijing's hard-line policies. Page A1

LEAD: Adobe Systems Inc., which supplies software that controls laser printers, said its revenues and earnings in its second quarter would be sharply lower than anticipated, largely because of a decline in sales to Apple Computer Inc., its largest customer.

LEAD: Pierre Andre Rinfret, the almost certain Republican candidate for governor of New York, has little state governmental and political experience but could be an oratorical match for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on the stump, many economists and business executives agreed yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The British Columbia Lions finally got their man with the arrival of a long-awaited document.

LEAD: Judith Gordon is to play Haydn's Sonata in C minor (Hob. XVI:20), Ravel's ''Valses Nobles et Sentimentales,'' Bartok's Improvisations (Op. 20) and Liszt's Sonata in B minor at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tickets are $10. Information: 570-3949.
LEAD: The Bush Administration reaffirmed its view today that the Palestine Liberation Organization has kept its promise not to engage in terrorism.

LEAD: Striving to put his stamp on New York City's spending in tough times, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday proposed a restrained budget calling for nearly $1 billion in new taxes, deep cuts in services from street cleaning to school aides and a few modest new social and health programs.

LEAD: If you have any doubts that New Yorkers are in a thrifty mood these days, just drop into the teeming dining room of Rose Cafe, an upbeat American restaurant on lower Fifth Avenue that serves single-digit appetizers and main courses that peak at $19. The success of this six-month-old effort is even more impressive considering it occupies a space that has seen two higher-priced flops in the past three years, Mosaico and 24 Fifth Avenue.

LEAD: Memorial Day will be celebrated on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Memorial Day Parade, starting at 10: A.M. Broadway will be closed from 72d to 86th streets from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M. Government offices: Federal, State and municipal closed Monday. Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only Monday; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.

LEAD: The Our Towns column on Tuesday, about the decline of many community orchestras, referred incorrectly to the Nutley (N.J.) Symphony. It did complete its 1990 concert schedule, and is preparing for its next season.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Bush's White House news conference today, as recorded by the Federal News Service: OPENING STATEMENT

LEAD: Dancers floated happily on air Wednesday night when Dance Theater Workshop celebrated its 25th anniversary with a gala performance at the Joyce Theater. The levitation and levity were justified, for D.T.W., as the organization is familiarly known, has been a major producer and supporter of dance attractions since 1965.
LEAD: Dr. Eleanor Alexander Jackson, a research scientist in medical bacteriology, died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: An obituary yesterday about a lawyer who was a founder of the New York Liberal Party rendered his name incorrectly. He was Marx Lewis.
LEAD: ''Fire Birds'' is a ludicrous action-romance about the United States Army's attack helicopters known as Apaches, and the heroic men and women who fly them in peace and in war.
LEAD: Gov. Jim Florio urged graduates of Rutgers University today to actively fight incidents of bias and intolerance.
LEAD: Walt Williams, a University of Maryland guard, said he had contacted Georgia Tech and St. John's regarding a transfer, The Baltimore Sun reported yesterday.

LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a decline of 1.7 percent in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended on May 15.
LEAD: * Acustar Inc., Troy, Mich., the parts unit of Chrysler Corp., said it would invest $31.9 million in its McGraw Glass and Detroit Axle operations.
LEAD: In its overwhelming passage of a comprehensive clean air measure after only a single day of floor debate, the House of Representatives seemed the model of legislative efficiency.
LEAD: The founder and leader of a Hare Krishna community was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of scheming to murder, kidnap and beat various followers.
LEAD: Charles J. Mason, a retired vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died on Monday at his home in Stonington, Conn. He was 90 years old.
LEAD: The ITT Financial Corporation offered $100 million of senior notes yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

LEAD: Emperor Akihito apologized tonight for Japan's brutal subjugation of Korea nearly a half century ago. It was the first time that unambiguous acceptance of responsibility for Japanese wartime aggression had ever been expressed at such a high level.

LEAD: Just three days after it was reached, an unusual agreement for the Federal Government to finance the legal defense of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega collapsed today when the judge in the case determined that it would be illegal.

Creating a band of actors hired to modernize a Passion play within the film, Mr.
LEAD: The Arizona Public Service Company offered $125 million of first mortgage bonds yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.

LEAD: President Bush is right to propose renewing China's trade privileges. But he would have sent a sounder message if he had expressed outrage over Beijing's continued gross abuse of human rights. Congress, which has 30 days to review the proposal, again will have to make clear that approving it in no sense approves repression.

LEAD: THE Commerce Department's revision of the gross national product data for the first quarter of 1990 heightens the picture of an economy suffering from slugflation, a mixture of sluggish growth and inflation that is a kissing cousin to stagflation.

LEAD: The average homeowner will pay $33 more in New York City property taxes, services at the city's branch libraries will be cut and the streets and parks will become dirtier if the $28 billion budget presented yesterday by Mayor David N. Dinkins is adopted.
LEAD: Rhythm From Zaire

LEAD: Hopes for a smooth re-entry into democratic life in Chile have been dashed by a wave of political violence, including one assassination and two attempted killings, in the 11 weeks since President Patricio Aylwin took office.

LEAD: As we approach the first anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre, China tugs at our understanding and our conscience. In a world of spreading democracy, how can so vast and talented a nation remain under authoritarian rule? Is there reason to hope for change? What should we on the outside do to help?

LEAD: The Postal Service has introduced what it calls a revolutionary innovation: a plastic postage stamp that not only needs no licking, but also can be purchased at banks' automated teller machines.
LEAD: President Ramiz Alia will move gradually in changing an orthodox Stalinist system in a country virtually sealed off to the world for four decades, two of his senior advisers say.

LEAD: James Edwards, the Detroit Pistons' power forward, was fined $3,500 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for his confrontation with Ed Nealy of the Chicago Bulls in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference championship series on Tuesday night.
LEAD: Mr. Affandi, an Expressionist painter whose works were exhibited worldwide, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: ''A Zed and Two Noughts'' was shown as part of the 1986 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 20, 1986. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, an article on Monday about a House clean air bill carried an incomplete listing in some copies for the areas where service stations and their suppliers would be required to sell cleaner-burning gasoline. The areas are Los Angeles, Houston, New York, Baltimore, Chicago, Milwaukee, Philadelphia, San Diego and most of Connecticut.
LEAD: The status of Manager Joe Morgan of the Boston Red Sox was settled yesterday when he was rewarded with another one-year contract extension through 1991.

LEAD: The Edmonton Oilers, in a move that provoked tears and loathing, traded Wayne Gretzky on Aug. 9, 1988. The date and the deal, of course, changed the Oilers forever. Tonight, though, the Oilers demonstrated that the change had not necessarily been for the worse.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in thin trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities after an unexpectedly poor auction of $8.5 billion worth of new five-year notes.

LEAD: The financial restructuring proposed by Resorts International Inc. to shed most of its $927 million debt has been approved by committees representing its two groups of bondholders, the casino company said today.
LEAD: Bill Shoemaker, who won five Belmont Stakes in his record-setting career, is the winner of the Mike Venezia Memorial Award, voted on by New York racing fans, racing writers and jockeys.

LEAD: Since ''The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover'' opened, Peter Greenaway has come to be known as the artist of sex, cannibalism and disputed X ratings. But long before that, he was making esoteric, witty, little-seen films. Samuel Beckett, Monty Python, Jorge Luis Borges and musical Minimalism are just a few of the influences that echo through the five shorts, made in the mid- to late 1970's, that open today for a three-week run at the Public Theater under the title ''Tastings of Greenaway.

LEAD: The characters in Sherry Kramer's ''What a Man Weighs'' are employees in a book conservation laboratory devoted to insuring the continuing life of words in print. The playwright provides the audience with intriguing details of this profession, raising questions that apply to art as well as literature.

LEAD: The role of Aurora in ''The Sleeping Beauty'' does not lend itself to imaginative acting. Aurora is a symbol of awakening womanhood and the pretext for one of the classical ballet's most beloved spectacles. Cheryl Yeager chose not to act the role but to dance it - triumphantly - when American Ballet Theater presented the Petipa-Tchaikovsky classic on Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera

LEAD: Officials of the Long Island Power Authority met with officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today to discuss together, for the first time, the fate of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station.

LEAD: An article on Sunday about the California governorship campaign of Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp omitted part of his statement explaining the appearance of contradictions in his position on the death penalty.

LEAD: The board of the Joffrey Ballet voted last night to have Gerald Arpino continue as artistic director of the financially troubled company, from which he resigned as director and resident choreographer on May 1. His resignation was not accepted by the board.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation did not grow into the world's No. 1 auto maker by thinking small or bucking the economies of assembly-line manufacturing. But G.M. has been trying to do both at the factory that assembles the Buick Reatta coupe, and G.M. executives now seem pleased enough with the result to consider using the system for other models.

LEAD: The last episode of ABC's widely publicized series ''Twin Peaks'' resolved none of its mysteries Wednesday night, including its future ratings prospects, as the May sweep rating month concluded with an unexpected storyline: vulnerability for NBC and viability for CBS.
LEAD: John Michael Kingsland, an investment banker, died of a heart attack on Monday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 58 years old and lived in Boston.

LEAD: President Bush vetoed legislation today that would continue the Federal subsidy for Amtrak, the national passenger railroad system, saying he objected to a provision that would subject certain takeovers of freight railroad lines to Government review.

LEAD: Herman B. Ferguson, a former radical in New York City who spent 19 years as a fugitive abroad to avoid prison for conspiring to kill moderate civil rights leaders, pleaded guilty yesterday to bail jumping.
LEAD: Vito P. Battista, an architect from Brooklyn, a former Assemblyman and a colorful perennial candidate for elective office, died yesterday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 81 years old.

LEAD: In what may be the first conviction of its kind, a Federal jury has found a company in Burlington, Mass., and its president guilty of knowingly violating the nation's Clean Water Act and endangering company employees as a result.

LEAD: The Navy today reopened its investigation into the explosion on the battleship Iowa after an ''unexplained ignition'' of gunpowder bags in a test earlier in the day raised the possibility that the Iowa blast was accidental.
LEAD: The Economy

LEAD: The Dinkins administration's new budget for New York City laudably strives to maintain a commitment to compassion despite falling revenues. There is one glaring lapse: a willingness to sacrifice clean streets. Otherwise, Mayor David Dinkins offers the State Legislature and City Council an example of reason and responsibility.

LEAD: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's concert in the Richardson Auditorium at Princeton University this evening, conducted by Hugh Wolff and featuring a new Viola Concerto by John Harbison, represented a homecoming for the composer.
LEAD: Continental Airlines yesterday matched fare cuts made by other carriers and said it would honor United Airlines coupons that take an additional $35 off round-trip prices.

LEAD: SPRING, rarely a season to dally in New York, has already come and gone, as the arrival of Memorial Day weekend heralds the season of beaches, barbecues and sweltering streets. During the next few days, the coming of summer will be duly noted with fireworks, outdoor concerts, fairs and parades throughout the city.
LEAD: Diane, I'm up Twin Peaks without a clue.

LEAD: COLLEGE BASEBALL North Carolina Beats Rutgers The National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament began yesterday and in a Northeast regional game in Waterbury, Conn., North Carolina defeated Rutgers, 3-2. Brad Woodall singled in the go-ahead run in the seventh inning and Jim Dougherty pitched a seven-hitter for North Carolina.

LEAD: ''The Lavoro affair'' is what some of us call the Government of Iraq's manipulation of the American and Italian banking systems to help Dictator Saddam Hussein finance the building of a missile with a nuclear warhead.

LEAD: ADELA HOLZER, the former Broadway producer who was an original backer of ''Hair,'' was sentenced yesterday to four to eight years in state prison for defrauding investors. She pleaded guilty to bilking one investor of $400,000. The original indictment put the figure at $4 million.

LEAD: Frank Viola was invincible for the Mets in his first seven starts this year. His changeup was baffling, making his fastball seem faster, and the results were staggering: seven straight victories and only five earned runs allowed.

LEAD: Last Dec. 8, some male Annapolis midshipmen carried a female colleague into a bathroom and handcuffed her to a urinal. Then, laughing all the while, they photographed her. She was smiling. It was either that or cry, which is about the last thing a woman who wants to be accepted in a man's world (there are 400 women and 4,000 men at the academy) would do in public.
LEAD: * American Express Co., New York, the diversified travel, financial and information services company, appointed Daniel T. Henry senior vice president and comptroller.

LEAD: In addition to marking the unofficial opening of the vacation season along the Jersey Shore, the Memorial Day weekend offers a variety of activities for those who want to watch unusual contests or just browse, buy and bet. KITES IN WILDWOOD.In Wildwood along the southern shore, stunt kites will be soaring and diving for the next three days as teams and individual experts compete in the annual East Coast Stunt Kite Championships.
LEAD: Stocks weakened a bit yesterday amid signs that inflation is too strong for the Federal Reserve to act to bring down interest rates.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Because of a production error, an article in Business Day yesterday about manufacturing innovations at General Motors appeared in some editions with paragraphs misplaced.

LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company said today that it planned to sell several of its European food units to focus on its more profitable businesses. Campbell, whose board approved the divestiture on Thursday, said that the total sales of the businesses to be sold exceeded $200 million a year and that it expected the sale to result in a $55 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings.
LEAD: ''I said you can get used to posh very quickly, and I did.'' -Edward I. Koch, on hid postmayoral apartment

LEAD: Gov. Jim Florio's proposed plan to shift tens of millions of dollars in state education aid from prosperous suburban school systems to poorer urban and rural districts was sharply criticized by surburban school officials today as unfair, divisive and shortsighted.

LEAD: Janis Zealand, a controller at the All Nations Flag Company in Toronto, was thinking about the flag business. But her mind was not on the 150 Soviet flags she had just dispatched to Ottawa for official use during the state visit of Mikhail S. Gorbachev there next week.

LEAD: Frustrated by a pair of last-second defeats in Portland, the Phoenix Suns left nothing to chance tonight. They did not settle for beating the Trail Blazers. They embarrassed them. Leading by as many as 46 points in the third quarter, Phoenix waltzed to a 123-89 victory at Veterans Memorial Coliseum in the third game of the Western Conference final.

LEAD: The National Commission on Child and Youth Deaths was created in 1988 to make the first systematic analysis of mortality among Americans under 18. The group hasn't received money and hasn't met. It's time Congress and the President rectified that.

LEAD: ''On the Sunny Side of the Street,'' sung by Louis Armstrong, was playing on a tape recorder beside the laid-out body of Rocky Graziano in a room in the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel in Manhattan.

LEAD: For nearly 20 years ROBERT REDFORD has used his fame to fight for the environment. Next Saturday, the University of Massachusetts in Boston is to give him an honorary doctor of science degree for his efforts.

LEAD: The opening of Vartan's Bluebird, a new venture by the Soviet impresario Vartan Tonoian at Irving Plaza, was a celebratory affair, drawing a hall full of emigres along with the merely curious and a smattering of jazz cognoscenti hoping to learn about Soviet jazz. Introducing Soviet jazz musicians to New York is a bit like shipping snow to Alaska in January: not only are they redundant, but they have also probably lost some meaning in the trip.
LEAD: Lie Detector for Thornburgh

LEAD: After briefing Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on his talks with the Soviet Foreign Minister, the West German Foreign Minister predicted today that conventional weapons would be a major topic at next week's Washington summit meeting.

LEAD: Former President Ronald Reagan's doctors have discovered several small areas of scar tissue in his small intestine that they believe are a result of his surgery for bowel cancer in 1985, Mr. Reagan's office said today.

LEAD: * American Savings Bank, a unit of Hawaiian Electric Industries Inc., Honolulu, signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Hawaii deposits and branches of First Nationwide Bank, San Francisco. First Nationwide had $242 million in deposits and 18 branches in Hawaii as of March 2.

LEAD: CARLA A. HILLS and LOUIS RUKEYSER have received the Women's Economic Roundtable's award, which was given for only the second time in the organization's 12-year history. The award was established to honor people who make outstanding contributions in financial policy and to education on economic issues.
LEAD: Banks spent more than $129 million last year on Government-required reports aimed at catching money launderers, the American Bankers Association said this week.

LEAD: Even languages you think you speak can leave you at a loss for words. Pocket dictionaries remain the richest source of portable help this side of a native traveling companion, but they do not help with syntax, and it can take what seems like forever to look up a word you want.

LEAD: A New York commodities dealer pleaded guilty in Federal District Court today to destroying 86 acres of wetlands on his hunting retreat and was ordered to pay a $1 million fine and $1 million as restitution.

LEAD: New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation today lifted a two-and-one-half-old year ban on the construction of new sewer mains in much of Westchester County that had halted an estimated $80 million worth of housing and other projects.

LEAD: Isiah Thomas and Mark Aguirre, inseparable friends, grew up within a few blocks of each other in Chicago. Today, they will be back home with the Detroit Pistons, who are looking for a second consecutive National Basketball Association title.
LEAD: Charles E. Coe, a former advertising executive, died of cancer on May 18 at the Virginia (Minn.) Regional Medical Center. He was 83 years old and lived in Virginia.

LEAD: A growing number of large health-care plans are asking patients to grade their doctors: How long are they kept waiting in the office? Can the doctor be reached at night and on weekends? Does the doctor listen as patients describe symptoms? How well is a treatment explained?
LEAD: David Levine, a New York landscape architect, died of pneumonia on Tuesday at Los Gatos, Calif. He was 79 years old and moved to Los Gatos from the Bronx when he retired two years ago.

LEAD: Stocks tumbled yesterday in the wake of a drop in bond prices, a rise in interest rates and increasing nervousness that high-flying technology stocks may be overdue for what Wall Street calls ''a sharp correction.''

LEAD: Charlayne Hunter-Gault, national correspondent for ''The MacNeil- Lehrer News Hour,'' urged members of Cooper Union's class of 1990 yesterday to become ''ambassadors of humanity through your work'' and to combat racism by striving to make diverse voices heard.

LEAD: The Advertising column of Business Day on May 11 misidentified the group that honored Richard V. Benson as Direct Marketer of the Year. It was Direct Marketing Day in New York Inc., a nonprofit organization, not the Direct Marketing Association.

LEAD: A photography exhibition that set off a ferocious debate here about artistic freedom and pornography and led to criminal indictments against a museum will end its seven-week run on Saturday with essential legal questions still unresolved.

LEAD: Kevin Secor, a junior catcher, hit a grand slam in a five-run first inning and Fordham went on to upset Arkansas, 8-5, today in a first-round game of the Midwest Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

LEAD: The customary deliberate downbeat so as not to risk bloated expectations from an imminent Soviet-American summit meeting is the current Washington sound. And there almost surely won't be the grand agreements on arms reductions that President Bush optimistically anticipated last year.

LEAD: Mike Schuler, who was honored as the National Basketball Association's coach of the year after his 1986-87 season with the Portland Trail Blazers, was hired yesterday as the Los Angeles Clippers' head coach. He replaced Don Casey, who had a 41-85 record in a season and a half of coaching before being dismissed last month.

LEAD: Mark Bavaro is alive and almost well. Today, for the first time since he tore a ligament in his left knee last November and underwent surgery in January, he stepped onto a football field and caught passes.

LEAD: An obituary yesterday about Dr. Stanley J. Sarnoff, a cardiologist and inventor, misstated his age and the circumstances of his death. He was 73 and died of heart disease. He was not undergoing surgery.

LEAD: Ed Koch, former resident of Gracie Mansion, doesn't read decorating magazines. He doesn't have to. In furnishing the central living area of his new apartment overlooking Washington Square Park, he simply followed the lead of Julius Caesar.

LEAD: As 132 students graduated yesterday from the City University of New York Law School, they and administrators and faculty members took stock of the seven-year-old institution, which is struggling through its own rites of passage.
LEAD: Thomas Mercer Waller, long a prominent figure in New York thoroughbred racing, died on Thursday at his home in Bedford Hills, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 86 years old.
LEAD: Dr. David I. Arbuse, a psychiatrist and neurosurgeon, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: Specialist Michael Egram helping to place flags yesterday on the graves of veterans at Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia. More than 215,000 flags were placed on the cemetery grounds. (Reuters)

LEAD: Fictional villains of my childhood usually cackled, hissed or purred. One line they were especially fond of cackling, hissing or purring was addressed to heroes about to suffer unbearably slow, agonizing deaths:
LEAD: Dr. Nahum J. Winer, a cardiologist, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: None of the 33 cars in the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday will have a Japanese engine, but future races may be very different. The event, as much a noisy reunion for car-crazy Americans as a test of speed and endurance, is attracting new attention from Japanese auto makers eager to increase their appeal in the United States and

LEAD: A routine fly ball would have tied the game in the sixth inning. A simple ground ball to one of the middle infielders would have done the same in the seventh. The Mets did not get either and so they lost to the Padres, 5-4, last night at Shea Stadium.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the Soviet Union would review its policies on European arms control and security negotiations if a reunited Germany was a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

LEAD: Ever since containers of Tylenol pain relievers were laced with cyanide in 1982, hundreds of patents have been issued for tamper-proof medicine bottles. This week a New Jersey inventor, Edward P. Diehl, patented an idea that may be the most unusual yet.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Prime Minister Li Peng said today that he welcomed President Bush's recommendation to extend most-favored-nation trading status to China for another year, and he suggested that Beijing would try to improve relations with Washington.

LEAD: Government experts on explosives presented new evidence today challenging the Navy's conclusion that the explosion on the battleship Iowa last year was probably an act of suicidal sabotage by a desperate young sailor.

LEAD: The party isn't over in Romania, where former Communists have managed to hang on to power in an election skewed against their underdog rivals. Yet a fairer campaign might well have had the same outcome, if by a smaller margin.

LEAD: ANTHONY HARVEY AND KATHERINE HEPBURN had a skirmish with a traffic officer yesterday in midtown Manhattan. It ended with the film director getting a summons for harassment and the officer gettng X-Rays as Bellevue Hospital.
LEAD: The Mets have asked the commissioner's office to investigate whether improper contacts with Darryl Strawberry's agent might have been made by other National League teams.

LEAD: A former chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange was permanently barred from the futures industry today after an administrative law judge found he had failed to impose adequate supervision on two brokers who were found to have bilked customers out of thousands of dollars.
LEAD: A badly injured hit-and-run victim spent four days and nights in the brushy median of a freeway, trying to signal for help from any of the 128,000 vehicles that pass by every day.

LEAD: Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, urged the United Nations Security Council today to send a new international force to the Israel-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to protect Palestinians and pave the way for eventual Israeli withdrawal.
LEAD: A Federal district judge refused today to dismiss 14 drug-related charges against Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., clearing the way for a trial to begin on June 4.
LEAD: Easy Goer quelled any questions about his fitness by working five furlongs in 59 3/5 yesterday morning at Belmont Park.

LEAD: Responding to criticism for not identifying its biggest donors, the Democratic Party has released a listing of organizations and individuals who have contributed a total of $3.6 million to the party since the beginning of 1989.
LEAD: The Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation said today that it was recalling two types of baby food distributed in 22 states because small stones had been found in them.

LEAD: Presidents Bush and Gorbachev are poised to announce agreement in principle at their summit meeting next week in Washington on a vital treaty to reduce strategic nuclear arms. But that won't be possible if caterwauling right-wing critics have their way.
LEAD: TENNIS

LEAD: The University of Notre Dame gave its prestigious Laetare Medal to Sister Thea Bowman at its commencement on Sunday, but she was not there to receive it. Seven weeks earlier, at the age of 52, she had died.

LEAD: When the Navy managed to ignite five bags of gunpowder Thursday at its Dahlgren, Va., weapons station, it exploded more than the official story that a gunner's mate had sabotaged the battleship Iowa, killing himself and 46 other sailors. It blew open a tight naval mindset that demands blame. It's a mindset so incapable of accepting uncertainty that the

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the effect of the savings and loan bailout on the Federal deficit described effects of accounting differences incorrectly in some copies. The deficit projected by the Bush Administration for the 1991 fiscal year would reach $199 billion if $61 billion in bailout costs were included in the deficit calculations.

LEAD: Responding to a warrant for his arrest, a former New York City official who had placed the body of a woman outside his town house on the Upper East Side last month turned himself in to the police last night, to be charged with a misdemeanor, the police said.

LEAD: At a time when everyone in the Soviet Union from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on down is bracing for the conversion to a market-oriented economy, Ramiz Shabanov sits in jail, serving a 15-year term for ''private entrepreneurial activities.''
LEAD: The embrace lasted at least a minute, from its hesitant start through a near-topple off the podium at the center of a locker room dizzy from euphoria and the thick aroma of champagne.

LEAD: Government plans to raise prices sharply set off panic buying and opposition in the country today, causing the Moscow authorities to order restrictions on food shopping in the city and prompting the Ukrainian Prime Minister to vow resistance.

LEAD: Conductors who take their orchestras on tour have a mandate to choose programs that make an interesting and perhaps slightly novel two hours' listening while also offering a thorough test of the ensemble's mettle. Edo de Waart achieved something close to an ideal balance of those virtues in the program he and the Minnesota Orchestra brought to Carnegie Hall last

LEAD: His fellow N.B.A. players have voted Charles Barkley, the powerful forward for the Philadelphia 76ers, as The Sporting News player of the year. In balloting by 180 players, Barkley received 57 1/2 votes to 44 1/2 for Magic Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers and 44 for Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls.
LEAD: Sales of existing homes fell by 2.1 percent in April, the third drop in four months as mortgage rates remained high, a real estate trade group reported today.

LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange recently approached Richard H. Jenrette, the chairman of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, about the possibility of taking the top position at the Big Board, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

LEAD: A Federal drug agent testified in court today that top officials of the Drug Enforcement Administration authorized plans, including a $50,000 reward, for the capture of a Mexican doctor who the agency believed was involved in the murder of an American drug agent in Mexico.

LEAD: The Governor of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, who oversaw the four-month crackdown against Muslim militants here, resigned today and is likely to be replaced by a top security official. The resignation of the Governor, Jagmohan, came as members of Parliament in New Delhi demanded his removal over the killing of at least 50 people by paramilitary troops on Monday after the assassination of a top religious leader here.

LEAD: Kevin Mitchell hit three home runs in a game for the first time in his career and drove in five runs tonight as the San Francisco Giants outdueled Pittsburgh, 9-8, to knock the Pirates out of first place in the National League East.

LEAD: A subcommittee of the House Banking Comittee voted this week to subpoena David L. Paul, the ousted chairman of Centrust Savings Bank, as part of its investigation into the failure of the huge Miami savings institution. In March, Mr. Paul declined to appear at a panel hearing investigating Centrust's failure.
LEAD: Tony George, who has taken over the presidency of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway at the age of 30, is a young man in a job that very much requires an old frame of mind.

LEAD: Researchers affiliated with the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, the electronics research consortium in Austin, Tex., obtained the first of two patents this week for a method of storing computer data as images on light-sensitive crystal particles.

LEAD: In the mid-1970's, M-G-M Studios hired a salvage crew to haul away and dispose of the waste material stored on one of its back lots, which included the background painting of the Emerald City used in ''The Wizard of Oz.'' Recently, that same matte painting, which the cartage company recognized and held in storage, sold for $44,000 at an auction here.
LEAD: When he hit the ball and saw it skip lazily inside the bag at first, the one thing that came to Jesse Barfield's mind was Minnesota.

LEAD: Dance-drama other than the kind customarily identified with Antony Tudor's ballets was the order of the evening on Thursday when American Ballet Theater presented its first all-Tudor program of the season.

LEAD: The Memorial Day weekend is the unofficial beginning of summer, but before you dive into that pool for the first swim of the season take a moment to see if it's clean. Otherwise, you could suffer from a number of ailments, among them eye and ear infections. The cleaning instructions provided by your pool manufacturer and/or installer should give you a cure for most problems.

LEAD: Boris N. Yeltsin, a rival and fierce critic of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, took the lead early this morning in the contest for the presidency of the Russian republic - a job that would give him an important power base.

LEAD: The results of the recent civil service examination for firefighters were released yesterday, and officials said they were concerned about how few minority candidates are now eligible for appointment.

LEAD: A required presentencing report in the Pete Rose tax-evasion case was made available yesterday in Cincinnati to prosecutors, Rose and Rose's lawyers. The parties have 10 days to object to any factual statements in the report. The report will then go to United States District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel, who will decide the sentence.
LEAD: Mark Strand, a poet, a translator of Spanish literature and a short-story writer, was named today the nation's fourth poet laureate.

LEAD: A confessed killer took the witness stand here this week to tell a Superior Court jury the tale of an impassioned teen-age love affair that went ''beyond obsession'' to murder and, ultimately, betrayal.

LEAD: The House of Candles Theater, the ramshackle storefront site on the Lower East Side of Manhattan where the Irondale Ensemble Project is performing the 1929 Brecht-Weill show, ''Happy End,'' is an appropriately atmospheric space in which to stage the team's followup to ''Three Penny Opera.''
LEAD: Shareholders approved by a wide margin today a sharp increase in pension benefits for the General Motors Corporation's top executives.

LEAD: Dr. Elliott W. Galkin, who had been a music critic for The Baltimore Sun and a director of the Peabody Institute, died at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore on Thursday after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Timonium, Md.

LEAD: The west side of Broadway will be closed today from 76th to 86th Street from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. for the Livable West Side Festival. Madison Avenue will be closed tomorrow from 37th to 56th Street from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. for the Cuban Day Parade. On Monday, Second Avenue from 42d to 53d Street will be closed for the Second Avenue Fair from 8 A.M.

LEAD: The Kremlin's latest proposals to rejuvenate the Soviet economy, unveiled to an incredulous citizenry this week, are widely viewed by Western analysts as too little, too late. The Government's concept of a ''regulated market economy,'' they believe, will exact much of the political pain of more radical approaches without generating much economic gain.

LEAD: To the Editor Your May 6 news article on the political debate over whether Kenya should adopt a multiparty system implies that instituting such a system would assure democracy and respect for human and civil liberties, and that such guarantees would be absent in a one-party state. Democracy is not a function of political parties but rather a product of effective government policy and programs.

LEAD: When a bomb went off here Thursday night in a car carrying two leaders of a radical environmental group, their supporters were quick to blame opponents of a protest aimed at stopping the logging of redwoods in northern California.

LEAD: The Serbian authorities have ordered the expulsion of 17 Albanian refugees accused of provoking ethnic unrest in the troubled province of Kosovo, official news reports say. The Albanians, mostly the offspring of defectors who escaped Albania's harsh Stalinist rulers after 1945, were given 30 days to leave Yugoslavia and find a new country in which to settle, the official reports said today.

LEAD: Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was booed loudly at the City College commencement ceremonies yesterday when it was announced that he could not appear as scheduled to receive an honorary degree because of a time conflict with his military duties.
LEAD: Remembering War A U.S.-Soviet Dialogue. By Helene Keyssar and Vladimir Pozner 254 pages. Illustrated. Oxford University Press. $27.95.

LEAD: When the Syracuse Orangemen (11-0) take the field Saturday at Rutgers Stadium against North Carolina (12-3) in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse championships, they will be trying to stretch a winning streak to 26 games.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Cynthia O.'s 15th birthday present came exactly one week early. It was a fat baby boy, her first. Seventeen months later, on a spring day rinsed in gray, she and the baby, Ronnell, are making their periodic visit to their pediatrician on wheels.

LEAD: The United States Golf Association's ''Rules of Golf'' states that a golfer may discontinue play if he believes there is danger from lightning. It's a sensible rule that all golfers should follow.

LEAD: The share price of Adobe Systems Inc., which supplies software that controls many laser printers, plunged by nearly a third today after the company's announcement of bad news late Thursday. It hardly mattered that the news turned out to be not quite so bad after all.
LEAD: The United States trade deficit shrank to $26.4 billion in the first quarter, the smallest quarterly imbalance in more than six years, the Government said today.

LEAD: The date is a bit earlier than usual, the weather should be a bit cooler, and the field, reduced by the Memorial Day weekend scheduling, will be smaller. But when 6,000 or so women take off from the West Drive at 61st Street in Central Park at 9:30 this morning to begin the 1990 L'eggs Mini Marathon, those at the head of the pack should be about as fast and just as competitive as ever over the 6.2-mile course.
LEAD: More and more customer are rebelling when they make a purchase with a check or credit card and the merchant asks for certain types of personal identification.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh submitted to a polygraph examination during an internal criminal investigation at the Justice Department that led to the reassignment of his two closest aides, senior Bush Administration officials disclosed today.

LEAD: Memorial Day will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Parade: Memorial Day Parade, starting at 10 A.M. Broadway will be closed from 72d to 86th Street from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M. Government offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post Office: Express Mail and special delivery only.

LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds tumbled yesterday in a shortened pre-Memorial Day weekend session. The Treasury securities market, which normally does not have fixed trading hours, closed at 2 P.M., Eastern daylight time.

LEAD: The State Board of Regents today faulted two doctors with gross negligence in their care of Libby Zion, who was 18 years old when she died at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in 1984.

LEAD: Edgar Conradson, the former manager of the Swedish Tourist Board in Manhattan, died on Thursday at Bellevue Hospital Center after a fall in March that left him paralyzed. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The International Opera Festival announced yesterday that the American tour of its production of ''Aida'' had been canceled. The tour, with the soprano Grace Bumbry heading a cast of 1,200 in an elaborate production featuring numerous animals and huge props, was to have begun next Friday at Giants Stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands and to have moved on to Los Angeles and San
LEAD: Companies

LEAD: Vic Tayback, a film, television and theater actor best known for playing Mel the diner owner in the television series ''Alice,'' died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Glendale, Calif. He was 60 years old.

LEAD: The Meredith Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell Sail magazine to Cahners Publishing, which already produces Power & Motoryacht, Motor Boat and Motoryacht International magazines. The price was not disclosed.

LEAD: New York City's effort to get its trash under control will take a big step forward on Tuesday when recycling of metal and glass becomes mandatory for the first time in a Manhattan neighborhood - the Upper West Side.

LEAD: In a cinder-block warehouse near the Long Island village of Stony Brook, bicycle helmets come to die. The headgear is smashed, split, snapped and yanked, all to determine whether it can be sold bearing a green label that means added safety.
LEAD: Immunomedics Inc., a small biotechnology concern in Warren, N.J., has obtained a patent on a method of pinpointing infections and inflammations.

LEAD: The chief bodyguard of Winnie Mandela, wife of the South African nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, was found guilty today of murdering a 14-year-old youth who had been abducted with three men and held in her home in late 1988.

LEAD: Maureen McGovern will sing at a benefit for the York Theater Company at 8 P.M. on June 6 at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street. The benefit marks the 21st anniversary of the company, which is presenting Chekhov's ''Cherry Orchard'' until June 3. Benefit tickets are $25 to $500.

LEAD: Last Saturday's show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Coltrane Legacy, was a good idea on several fronts. For one thing, John Coltrane's music is rarely played anymore. The contributions of the saxophonist, who died in 1967, are taken for granted now, and the concert allowed the audience to examine exactly how well arranged his later works were and how carefully he constructed his pieces to evoke certain moods that on records sound deceptively natural and improvised.
LEAD: When Colombians vote for president on Sunday, their ballots will constitute a referendum on the nation's nine-month war with cocaine traffickers.

LEAD: Ethel Stafford Masland, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Stafford Masland of Tucson Ariz., and West Chop, Mass.,was marries yesterday to Peter Wolcott, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Wolcott of San Rafael, Calif. The Rev. Thomas E. Copps performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Vineyard Christian Community Church in Tucson.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Protesting students agreed in court yesterday to end their occupation of the administrative headquarters of the City University of New York in return for negotiations on their demands for amnesty and a stronger voice in CUNY's minority hiring and tuition policies.

LEAD: The International Monetary Fund approved the resumption of aid to Argentina yesterday and, at the same time, Argentina and its commercial bankers said they will start debt negotiations on June 7.
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins was loudly cheered today as he arrived to address the Coalition of Black Trade Unionists meeting here.
LEAD: President Bush tonight signed a spending bill that includes $720 million in aid for Panama and Nicaragua after he arrived here for a four-day holiday.
LEAD: The President of Liberia, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, said today that he would consider holding early elections if it would bring a peaceful settlement to the West African nation's insurgency.

LEAD: For retirees, making the right investment decisions can be crucial because the income from investments must often replace earned income for living expenses. Consequently, most retirees feel they cannot afford to risk any loss of capital.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Calling the Ku Klux Klan ''a persecuted group,'' a Georgia state court judge ruled today that a state ban on the wearing of masks illegally restricted the group's free speech.

LEAD: Candice C. Baker, a doughter of Mrs. Nicholas M. Zumas of Bethlehem Pa., and Charles S. Baker of Augusta, Me., was married yesterday to Dr. Michael E. Leit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barton H. Leit of Boca Raton Fla. The Rev. Dr. Alan C. Mermann officiated at Yale University.
LEAD: The residents call it ''Ground Zero.''

LEAD: Augie Donatelli, a National League umpire for 24 years and the founder of the Major League Umpires Association in 1964, died Thursday. He was 76 years old. Mr. Donatelli died in his sleep at home, his wife, Mary, said.

LEAD: New York City and Congressional officials say the crucial second phase of the 1990 census, the door-to-door canvass of households, is failing as badly as the mail responses.

LEAD: The following is an excerpt from a report commissioned by the General Accounting Office, based largely on testing by the Sandia National Laboratory, about the Navy's investigation of the explosion aboard the battleship Iowa. The report was submitted today to the Senate Armed Services Committee.

LEAD: A panel of scientists warned today that unless emissions of carbon dioxide and other harmful gases were immediately cut by more than 60 percent, global temperatures would rise sharply over the next century, with unforeseeable consequences for humanity.

LEAD: The choosing of a Republican state ticket verged on becoming chaotic yesterday as the party's traditional ally, the Conservative Party, threatened to oppose the Republicans' likely choice for governor.

LEAD: An advisory group of representatives from major arts organizations unanimously declared its support today for extending the life of the National Endowment for the Arts for another five years without legislative restrictions on the kind of art the endowment supports.
LEAD: Western analysts view the new Soviet economic plan as too little, too late. Some see it as an attempt to legitimize a rapid drive to free markets. News analysis, page 4.

LEAD: Photo: A tornado struck central Kansas Thursday night, destroying farm buildings and seriously injuring two people. Eighty-eight cars of a Southern Pacific train were knocked from the tracks near Claflin. (Associated Press)

LEAD: Roller-skating demonstrations and putting contests are among the weekend's outdoor activities at Wollman Skating Rink in Central Park. Skaters can whizz around the rink and golfers can play a round on a miniature course that features such New York landmarks as the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the Statue of Liberty and the Bronx Zoo.
LEAD: Wally Backman had three hits and drove in three runs and Doug Drabek won his sixth consecutive decision, leading the Pittsburgh Pirates past the San Francisco Giants by 10-4 today.

LEAD: The fine article ''In Morris County, a Changing Outlook on Development'' (April 15) summarized the impact of growth and increased employment opportunities on one central New Jersey county. Somerset County was noted as having enjoyed the same kind of economic growth and prosperity in recent years.
LEAD: The stock market has been hitting new highs in recent weeks, but Wall Street can't get its mind off something else that has gone through the roof: the Federal budget deficit.

LEAD: In a letter to the New Jersey editor on April 22, John A. Karanik laid most of the blame for high auto insurance premiums in New Jersey on automobile design, the high incidence of auto theft and the New Jersey driver. Despite the fact that costs from these sources would primarily fall under comprehensive and collision portions of auto policies (which many motorists have dropped because of the high cost of the legally required liability portion), most insurance industry apologists wheel out these tired arguments.

LEAD: A YOUNG BOY MOLTS. Tender skin falls off, or gets scraped off, and is replaced by a tougher, more permanent crust. The transition happens in moments, in events. All of a sudden, something is gone and something else is in its place. I made a change like that standing in the back of a pickup truck when I was 15.

LEAD: Watching Rose Bowl Parade Q. How do you get tickets to view the Tournament of Roses Parade in Pasadena, Calif? Are there tour companies that will obtain seats on the route? - Florence Wilson, Brockton, Mass. A. You can watch the New Year's Day parade for no charge by sitting or standing along much of the parade route.

LEAD: David Opont, the 12-year-old Brooklyn boy recovering from a March 7 assault in which he was set on fire, was visited yesterday by the president of his native country, Ertha Pascal-Trouillot of Haiti.

LEAD: In an unusual example of regional cooperation, the governors of New York and three New England states have agreed to increase land purchases and adopt tax incentives to preserve their sprawling northern forests and to support forest-related industry.

LEAD: AN EXAMPLE OF SUSIE RAY'S work is hanging in the British Museum, though Ray doesn't much care for the exhibition's title. It's called ''Fake?''; her painting is a duplicate of Manet's ''Vase of Peonies.'' Ray, 31 years old, is a copy artist. In her London gallery - called Susie Ray Originals - she replicates masterworks for collectors not keen on prints.

LEAD: I grew up in a family that was nothing like the Addams family except in one respect. When I was small, I would go with my favorite aunt and uncle and a cousin just my age to drive-in horror movies every week. Better not to ask whether this was healthy for children under 10. We loved being scared. But ''The Premature Burial,'' Roger Corman's cheap, trashy version of Poe, was more frightening than anyone had expected.
LEAD: Members of the faculty, staff and student body at Mount Vernon College have joined forces to try to oust the school's president who has served for the last decade.

LEAD: THE migration back to Westchester's waters is in full swing. Like flocks of birds, flotillas of recreational mariners return each spring to the Hudson River and Long Island Sound. Sailboats and powerboats come down from their cradles and out of winter storage.

LEAD: Q. My glass shower doors have accumulated a layer of soap scum that has built up on the glass for a considerable length of time. LEAD: So much is still not known about Special Agent Dale Cooper. It is not even a sure thing that is he still alive, although the betting is that the dark splotches that those bullets pasted all over the pleats of his white shirt were only Kevlar, the stuff that bulletproof vests are made of. After all, even though he was just expecting room service when he opened the door to the barrel of a gun, Agent Cooper had not changed out of the F.B.I.

LEAD: Even in a region known for its overnight millionaires, Finis F. Conner turns heads. With homes in Pebble Beach and Palm Springs, a collection of classic cars, private planes, yacht, speedboat and a near-professional golf game, Mr. Conner has become the epitome, or perhaps the caricature, of the Silicon Valley executive made good.

LEAD: Although much of her preservation work has been done building by building, Laurie Beckelman hopes to bring a wider perspective - that of whole neighborhoods - to her new job as chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

LEAD: For several years, many of the companies that consider themselves in the vanguard of financial reporting, like Boeing and Chrysler, have been reserving a little-noticed section in their annual reports for something called the ''management report.'' In it, members of top management acknowledge their responsibility for presentation of the numbers in the financial statements, affirm their commitment to maintaining adequate internal controls and sometimes even sign their names for emphasis.

LEAD: ONE of the many fables written and illustrated by Leo Lionni tells of a mouse named Frederick who, like Jiminy Cricket, does not prepare for winter. Where other mice are collecting food, Frederick is off by himself, gathering, he says, ''sunshine,'' ''colors'' and ''words.'' Come winter, the odd-mouse-out nests with his brethren, sharing their supplies and, when they look to him for a contribution, he has only his food for the soul to offer.

LEAD: It was just like Ted Tinling to plan his own memorial service. He dictated to John Parsons, a British sportswriter, the exact instructions, whom he wanted notified and who would speak. He told John, ''I just want you to know I won't go out with a whimper.''

LEAD: The polar bears were cavorting in their glass-encased grotto inthe Central Park Zoo Wednesday night, peering out quizzically at the mariachi players. LEAD: A team of scientists at Columbia University led by physics professor Norman H. Christ has built one of the fastest computers in the world. It can perform 6.5 billion operations per second, three times as many as the largest supercomputer built by Cray Research Inc.

LEAD: OFF and running since last November, Saratoga Restaurant and Bar is a recent addition to the restaurant scene in Westport. The look of the dining room and its separate bar is so ordinary that one is hardly prepared for the interesting menu.

LEAD: Voters in India who have been turning state-level Congress Party governments out of office in a series of elections now find that they are getting more than just new faces. In several of India's largest states, recently elected governments are declaring war on the English language, reversing the trend toward the spread of English as a common link for a multilingual country.

LEAD: Amy J. Schlott, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. D. William Schlott of Baltimore, and Dr. Stephen W. Downing, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin G. Downing of Buffalo, plan to be married in June. Both are 29 years old. The prospective bride, a Princeton University graduate, received an M.A. in international studies and an M.B.A.

LEAD: Are the Giants as good as they think they can be? Last year's division champions ended a five-day minicamp today, and like every other team at this time of year they were unbeaten, upbeat and anxious to get on to training camp eight weeks from now and real games 15 weeks hence.

LEAD: As an African-American who swam competitively during the 1960's, I was happy to read that there is again an inner-city swimming program that is producing swimmers of national caliber, although I was sad to learn that the swimmers must use inferior facilities.

LEAD: Al Unser Jr. was asked this week if his 7-year-old son, also named Al, would follow his father and grandfather into auto racing. Unser said he had planned to put the boy into a kart in a few months, but that he had recently hurt his arm in a minibike crash.

LEAD: American tourists, who flocked to the Soviet Union in record numbers in 1988 and 1989, are thinking twice this year, travel companies and agents specializing in Soviet tours say.

LEAD: Tennis Spain Beats United States: Conchita Martinez breezed past Lori McNeil, 6-1, 6-1, in the deciding singles match yesterday to give Spain a 3-2 victory over the United States in the Nations Cup, a tournament being played for the first time. The event was held in Marbella, Spain. Jennifer Capriati had given the United States a 2-2 tie when she overpowered Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, 6-3, 6-4, in the day's opening match.(AP)

LEAD: What President Mikhail S. Gorbachev seems to need most of all from the Washington summit meeting that begins on Wednesday is not arms control or economic aid, not agreement on Germany or sympathy on Lithuania, but proof that he still matters.

LEAD: Illegal Alterations Question: There are two apartments on the floor above me and it appears they are being converted to four units. Workmen are removing all the old plaster walls, the ceilings and the floor planks. Some of the work has resulted in large holes in my living room wall and damaged electrical and telephone wiring.

LEAD: The Baltimore Orioles will switch their spring training headquarters from Miami to a site on the Gulf Coast of Florida, ending 31 years at Bobby Maduro Miami Stadium, the team announced Friday.

LEAD: With the economic and monetary unification of the two Germanys now planned for early July, the European Community is struggling to find ways of absorbing East Germany without disrupting the 12-nation Common Market.

LEAD: Can data obtained by unethical means be permitted in science? The issue is raised pointedly by Nazi experiments in concentration camps. Some of these exercises, like Josef Mengele's experiments on twins, were brutish and demented. Others were brutish but aimed at scientific goals. A study at Dachau on methods for reviving people numbed by icy water has been cited often in the scientific literature.

LEAD: The Soviet Union will never agree to allow the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to play the leading role in building a new European security order, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev says in an interview to be published by Time magazine on Sunday.

Broadway will be closed from 72d to 86th Street from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M. Government offices: Federal, state and municipal closed. Post Office: Express Mail and special delivery only.

LEAD: Heather S. Campbell and Mark T. Leonard, 1987 graduates of Duke University, are planning a June wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Milton F. Campbell of Greenwich, Conn., have announced.

LEAD: When student protests commemorating a massacre of demonstrators here 10 years ago slowly tailed off and then stopped, there was almost a palpable sigh of relief from Koreans. After a decade of persistent violence in the streets, most Koreans seem eager to put the disruptions behind them and breathe in some of the country's air of economic success rather than tear gas.

LEAD: Chief of Police James J. Dolan Jr., called Fingers by his friends, has been the subject of several grand juries during his 11 years on the force. One investigated his role in a barroom brawl. Another focused on his shooting of a fleeing crime suspect.

LEAD: When the Stanley Cup playoffs began almost two months ago, the president of the National Hockey League, John Ziegler, stood watching in disgust as the Islanders and the Rangers brawled at the final buzzer of the opening game of the opening round in Madison Square Garden.
LEAD: After a hunger strike by four students, administrators at the University of California at Davis have agreed to take steps to improve the racial climate.

LEAD: Despite its phenomenal penetration into society, the personal computer is only now beginning to mature. Early personal computers required the user to learn strings of esoteric commands that differed from system to system, which limited their appeal and made them difficult to use. While that is still largely the case, common standards are beginning to emerge.

LEAD: Why do teachers and parents find it so hard to stress the importance of reading to our young? Thank you, Lori Negridge Allen, for putting in writing what many people are complaining about in faculty rooms and around dinner tables (''Why Students Don't Read,'' Opinion page, May 6). Whom do we really blame?

LEAD: To the Editor: China's airline, Air China (C.A.A.C.), has never been particularly user friendly, but judging by my experience the carrier has given a whole new meaning to the concept of nonrefundable ticket. We are accustomed to thinking that this means that if the passenger's plans change, the fare paid is lost.

LEAD: When he was 14 years old, Ronnie Jones walked in off the street and found a refuge at St. Peter's-in-the-Bronx. He was given a home and encouraged to study and to stay away from the drugs that plagued his family and neighborhood.

LEAD: If you have been following food trends, you know that salsas and relishes and chutneys have taken over from beurre blanc as accompaniments to fish, poultry and meat. It's all part of a continuing interest in health and in intensely flavored foods. And it provides proof that you don't have to have butter and cream to make something taste wonderful.
LEAD: I for one, do not think the speeds are too fast at the Indy 500.
LEAD: An article in the special Careers section last Sunday about jobs in the environmental safety industry misidentified a New York recruiter who specializes in the area. He is William Alford.

LEAD: BEFORE Hilda Green Demsky's mural - ''From Earth to Space'' - was installed last week, there was little reason to look up in the entry hall of the Thomas H. Slater Center, a United Way-affiliated agency here. There was nothing on the walls except for an incongruous piece of pseudo-Grecian wallpaper in one small area.

LEAD: A CHIC lady, wearing long, dangling earrings and a short skirt, is seated so primly in the Kornbluth Gallery that it's hard to imagine sitting on her lap. But don't hesitate; she is a garden chair. What's more, it is comfortable.

LEAD: Moscovites are used to complaining about empty stores, but today their worst exaggerations became a reality as nervous weekend shoppers from within and without the city raided stores, leaving shelves bare.

LEAD: Stella Madrid won the opening leg of the New York filly triple crown yesterday at Belmont Park in a style suggesting that the next two legs will be much tougher.
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has ruled that a publisher is not required to delete material from a coming biography of L. Ron Hubbard, founder of the Church of Scientology.

LEAD: The fight in Tunis was called off for what were described as ''technical reasons.'' That is, the promoter refused to pay the boxers. Then, for what were described as ''prestige'' reasons, the promoter was arrested.

LEAD: An article last Sunday about apartments in single-family houses misstated the position of the housing subcommittee of the Darien Representative Town Meeting in the town's discussions on legalizing accessory apartments. The subcommittee has not yet made a recommendation.

LEAD: Joey Harris, one of the title characters in the NBC comedy series ''My Two Dads,'' revealed himself during the past television season to be a dedicated environmentalist. In one episode, Joey, played by Greg Evigan, threw away all the aerosol sprays in the house. He lectured his daughter about using Styrofoam containers.

LEAD: Every city likes to show off after a major remodeling, and Seattle is no exception, despite lingering traits of Scandinavian bashfulness. For the last four years Seattle has been under almost constant construction, but now virtually everything - the new skyscrapers, the pocket-park in the center of town, the underground bus tunnel - is finished, or in the final stages.

LEAD: The people of Myanmar, formerly Burma, vote on Sunday in the first multiparty election in almost 30 years, but Western diplomats based there and human-rights organizations say that the voting will not be free or fair and that the military will continue to rule.

LEAD: CUISINE confusion causes many Long Islanders to think of hot, spicy Latin American food as being Spanish. Mention Spain and they reply tortillas, tacos and tamales instead of paellas, mariscadas or chorizos.

LEAD: Next year, Gerard Mortier takes over as artistic director of the Salzburg Festival. Mr. Mortier is committed to musical theater. He has a close professional association with the innovative stage director Luc Bondy and the innovative designer Erich Wonder. The musical backbone of the Salzburg Festival is the Vienna State Opera.

LEAD: Record collectors regularly find themselves strapped to a Procrustean bed, agonizingly tugged in several directions at once. If one wants the most dramaticaly compelling account of Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin'' on CD, for instance, the decision appears simple enough: Acquire the new Legato Classics issue (LCD 163-2; two CD's), whose Tatyana is the gripping actress Galina Vishnevskaya in her vocal prime.
