LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday about a party honoring Thomas N. Armstrong, the former director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, misidentified two people playing with plastic clappers. They were Ryder Ziebath and Alfred (Chappy) Morris.

LEAD: UNPOPULAR GUESTS WHO VISIT THE Connecticut summer house of my old college roommate are shown to the so-called Perry Como suite - a room barely bigger than a shoe box with a signed picture of the singer and a single, rickety old bed that breaks with one toss of a blanket. How embarrassing for a first-time guest to confess at the breakfast table the next morning that half the lumpy mattress accidentally fell through the rustic wood frame.
LEAD: Cambodia's four warring factions have signed a cease-fire that is to take effect next month, but one guerrilla official today called the agreement a mere ''play on words.''

LEAD: In one of the few decisions about the new national Indian museum that seemed to be easy, the Smithsonian Institution has named a director. W. Richard West Jr. of Albuquerque, N.M., is a lawyer, not a museum professional. But Mr. West, 47 years old, a member of the Cheyenne-Arapaho tribe, has represented Indian tribes and organizations since graduating from Stanford Law School.
LEAD: It is human nature to push for new limits, to go to the very edge. There is no end in sight as, once again this month, records were set during qualifications.

LEAD: THE Associated Artists of New Jersey is celebrating its 50th anniversary with a show at the Hunterdon Art Center. Established 40 years ago, the gallery is no chicken either, and its premises, a former mill, complete with a weir that is currently swarming with trout, are an antique.

LEAD: On a Friday night a few weeks ago at the Fridge, a run-down theater-turned-dance hall in the Brixton section of London, Soul II Soul started to add up. Soul II Soul's leader, Jazzie B., was in the disk-jockey booth; the Fridge is his club, a place to put musical hybrids to the test of dance-floor popularity.

In one of the paintings we seem to be hang-gliding toward an immense and limitless space.

LEAD: Israelis are casting a wary eye on the summit meeting of Arab leaders that begins Monday in Baghdad, conscious of a resurgent mood of belligerence that Israel has not had to face in more than a decade.

LEAD: I'm not sure how many gypsy moth caterpillars are in the yard. The term a million billion zillion -coined by a younger member of this family - comes to mind. They sashay onto your clothes, flail about on your shoulders, fall into your soda and do a mad fandango. Some people say they can hear them chewing, but entomologists say that is not true.

As he fell, his head hit a metal object and he was bleeding profusely.

LEAD: Bittersweet memories of immigrant family life in a lower Manhattan tenement come alive in the painting ''Family Supper,'' which a newly formed civic group is trying to acquire for the Ellis Island Immigration Museum, due to open in the fall.

LEAD: Taxi service is one of New York City's more persistent shames: cabs are often filthy and uncomfortable; drivers often don't know English, don't know the city, behave rudely and drive recklessly.

LEAD: It was a milestone of sorts for the Japanese. The dollar fell below 150 to the yen on Friday, a key psychological break for the Japanese currency. Although still weak, the yen has risen 5.9 percent against the dollar in three weeks and is at its strongest point since the beginning of March. If the dollar remains below 150, the yen could gain more momentum as the Japanese switch their hedges, which would mean buying more yen.

LEAD: COMPANIES Putting Ivan Boesky on Trial The Mulheren trial is turning into the Boesky trial. Ivan F. Boesky was forced to testify last week that he kept millions in profits from insider trading, took a tax deduction for half of his $100 million settlement and illegally paid other prisoners to do his laundry.
LEAD: WHEN builders start explaining how we're all going to profit from their business ventures, taxpayers had better hold on to their wallets.
LEAD: Neither Hercule Poirot, Miss Marple nor any of the other characters who are associated with Dame Agatha Christie make an appearance in ''Murder on the Nile.''

LEAD: A Boston organization has said three Hartford-area insurance companies will be the next targets of its campaign to convince large institutional investors to rid their portfolios of tobacco company stocks.

LEAD: Gold investment reached record highs in Latin America, Asia and the Middle East last year, according to the annual report issued by Gold Fields Mineral Services Ltd. But there was net selling of gold in North America and Europe. After the supression of the democracy movement in China, gold purchases soared in Hong Kong and rose 57.9 percent for the year.

LEAD: There is a strong multiracial team - the Westside Y Marlins - in our own backyard. The team is young, most of the swimmers are under 13, but its record is impressive. It dominated the New York State Y.M.C.A. championships this year and two of the swimmers have clocked nationally ranked times in their age group.

LEAD: JUDGING by a surge of books on traveling with children, the baby boom generation - statistics show it to be the oldest and best-educated group of parents in the country's history - is finally taking its show on the road.

LEAD: The restless Seymour Solomon, who sold his Vanguard Recording Society catalogue to the Welk Record Group in California in 1986, has bought back most of the classical part of the catalogue (for an undisclosed amount) and plans to issue digitally remastered compact disks, digital audio tapes and cassettes of the material.

LEAD: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products.

LEAD: ILIAS. By Jim Sakkas. (Salem House/Harper & Row, $17.95.) The long voyage from Greece to Australia begins hopefully enough for Ilias Verginis, the title character of this first novel by a writer born in Greece who also left his native island to find a new life on the other side of the world. It is 1928, and Ilias arrives in Melbourne with a simple five-year plan: he will work hard, save money and return home to buy his own fishing boat.

LEAD: Kirk Dressendorfer was in the trainer's room again. Last weekend, as he approached the most significant moments of his third and presumably final season as a pitcher for the University of Texas, Dressendorfer had become a regular occupant of the trainer's room and doctor's offices.

LEAD: From the shores of the Mediterranean to the arid hills of the Mont-Ventoux, the town squares, medieval castles, antique arenas and Roman cloisters of Provence come alive under the summer sun. The region plays host to many of France's major summer music festivals. Music and Dance

LEAD: Through it all, Earl Hartwig never wavered in his belief that his son, Clayton, had been wrongly accused of intentionally causing the explosion that killed him and 46 other sailors aboard the battleship Iowa last spring.

LEAD: After seeing Eduardo Ivan Lopez's ''Spanish Eyes'' at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, an audience could conclude that love and loyalty, if they are virtues at all, are very dangerous ones. The play has some laughs and a few poignant moments, but it is emotionally exhausting and more than a little bewildering.

LEAD: A grand jury decided Friday that no criminal charges should be filed against two police officers who shot and killed a 20-year-old man on March 1 in Brooklyn.

LEAD: Enforcement officials of the National Marine Fisheries Service are waiting to see if the longstanding high-seas harvest of salmon of United States origin in the North Pacific by drift-net vessels from other nations has been brought under control.

LEAD: The Presidential commission on terrorism in the air has turned in a report that is clear, thoughtful, brave and of commanding importance. Therefore the likelihood is that the Administration will try to shove it into oblivion as fast as possible.

LEAD: Happiness is Darci Kistler at the New York City Ballet, where the pleasure of her performances invariably brings a smile to the lips of the spectators in the house.

LEAD: AUG. 15, Le quinze-aout, in France is the Feast of the Assumption, and virtually the entire country is closed that day. Celebrations are various and splendid; each region has its own version with its own local flavor. St.-Remy-de-Provence, in the south, produces a robust quinze-aout, a rich mixture of the religious and secular, hearty, salubrious and entirely unique.

LEAD: As the metropolitan area's beach season gets under way this rainy Memorial Day weekend, government officials and environmental groups say there is no way to predict whether beaches will remain clean this summer.

LEAD: Those who ply their trades at newspapers know only too well what a stylebook is. It's a comprehensive and usually exhausting compilation of all the rules of spelling, punctuation and usage that a publication tries to follow. It tells you whether to write ''ten'' as a word or as a number. It dictates whether ''catalog'' ends with a ''g'' or ''gue.
LEAD: The unseasonably warm weather that hit the Northeast early this spring has cost a Juniata College biology professor some bartering power this year.

LEAD: Q. My glass shower doors have accumulated a layer of soap scum that has built up on the glass for a considerable length of time. The glass has a textured, uneven surface, so it is difficult to scrape off this scum. I have tried various household cleansers, but none worked. Anything you can suggest?

LEAD: The Mutual Funds column on May 6 about proposed changes in rules governing mutual fund fees misstated the tax ramifications of a sale of mutual fund shares. Investors defer a tax loss if they sell and then buy back the identical shares in a fund within 60 days of the sale. They do not forfeit the tax loss.

LEAD: If Broadway shows were judged solely by their original cast albums, the history of the American musical would be quite a different story than it is. Since cast albums don't provide scenery, costumes, dancing and spoken text (except sometimes in a printed libretto), the music becomes the whole show.

LEAD: The polls open on Sunday in Poland's first fully free elections since the Communists gave up power a year ago, with voters poised to throw out the Communist officials who have dominated local government here since the end of World War II.

LEAD: Did you hear the story about the man who bought a $100,000 boat on Friday, set sail on Saturday without the foggiest idea of how to operate the thing, and ended up adrift on Long Island Sound out of gas?
LEAD: The article ''Proposal for Jobs and Homes Fought'' (April 15) was a clear case of poorly researched, slanted journalism.

LEAD: A woman who won custody of seven frozen embryos last September in a widely publicized court ruling now says she plans to donate them to a fertility clinic so that they can be used by a childless couple.

LEAD: One night last August the letters C, M, B and P popped into Freddy (Action) Jackson's head. Business at his car dealership has never been the same since.

LEAD: Responding to State Health Commissioner Frederick G. Adams's expression of dismay that there is ''no public panic'' about the spread of the fatal AIDS virus (April 22), he must be asked, why should the public panic?
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Homosexuality should not bar people from serving as rabbis in Reform Judaism, a committee appointed by the Reform rabbinical association has recommended.

LEAD: It seems somehow appropriate that a good portion of the college-age population in Manhattan makes up a sort of walking fashion experimentation lab, where all sorts of combinations and permutations of dress can be studied. There is a boldness among this group, a sense of adventure that makes this endeavor a lot more fun than organic chemistry ever was.

LEAD: Congressional investigators have found that more than half of the new drugs approved for marketing in this country have some severe or fatal side effects not found in testing, or not reported until years after the medications have been widely used.

LEAD: In a development likely to heighten tensions at next Monday's Arab summit meeting in Baghdad, the United States today blocked an attempt by the United Nations Security Council to send a mission to investigate the treatment of Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

LEAD: ON a stroll through the corridors of any one of Long Island's community hospitals 30 years ago, a visitor might have seen heart attack victims in their third week of recuperation, a new mother taking her first halting steps days after her baby's birth and a few affluent members of the community on a kind of rest and rehabilitation program, compliments of good insurance coverage.

LEAD: On screen, it's not a novelty: Beau and Jeff Bridges play brothers in ''The Fabulous Baker Boys,'' Henry and Jane Fonda are father and daughter in ''On Golden Pond.'' But the casting of relatives is rare in the American theater, particularly since the number of stage families - the Cronyns excepted - is small to nonexistent.

LEAD: Less than a year after it started operation, Detroit's giant trash incinerator, the largest in the nation, was abruptly shut down last month by state regulators. Environmental officials said the behemoth plant, which converts waste into energy, was emitting much higher levels of mercury than are permissible under state law.

LEAD: Even if you are, as Sue Wartur put it, ''something of a sailor,'' how long do you keep the sail from your first little sailboat? Years, of course, a lot of years. And then one day you think to yourself, ''It's ridiculous; what am I keeping this for?'' and you get rid of it. In fact, you're pretty pleased with yourself about finally taking some decisive action.

LEAD: It is my layman's opinion that designers and mechanics will always find more speed with advancing technology. If you curtail the engines, then the body will evolve for more speed. They cut the down force this year and still there's more speed.

LEAD: Thursday will be the last gathering of the Last Thursday of the Month Club at the Zig Zag Bar and Grill in Manhattan. For the past year or so young magazine editors, writers, art directors and photographers have been flocking to these industry parties where the conversation, like the configuration of the bar at the Zig Zag, has a way of veering off at crazy angles.

LEAD: Steffi Graf isn't used to losing, but every young tennis player's life is subject to disruption by a an even younger tennis player. So it happened last weekend, at the German Open final in Berlin, that 20-year-old Graf lost to 16-year-old Monica Seles of Yugoslavia. The 6-3, 6-4 victory gave Seles her fifth tournament title in a row.

LEAD: Elizabeth Kipper, the winner of the New York Youth Symphony's 1990 Concerto Competition, is to play the Barber Violin Concerto with the orchestra at 3 P.M. today at Carnegie Hall. LEAD: For This Week: If iris did not bloom well, the rhizomes may need dividing; wait until late June or early July to dig up, separate and replant the rhizomes. Plant beans, especially limas, and set out seedlings of tomato, pepper and eggplant; be sure the soil is enriched with organic material so it holds moisture; water then mulch the plants to hold moisture in and keep weeds out.

LEAD: A Newark leather company owned by a Port Authority commissioner faces possible fines after receiving two citations for dumping scraps of animal skins into sewers, officials said.

LEAD: I was delighted to read Phillip Hoose's article ''A New Pool of Talent'' (April 29), about Jim Ellis and his Philadelphia Department of Recreation team. I wish there had been a Jim Ellis in my Harlem community when I was a growing up in the 1950's. In those days, the boys were given swimming lessons at the local Y after school and the girls were left home.

LEAD: Many American officials and strategic analysts seem to be making the preservation of NATO the principal objective of American policy in Europe. This goal makes sense in the short run. NATO is still the only organization that gives the U.S. a preponderant role in Europe, and it remains critical to preserving stability and balance there.

LEAD: THE FALSE YEARS. By Josefina Vicens. Translated by Peter G. Earle. (Latin American Literary Review Press, 2300 Palmer Street, Pittsburgh, Pa. 15218; Paper, $11.50.) ''We've all come to see me,'' begins this strange, dense story of life entangled with death, first published in Spanish in 1982. It is the fourth anniversary of the day that a small-time rural wheeler-dealer named Poncho Fernandez accidentally blew his brains out, and the family has come to tend the grave.

LEAD: IN THE EARLY MORNING DARK, WHEN THE AIR IS A fine mist, I stand on a deserted walkway at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, listening for the footfalls of comrades long gone and waiting for the strangers who daily come to visit.

LEAD: FOR many Americans there is only one way to serve an artichoke: boiled, with a Hollandaise or vinaigrette sauce. The notion of cutting off the leaves beforehand and using only the heart or bottom seems wasteful. But now that large artichokes cost less than $1 each and the medium-sized ones are selling for 20 cents apiece in some stores, it is possible to use them in a variety of ways without feeling guilty.

LEAD: NOT that long ago, concert music virtually went into hibernation between the end of the spring season in May and the start of summer festivals a month or so later.
LEAD: Last year the French Open lurched to an improbable conclusion when two 17-year-old dark-horse contestants made history by stubbornly outlasting their elders on the red clay.
LEAD: YOUNGSTERS who captured their world in pictures and words are the winners of a student photography competition conducted by the Bushnell Children's Theater in Hartford.

LEAD: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products.

LEAD: Howard D. Hosbach, a former president of the Standard & Poor's Corporation and former executive vice president of operations for McGraw-Hill, died of cancer on Friday at his home in Allendale, N.J. He was 59 years old.

LEAD: Caroline Harriet Stewart and Douglas Percy Codrington Nation, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas C. Nation of Crondall, Hampshire, England, plan to marry next month, the prospective bride's mother, Nancie Palmer of New York, has announced.

McCann of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Christopher Mould officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Alexandria.
LEAD: ''If the Parliament cannot decide, the decision must be made by the people.'' - Boris N. Yeltsin, on the presidency of Russia. [1:6.]
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: New Jersey's mass transit system, among the nation's oldest and largest, has reached a point of no return. When fares went up 12.5 percent last July, ridership was expected to drop. But no one figured that so many commuters would get off buses and into their own cars that fare revenues would fall below the year before.
LEAD: Ending a debate that has lasted almost two years, a Stanford University committee has voted to amend the student conduct code to prohibit ''discriminatory harassment.''

LEAD: ADAM PENNINGTON SAYS HE SLEEPSJU in nothing but his boxer shorts. Pajamas? ''They're a little old-fashioned,'' demurs Pennington, an executive with a sports-marketing firm in New York City. ''My father was the only person I knew who ever wore them religiously.''

LEAD: Bogota Leader Speaks Out On the eve of presidential elections in Colombia, President Virgilio Barco Vargas said the cocaine traffickers were determined to bring down the nation's democracy. Page 16. Second Thoughts on Drugs More than half of the new drugs approved for sale in the United States have severe, unpredicted side effects, a Congressional report says.

LEAD: As he meets with President Bush this week, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has an overriding interest in more trade with the United States as the key to restructuring the Soviet economy and integrating it into the world economy.

LEAD: The man who designed Michael Jackson's white glove and Elton John's feathered gorilla suit and boots that lit up with electric lights is Bill Whitten, a Los Angeles designer and as of March, also a retailer. On March 4, he opened his store, Bill Whitten.

LEAD: After reading ''The Fabulous Bush and Baker Boys'' (by Maureen Dowd and Thomas L. Friedman, May 6), I would vote George Bush and James Baker the two guys I'd most like to go on a working vacation with. I'm just sorry that these two bright and engaging men have given us nothing to date but all-talk-no-action domestic policies.
LEAD: Although it takes in less than a quarter of a square mile, Prospect Heights in Brooklyn is a microcosm of New York City's housing situation.
LEAD: The leader of the right-wing Conservative Party called on whites today to rally for ''all-encompassing action'' against President F. W. de Klerk's plans to dismantle apartheid.

LEAD: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products.

LEAD: MACHOL SIPPED DEEPLY FROM THE BOWL OF FERMENTED MARE'S milk and pondered democracy. Machol knew all about horses and sheep and wolves, but now this unfamiliar concept was sweeping Mongolia. His wife and five children hovered silently in the rear of the gur, the white felt tent that is a herdsman's home, waiting for his judgment.
LEAD: Jose Canseco is vastly overrated as a power hitter. After all, he hit only his second double of the season yesterday and he hasn't hit any triples.
LEAD: ART AND NATURE

LEAD: If the overseers of our musical life have their way, the days of the simple, single classical music concert - a morceau of modernity followed by a concerto, an intermission and then something earnest, long and uplifting - may be numbered. The trend these days is toward thematic inclusivity, not to say all-inclusivity.

LEAD: Behind the batting cage at Veterans Stadium, chewing tobacco was spilling out of Lenny Dykstra's chubby fingers as he stuffed a wad inside his left cheek. In the outfield, Roger McDowell, with a white bandana under his burgundy cap and his peppermint pin-striped pants stretched down around the top of his burgundy shoes, was shagging fly balls.

LEAD: All artists have personalities and skills that shape their art; no one is equally expert at everything. Thus artists who attempt to stretch beyond their innate strengths command respect but risk failure.

LEAD: The late Joseph Campbell, the teacher and philosopher, continues to make his presence felt at Sarah Lawrence College, where he taught for 38 years. Mr. Campbell was known for his work on mythology.
LEAD: Do the Saudis know something that American oil traders are only beginning to suspect?

LEAD: WORK is now under way on the second of seven levels of a 364-space parking garage that will form the base of the 39-story Savings of America Tower in the financial district at 120 North LaSalle across the street from City Hall. It is the latest of three new downtown office projects catering to smaller tenants in the last two years.

Mr. Gordon, 25, graduated from the State University of New York at Stony Brook and the New York Law School.

LEAD: For years, Americans demanded cleaner air and Washington did nothing. Now that the House has joined the Senate in passing legislation, a major overhaul of the air pollution laws - little more than a distant dream one year ago - seems well within reach.

LEAD: John Smoltz came within two outs of pitching Atlanta's first no-hitter in 17 years as the Braves beat the Philadelphia Phillies today, 6-1.

LEAD: The music-hall tradition has died out in this country, supplanted by television specials. But with the best dog act in decades, creative aerialists and acrobat-contortionists, a brilliant Michael Jackson impersonator-cum-juggler and its one-sketch comedians, the Leningrad State Music Hall declares that there is still room for a beplumed chorus line and the old variety show.

LEAD: Charles H. Keating Jr. has filed a new lawsuit contending that Federal banking regulators waged a vendetta against him, destroying the American Continental Corporation and his personal fortunes.

LEAD: Although much of the public debate over the civil rights bill now before Congress has focused on the issue of quotas in hiring and promoting minority workers, the opposition of business to the legislation centers on a different concern - monetary damages.

LEAD: Greg Norman is fed up. Here he is an acclaimed golf champion, a master of his sport, yet every time he gets together with his buddies, Wayne Gretzky, Ivan Lendl and Larry Bird, they make him feel like some third-rate tiddlywinks player.

LEAD: Ethnic violence intensified in Sind Province today, leaving at least 82 people dead and more than 275 wounded in two cities, the authorities and witnesses said.

LEAD: It was the eighth inning that Bucky Dent couldn't quite wipe from his mind. Not the first or the third or the fourth, not the way that Dave LaPoint pitched, not the sudden turn for the worse that the trip has taken.

Their launch pad is a transitional housing program designed to help homeless families find the skills, the courage and ultimately the permanent housing to end the cycle of despair.

LEAD: For New York fans of Louisiana zydeco, last Monday's show at Tramps was something like having the mountain come to Mohammed. Ms. Adler, who will keep her name, is a Williams College graduate and a project planner in the Mayor's Office of Special Projects and Events in New York.

The criticism comes from Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting, a left-wing watchdog group, which has documented the reliance of both programs on guests identified with the

LEAD: Ballerinas sometimes approach the Cowgirl, the lovelorn tomboy of Agnes de Mille's ''Rodeo,'' in much the same spirit as glamorous actresses used to portray women with spectacles and their hair in buns. In cowboy boots and a braid, a dancer can act, and the Cowgirl seemed to grow mousier and more gamely pathetic as years went by.

LEAD: Angela Allyn, a daughter of Christina Adamson of Glencoe, Ill., and the late Thomas Tilden Adamson, was married last evening to Matt Gordon Dinerstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Dinerstein of East Hills, L.I. Rabbi Mordecai Rosen performed the ceremony at the Glencoe Women's Library Club.

LEAD: The whole last half of the 20th century has been clouded by the cold war, a war of deadly sparks if not of conflagration. That somber fact warrants note on this day set aside to commemorate the valor of those who lost their lives in hot wars.
LEAD: Dominating Brazil's ''Steel City'' for half a century, the smokestacks and blast furnaces of the Companhia Siderurgica Nacional have long symbolized Brazil's state-led industrialization.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There was a time, tonight's opening episode of ''Stalin'' reminds viewers, when the Soviet dictator was treated as an avuncular figure by many Western journalists. The distance between that period and the present can be measured by the absorbing three-part documentary that begins at 9 tonight on Channel 13.

LEAD: Familial quarrels, especially those incited by greed, sometimes degenerate into bloodletting, and in ''German Requiem,'' Eric Bentley's new play at the Living Theater, they may even portend the end of the world.
LEAD: The wedding of Sarah Simms and Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal took place yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony.

LEAD: What was fine weather for Arie Luyendyk and about 350,000 fans who watched him win the Indianapolis 500 today turned out to be miserable conditions for Emerson Fittipaldi, Al Unser Jr. and a bunch of Goodyear tires.

LEAD: In the 150-odd years of their existence, Liszt's B-minor Sonata and Chopin's 24 Preludes have become major industries for performing pianists. Literally thousands have stepped before the public and had their say about both pieces. Stronger personalities manage to reflect images of themselves in these shopworn masterpieces; lesser musicians use the allure of their familiarity to attract audiences.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Seven honorary degrees, including one to a Chinese dissident writer who spent 20 years in forced labor and exile, were awarded at Trinity College's 164th commencement yesterday in Hartford.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The University of Rochester yesterday conferred its 5,000th doctor of philosophy degree, one of 2,341 degrees awarded during its 140th commencement.

LEAD: C. J. Mueller hummed softly to himself as he paced around the tent at the top of the course. He felt a loosening in his shoulders and a tingling in his body; occasionally he recreated the sensation of holding a perfect tuck through the speed zone while rocketing down the hill at a speed of over 130 miles per hour.

LEAD: The Vivaldi juggernaut gained momentum on Wednesday evening, when Dino Anagnost and his Little Orchestra Society presented the second of this season's three concerts in a projected five-year festival, Vivaldi's Venice. In contrast to the first concert at Alice Tully Hall, which trotted out ''The Four Seasons'' yet again along with some opera excerpts, this one, at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, presented some important and little-known sacred works in their entirety.

LEAD: Since she has inarguably mastered the tennis racquet, Steffi Graf wants to learn to play the piano. It is the latest twist to her conviction that, no matter how much she reveres it, tennis can get a bit monolithic.
LEAD: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's annual Dance Africa festival can be relied on for exciting and provocative dance and a warm glow of community. And this year was no different.
LEAD: Two Hispanic men were assaulted and one was severely beaten by three black men who shouted racial slurs at them as they waited for a taxi early yesterday in the Bronx, the police said.

LEAD: Charles Simic, who won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry this year with a collection of prose poems, ''The World Doesn't End,'' credits the military police with having helped in the formation of his work. Mr. Simic had begun writing verse in his youth, only a couple of years after he acquired English when he came to this country from Yugoslavia.
LEAD: Crippled by the collapse of the tourism industry, foreign-financed hotels across the country are struggling to meet their debt payments.

LEAD: Celebrating the 30th anniversary of his transition from Valentino Garavani to VALENTINO, the Italian couturier has transformed a splendiferous 15th-century building in the heart of Rome into a center for the arts. Named after himself, of course, first name only.

LEAD: Rebel forces began an offensive today apparently aimed at cutting off Liberia's capital from the rest of the country.

Gregory of Los Angeles, took place yesterday at the American Boychoir School in Princeton. Mayor Cathleen R. Litvack of Princeton Township officiated.

LEAD: The disclosure of a flaw in the design of nuclear artillery shells deployed in Europe has generated new interest in a number of Government studies that said 14 types of nuclear weapons had been temporarily withdrawn from the American arsenal since 1961 for repairs.
LEAD: A two-week-old tabloid in Kansas City, Mo., is trying to solve the long-standing riddle of how to make a profit with an afternoon newspaper.

LEAD: When the seniors at Mills College loosed yellow balloons and let them float toward the sky a week ago, they were celebrating more than their graduation. They were celebrating the continuance of the kind of education they had chosen for themselves, and that Mills had been offering its students for 138 years.

LEAD: In a Harvard lecture on what he called ''the American Romance,'' Richard Darman recently declared that America ''was founded by risk-takers, expanded by risk-takers and led to the highest standard of living on earth by risk-takers.''

LEAD: Charles Hamilton, an autograph dealer and handwriting expert who has sold his share of sketches over the years, is the first to tell you that a signed sketch by the noted muralist and poster artist, Howard Chandler Christy, a portrait of a beautiful woman or a noted society matron done in ink on the finest white stock in pristine condition, would sell for no more than $5,000.

LEAD: At Temple Sholom in Chicago, Ruth Richman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Richman of Glencoe, Ill., was married yesterday to Kenneth Kornbluh, a son of Alan Kornbluh of Miami and Leah Poller of Washington. Mrs. Kornbluh, a writer, graduated magna cum laude from Brandeis University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a master's degree in journalism from Northwestern University.

LEAD: As a member of Congress from northwest Alabama more than 30 years ago, Carl Elliott was an uncommon Deep South politician, championing revolutionary social legislation, eschewing racial demagoguery and more often than not finding himself casting a crucial vote to advance Federal initiatives in education, health care or civil rights.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who is enmeshed in a controversy involving two of his closest aides, may face a similar problem as a Federal grand jury in Pennsylvania investigates another former longtime assistant on cocaine charges.
LEAD: A sheriff's deputy resigned and an Ohio restaurateur killed himself after their names turned up on a list of a male prostitution ring that the authorities say involved customers from 39 states.

LEAD: When Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev agreed to visit Camp David next weekend, the Soviet Embassy was asked what pastimes the couple would enjoy. The answer was no to recreation. A senior Bush adviser said, ''Gorbachev doesn't like to do anything except work.''
LEAD: Two of the most promising 3-year-olds in the country will be racing at Belmont Park on June 9, but not in the Belmont Stakes.
LEAD: One man was killed and another wounded when a gunman opened fire at a bar in upper Manhattan early yesterday morning, the police said.

LEAD: As the House and Senate prepare to go to conference on their separate versions of the Clean Air Act, lobbyists for the auto, oil, steel and utilities industries are planning to reopen some battles they lost in one or even both houses, including a dispute over creating cleaner automobile fuels for nine large cities.

LEAD: Philip V. White, a former associate dean at the City University of New York who was about to become New Jersey's acting Chancellor of Education, died Thursday night at his home in Princeton Township. The police said the death was apparently a suicide. He was 46 years old.
LEAD: ''I've got grandchildren and he's got family and we can talk about it as human beings. 'Hey, what are we going to do to make things a little safer?' '' -President Bush. [6:1.]

LEAD: Prof. Emil J. Konopinski, who helped design the first atomic bomb and made testing of the first hydrogen bomb possible by showing that it would not destroy the world, died Saturday at Bloomington Hospital after a long illness. He was 78 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed.

LEAD: The big motor race yesterday, which I wouldn't watch, reminded me that as a driver I was on my way to Indy the first time I got behind the wheel of a car. This is a true story.

LEAD: The kind of student demonstrations that filled the streets with protesters and tear gas here over the last week have become an unofficial fixture of the South Korean university curriculum and, at times, a genuine catalyst for change. LEAD: In their rush to toughen the nation's laws against money laundering, Congress and the Bush Administration may be stepping on the civil liberties of bank customers, the American Civil Liberties Union and some lobbying groups representing bankers assert.
LEAD: An art review in Weekend on Friday about ''The Decade Show'' misidentified one museum. It is the Museum of Contemporary Hispanic Art.

LEAD: Poles voted today for community councils nationwide and were expected to push forward democratic changes by ousting holdover Communists from their last bastions of power.

Rabbi George M. Stern officiated at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton. The bride, 27 years old, will keep her name. She is a marketing manager at the Pepsi-Cola Company in Somers, N.Y.
LEAD: Two young sisters were killed and their grandmother was critically injured before dawn today when their house was swept by a fire that the authorities believe was deliberately set.
LEAD: THE Alberto-Culver Company seems an unlikely character in a takeover story, but in the last few weeks its shares have been trading as if someone was expecting an offer.

LEAD: Minna Ferziger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Ferziger of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Clifford M. J. Felig, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Felig of New York. Rabbi Adam S. Ferziger, a brother of the bride, officiated at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y.

LEAD: Pat Williams is taking no chances. The Montana Democrat heads the House subcommittee that oversees the National Endowment for the Arts. That's why he has convened 30 representatives of arts institutions and the public to debate the future of the beleaguered agency.

LEAD: Robert B. Meyner, who revitalized the Democratic Party in New Jersey and rose to national prominence during two terms as Governor in the 1950's and early 60's, died Sunday at his home in Captiva, Fla., after a long illness. He was 81 years old and had been in declining health since suffering a stroke in 1986.

LEAD: Japanese banks, which earned a reputation for price-cutting as they become the colossuses of the financial world in the 1980's, are adjusting their strategies to improve profits, an area in which they lag behind American and European banks.

LEAD: When the American Civil Liberties Union supported the right of American Nazis to march through Skokie, Ill., a largely Jewish suburb of Chicago, in 1977, 10,000 members of the A.C.L.U. were so angered that they resigned from the group.
LEAD: The National Gallery of Art will put on public view on Wednesday its latest acquisition, an early-17th-century painting by Peter Paul Rubens titled ''The Fall of Phaeton.''

LEAD: The era of the Gait twins, the Syracuse lacrosse luminaries, came to an end today in expected and glorious ways. The Orangemen routed Loyola College of Baltimore, 21-9, and thus won the national championship for a third consecutive year, before a crowd of 19,075 that overflowed Rutgers Stadium.

LEAD: Although National Basketball Association teams have played a number of exhibition games in foreign arenas, including a barnstorming series by the Atlanta Hawks in the Soviet Union in 1988, no American pro sports league has had an official game outside of North America.
LEAD: The dollar finished mixed in quiet European trading today, affected by the Memorial Day holiday in the United States and a bank holiday in Britain.
LEAD: Baseball

LEAD: When Whittle Communications announced plans for Channel One, an advertiser-sponsored news program for high school students, critics assailed the inclusion of commercials. The program has been running since March, and with a single exception, the commercials have been standard-product advertising.

LEAD: Frank M. Adams, the president of the Morrison Knudsen Company, and his wife, Novella, were killed on Sunday morning when a single-engine plane he was flying crashed near Naylor, Mo. Both were 64 years old and lived in Boise, Idaho, where Morrison Knudsen, one of the world's largest heavy-construction concerns, has its headquarters.
LEAD: Sheets covering a patient caught fire during surgery today, filling an operating room with smoke so thick that staff members could not extinguish the flames. The patient died.

LEAD: New York City's property-tax system, which has been criticized for a decade for placing a heavier burden on less-affluent homeowners than on wealthier ones, appears to have grown more inequitable.
LEAD: Bird Navigation

LEAD: The Soviet Union has begun to dismantle its huge radar station at Krasnoyarsk, which the United States has long said was a violation of the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, a Bush Administration official said tonight.

LEAD: Ron Whyte, who died last September, wrote the libretto for ''Mother and Child,'' a new one-act opera that had its first showing at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Wednesday night. Rarely is the author the first matter of consideration in an opera review, but Mr. Whyte's life and this stage piece are inseparable.

LEAD: Joseph H. Braverman, a retired vice president of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, died of lymphoma on Saturday at University Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived on Staten Island.
LEAD: More than 1,300 passengers were stranded for two days on board a luxury liner stuck on a sand bar in Delaware Bay until they were carried to shore today on a ferry.

LEAD: The Pittsburgh Pirates, held to one hit in eight innings by Tim Belcher, rallied for five runs in the ninth today to beat Los Angeles, 6-5, ending the Dodgers' five game-winning streak in a game marred by brushbacks.

LEAD: CHILDREN whose mothers had amniocentesis, a commonly used prenatal test for genetic defects, seem to have more frequent ear infections than those whose mothers did not, according to a study published in a British scientific journal earlier this year.

LEAD: Ronald J. Grayheck has been elected chief executive of the American National Corporation and its principal subsidiary, the American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, which are units of the First Chicago Corporation.

LEAD: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the Memorial Day parade in New York misidentified the marchers. They were Chinese-American veterans from the American Legion's Kim Lau Post, not Korean-Americans. Another Memorial Day caption, about women performing folk dances, misidentifed the monument in the picture. LEAD: It was a small parade, and the crowd was often only one-deep along the sidewalk. But they clapped respectfully when the veterans of many wars marched by on West 72d Street yesterday morning, and there was a pleasing solemnity missing from most Manhattan parades. At least until the truck of WHTZ-FM rolled by, towing a set of speakers that required their own trailer.

LEAD: Japan's major banks announced their earnings today for the just-ended fiscal year, and, as had been expected, most reported lower profits and margins because of the tumultuous changes affecting the financial markets here.

LEAD: The arrests of four men for drinking alcohol at a street picnic in Jersey City yesterday afternoon led to a clash between the police and neighborhood residents, who said the police had handcuffed one of the men and beat him.
LEAD: A collapsed lung is expected to keep Harmon Killebrew hospitalized for at least 10 days. Killebrew, 53 years old, underwent surgery last Friday at a Scottsdale, Ariz., hospital.

LEAD: WINDOWS 3.0, the new software that the Microsoft Corporation describes as a ''graphical environment'' for I.B.M. PC and compatible computers, really hides the Phantom of the Operating System behind an attractive mask. The true face of DOS, the Disk Operating System, resides in dark, hidden chambers deep within tens of millions of PC's.

LEAD: A performance by the Harbor Brass Quintet will open a series of shows in St. Mark's Park, 10th Street and Second Avenue. A variety of entertainers will be featured during the free outdoor series, which will run on Thursdays at 12:30 P.M. from June 14 to July 26. The shows, sponsored by the Third Street Music School Settlement and local block associations, will go on rain or shine.
LEAD: There are no answers. Not from Bucky Dent. Not from any of the Yankees, who sat passively at their lockers tonight.

LEAD: Noon - President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and his wife, Raisa, arrive at Uplands International Airport in Ottawa, where they are to be met by Governor General Ramon John Hnatyshyn and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney for a 30-minute ceremony. 1:30 P.M. - The Gorbachevs have a private lunch with Mr.

LEAD: Rusty Wallace, hard-charging at an average of 137 miles an hour over more than four hours, crossed the finish line of the Coca-Cola 600 in first place on Sunday, earning $151,000 for himself and inestimable millions in recognition for his sponsor, the Miller Brewing Company.

LEAD: If composing music used to be the creation of order out of chaos, the trio of performers called First Avenue seemed to be telling its Thursday-night audience that things have changed. In most of the music that came out of this long evening at Merkin Concert Hall, the composer became if anything a master of ceremonies, someone who announces the attractions of other forces and then steps aside.

LEAD: In the months before Lee Trevino joined the Senior PGA Tour, he would smile and say, ''I can't wait to play against the round bellies instead of the flat bellies.'' And play he has. Awaiting the Nynex/Golf Digest Commemorative that starts Friday at Sleepy Hollow in Scarborough, N.Y., he is the money leader with $340,133 and the scoring leader with a 69.29-stroke average.

LEAD: A record total of 20 syndicates from 15 foreign nations have entered bids to challenge the San Diego Yacht Club for the America's Cup in 1992. The foreign syndicates had 30 days from the April 26 filing of the New York Court of Appeals' decision upholding the San Diego Yacht Club victory over New Zealand in 1988 to challenge for the 1992 event from off Point Loma, Calif.

LEAD: A thunderstorm's winds toppled stage speakers at a music and arts festival Sunday, injuring 27 people. Several thousand at the Baton Rouge Fest for All were watching a warm-up band and waiting for a performance by the Temptations when scaffolding about seven feet high on the sides of the two-story-tall stage collapsed.

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday New Home Sales . . . April Leading Indicators . . . April Thursday Farm PricesMay Friday Construction Spending .

LEAD: More than a third of the nation's nursing homes offering skilled care failed to meet standards for clean food in surprise inspections in 1988 and 1989, and nearly a quarter did not administer drugs properly, according to the Government's latest consumer guide.
LEAD: MUCH of the sulfuric gas pumped into the atmosphere by man and nature falls out in acid rain, but some molecules can penetrate the upper reaches and hover like an impenetrable cloud.

LEAD: An Israeli belly dancer won a Supreme Court appeal against the Orthodox hierarchy today when the court ruled that kosher licenses could be issued or revoked only on the basis of preparation and serving of food, and not because of other factors, among them her presence as a performer in a restaurant.

LEAD: After nearly three years of seeking permission to raise its 8.9 percent stake in the St. Paul Companies, the Alleghany Corporation is selling its 4.4 million shares back to St. Paul for a market value of $260.7 million, plus $5 million in expenses.

LEAD: IF America eventually decides it can spare the $8 billion or so needed to build the Superconducting Supercollider, the county-size machine might turn out to be a key to the meaning of physical reality, or it might be a dud. But either way, the project is raising intense debate among scientists and politicians as to whether the new knowledge it generates will be commensurate with the enormous cost.
LEAD: Joseph Papp has made major changes in the artistic structure of the New York Shakespeare Festival, which he created 35 years ago.

LEAD: While the voters and news organizations focus on the heated race for the Democratic nomination for governor of California, political professionals from the White House to Los Angeles are riveted on how Californians will vote on two ballot measures that could eventually help to alter the balance of power in

LEAD: If you think the census counters have a monumental task, consider what's going on at 97 Orchard Street on the Lower East Side. The six-story building, built in 1863 near Delancey Street, is the home of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which chronicles the urban immigrant experience and which is trying to find the names of all the people who lived in the building's 20 apartments.

LEAD: A few hours after his team was eliminated from the college baseball playoffs, Dan Gallagher, the Fordham Rams' barrel-chested coach, sat in his hotel room reflecting on the squad's 6-5 loss to South Alabama.

LEAD: Ramon Ramos of the Portland Trail Blazers came back to practice yesterday. Five months after suffering a severe brain injury in a car accident, Ramos watched as his teammates prepared for Game 5 of the Western Conference finals, which will be played tonight in Portland, Ore.

LEAD: Is President Bush, who built an imposing victory in 1988 and imposing poll ratings in 1989 and 1990 at least partly on his ''no new taxes'' pledge, starting to fade politically because he has softened that pledge?
LEAD: In observance of Memorial Day, all financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday. The financial markets in Britain were closed in observance of a bank holiday.

LEAD: An Amtrak passenger train struck a tanker truck loaded with sewage sludge today and 9 people were injured. None of the injuries were serious, the authorities said. The accident occurred about noon at a rural crossing between Indiantown and Okeechobee in southeast Florida. Lieut. Jim Howell of the Florida Highway Patrol said the truck driver was ticketed for failure to stop at a railroad crossing.

LEAD: The Chinese authorities in Tibet have increasingly relied on political repression and torture to suppress Tibetans who oppose their rule, according to a report made public today by Asia Watch, a United States-based human rights group.

LEAD: The Federal pension insurance fund's $2.2 billion claim against the LTV Corporation should be reduced, a Federal bankruptcy judge has ruled. He also rejected an effort by the fund, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, to push its claim ahead of others in the company's bankruptcy case.
LEAD: In a child-abuse case that has sparked an outcry from advocates for battered women, a woman and her former husband have been indicted in the beating death of the woman's 2-year-old son.

LEAD: Voters in Myanmar, formerly Burma, appeared today to have sharply repudiated their military rulers and to have given a landslide victory to the main opposition party, whose leadership remains in jail or under house arrest.
LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq set a bellicose and anti-American tone for the Arab summit meeting here today, despite efforts by Egypt and Saudi Arabia to mute inflammatory oratory.

LEAD: No less an authority than the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, says the eventual cost of the savings and loan bailout could exceed a half- trillion dollars. A half-trillion. And Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady admits that taxpayers will bear most of that burden.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Moscow stores featured fresh supplies of stoicism today, with shoppers forced to brandish their domestic passports and face a ration list rapidly growing to include everything from light bulbs to socks.
LEAD: * Federal Paper Board Co., Montvale, N.J., promoted W. Mark Massey Jr. to senior vice president for manufacturing at its forest products division. He was also named a director.

LEAD: With deadlines next month for resolving a longstanding dispute, negotiations between Hollywood producers and the broadcast networks over financial ownership of television reruns have been thrown into ''turmoil and chaos'' by the producers' threat to seek Federal antitrust charges against the networks, a senior network executive said last week.
LEAD: rrThe demise of the New Shooter went unnoticed four years ago, but this season his absence is glaring.

LEAD: American and Soviet negotiators have reached an agreement that would triple airline capacity between the two countries, a United States official said today, and the pact is to be signed at the summit meeting this week of President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
LEAD: * Ayer has created a campaign against teen-age alcoholism for the Advertising Council, the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence and the National Citizens Commission on Alcoholism.
LEAD: For the nations of Eastern Europe, freedom may be far dirtier than they expected.
LEAD: Henry A. Keller, who helped pioneer the use of prefabricated aluminum products in the home-building industry, died at his home on Sunday after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

LEAD: The countdown for the launching of the space shuttle Columbia was abruptly halted this evening when sensors detected abnormally high levels of fuel vapors in the engine compartment of the spaceship, indicating a leak in the propulsion system.
LEAD: Charter flights carrying 500 Soviet Jews a week to Israel will begin moving through Poland next month, marking a new chapter in the complex relationship between Warsaw and Jerusalem.

LEAD: Dissatisfied with the way intricate and elaborate sound tracks came across on the antiquated sound systems in most theaters, Lucasfilm Ltd. seven years ago introduced a system that matched the quality heard on the dubbing stage at the studio. Now, with a greater percentage of movie revenues coming from home video than from theaters, the company is about to announce home versions that will vastly improve the sound from the typical videocassette or laser disk.

LEAD: A grand jury investigation was ordered today into an arrest here on Monday that prompted about 100 protesters to hurl rocks and bottles at police officers outside the West District police station.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THERE are people who live for the molt of the Chesapeake Bay crab. Others await shad from the Hudson, the June run of bass off Cape Cod, or open season on Nantucket's bay scallops in the fall. And then there are those who live for fresh herring.

LEAD: CALF'S liver, which is one of my favorite, budget-priced meats, turns up in countless fine preparations in cuisines of the world. Among the classic French recipes are calf's liver Lyonnaise, which involves sauteeing slices of liver with onions, or a l'Anglaise, made by combining it with onions, bacon and lemon juice.

LEAD: Two young dancers took on the roles of the little ballerina and soldier this season in ''The Steadfast Tin Soldier,'' a charming duet by George Balanchine. And their performance of the ballet on Sunday afternoon, when it was presented by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater, was a treasure that promises to be a highlight of the season.
LEAD: Class at the Waldorf

LEAD: MARKETS Both the Dow and the S.&P. 500 stock index rose sharply to set new highs. The Dow closed at 2,870.49, up 49.57, or 1.8 percent. The S.& P. 500 rose 6.07, to a record 360.65, breaking the former record of 359.80 set Oct. 9, 1989. [Page D1.] Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in light trading as some strength in the dollar and a drop in commodity prices gave investors reasons to buy notes and bonds.

LEAD: Marguerite Stitt Church, an Illinois Republican who was a member of the House of Representatives from 1950 to 1962, died in her sleep on Saturday at her home in Evanston, Ill. She was 97 years old.
LEAD: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal Government can prohibit federally financed family planning programs from giving information or advice about abortion.

LEAD: Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt, the former Dallas billionaires, said yesterday that they were selling their wide-ranging collections of Greek and Roman antiquities in court-ordered sales to help pay the Internal Revenue Service and creditors. The collections include ancient Greek vases, Roman bronzes and coins, and have been valued by

LEAD: The World Bank today approved a $300 million loan to help China combat deforestation but indefinitely postponed a second loan of $150 million for roads and waterways that had been opposed by the Bush Administration.

LEAD: Nintendo of America, the video game company, is ''talking to a number of agencies'' about its advertising account, an advertising executive said yesterday. The incumbent, McCann-Erickson/ New York, is participating in the review, the executive said. The account bills about $15 million. Nintendo officials did not return telephone calls for comment.
LEAD: Taking most traders by surprise, both the Dow Jones industrial average and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rebounded sharply yesterday to set new highs.
LEAD: THIS is the Federal Government's version of a riddle: When is fresh not fresh?
LEAD: Juan Antonio, a dancer, choreographer and co-founder of the Louis Falco Dance Company, died of AIDS last Thursday at Doctors Hospital in Toronto, where he lived. He was 45 years old.
LEAD: Joe McDonald Ingraham, a Federal judge for 36 years, died of complications from heart disease on Sunday at Memorial Southwest Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Houston.
LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk today postponed his trip to the United States next month after complaints from American critics that he was being received by President Bush before Nelson Mandela.

LEAD: Brad Stowell and Hank Kraft combined on a four-hitter today as The Citadel earned its first trip to the College World Series, beating the top-seeded Miami Hurricanes, 4-1, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Atlantic Regional tournament.
LEAD: Jack J. Jorgensen, a teamsters union leader who was convicted in 1955 of taking payoffs to help break a strike, died of pancreatic cancer on Sunday at his home. He was 75 years old.
LEAD: With the United States' opening game of the World Cup finals in Italy just 12 days away, the team's three goalkeepers are still uncertain which of them will be named the starter.

LEAD: Abram J. Shorin, one of four brothers who founded the Topps Chewing Gum Company and its ubiquitous line of baseball cards, died of a heart attack on Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami Beach, Fla. He was 91 years old and lived in Miami Beach.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that the presence of cocaine in a newborn's system, and the mother's admission of drug use, were enough justification for New York City to ask for a Family Court hearing on child neglect.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: In a bold move, the expanding Fox network announced yesterday that it was moving its hit show, the animated comedy ''The Simpsons,'' to compete against NBC's top-rated ''Cosby Show.''

LEAD: A memorial meeting for Richard G. Stein, a Manhattan architect whose ideas on energy conservation influenced architectural design, is to be held at 12:30 P.M. on Sunday at the United Nations Chapel, First Avenue at 44th Street. The speakers are to include the environmentalist Barry Commoner. Mr. Stein died on April 18 at the age of 73.

LEAD: Jenny Zeng left her home in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou 18 months ago. She was a teacher in an elementary school there. Now she works in a Chinatown garment factory, stitching together dresses that she later sees for sale along Canal Street.
LEAD: Robert Abrams announced today that he would seek a fourth four-year term as state attorney general.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Bush Administration believes that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's domestic problems will not prevent him from completing pending arms control treaties, but it is increasingly concerned that they might become an obstacle on broader issues like the future of Germany, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Taking a step described as the first toward giving the firm a new life, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday as Frederick H. Joseph stepped down from his post as chief executive.

LEAD: Not even the metamorphosis of Robert Morse into Truman Capote can match that of the comic actress Pat Carroll into Sir John Falstaff for ''The Merry Wives of Windsor.'' When Ms. Carroll makes her first entrance, a nervous silence falls over the audience at the Shakespeare Theater at the Folger here, as hundreds of eyes search for some trace of the woman they've seen in a thousand television reruns.

LEAD: The seizure of a fleet of North Korean fishing boats by the Soviet Union in the Pacific Ocean last week has turned into a major diplomatic embarrassment for Tokyo, with the discovery that the fleet and more than 140 fishermen now in Soviet custody are actually Japanese.

LEAD: The judge in the Iran-contra case of John M. Poindexter today denied a request for a new trial for the former national security adviser, who was convicted of five criminal charges last month for his role in the affair.

LEAD: The economist who is the Minister of the Office of Central Planning in Poland's Solidarity-led Government told more than 2,300 graduating students of Bernard M. Baruch College yesterday that they should ''go beyond symbols and work to integrate the free world - East and West.''
LEAD: Among those who have read or heard his views on race, it is very hard to find anyone, black or white, with a neutral reaction to Shelby Steele.

Bogus Fishing Fleet A Soviet seizure of North Korean fishing boats in the Pacific has turned into an embarrassment for Tokyo, with the discovery that the vessels were actually Japanese.

LEAD: Despite all the down-to-the-second planning of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's supposedly spontaneous walkabout today, the Soviet President briefly confounded the plans of security guards and well-wishers alike. He was 20 minutes late, didn't stop in the designated spot, and then just stayed and stayed.

LEAD: The Fiat Group, racing ahead of its competitors to set up shop in Eastern Europe, has agreed to work with the Soviet Union to produce 900,000 cars a year there and with Polish auto makers to assemble 270,000 cars a year.
LEAD: Five of the six family members controlling the Champion Insurance Company have pleaded guilty to mail fraud charges in a plea bargain with the Federal Government.

LEAD: The New York State and New York City governments, faced with disappointing tax revenues, have been scavenging everywhere for money with which to plug big holes in their budgets. Some of these forays threaten the state's and city's ability to carry on their work. An offer by the Municipal Assistance Corporation to give New York City $1.5 billion in fiscal 1991 poses no such threat and ought to be accepted in

Yeltsin, the maverick politician who has spent three years fighting the Communist Party establishment, today became President of the Russian republic, overcoming a last-ditch effort by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to block his election before departing for visits to Canada and the United

LEAD: ''The Art of Fugue'' is Bach at his most abstract and cerebral. A compendium of contrapuntal techniques demonstrated in 20 increasingly complex fugues and canons, the work was conceived more as a valedictory than as a performance piece. Bach did not specify instrumentation, but the work is too glorious to live only on paper.

LEAD: Cliff Robinson, a 6-foot-10-inch, 225-pound rookie forward with the Portland Trail Blazers, pleaded guilty yesterday to punching a policewoman outside a Portland bar at about 3 A.M. on April 29 and was sentenced to a year of probation and fined $250 for fourth-degree assault, a misdemeanor.

LEAD: Five days after saying that the city could not afford it, Mayor David N. Dinkins moved yesterday to restore money in his proposed budget to maintain the Sanitation Department Clean Team, a group responsible for manually sweeping streets and emptying trash cans.
LEAD: Cecil Johnson Roberts, a patron of the arts and a colorful liberal in conservative Alabama, died yesterday at a hospital in Birmingham, Ala., after suffering an embolism. She was 76 years old.
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev may not yet face a full-fledged political opposition in this deeply troubled land, but he now certainly has a personal nemesis to haunt his days of power.

LEAD: * Acton Corp, Raleigh, N.C., an insurance and real estate concern, agreed to purchase the furniture operations of Hickory Furniture Co., High Point, N.C., for $44.5 million. The operations will continue under the name of Hickory White.
LEAD: * Association of Exporters of Spanish Table Olives, Seville, Spain, to Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners.

LEAD: Boris Becker went out without answering the bang of his opponent's backhand and Stefan Edberg provided little more than a whimper as the top two top-seeded players, neither of them clay-court aficionados, were ambushed today by teen-agers in the opening round of the French Open.

LEAD: A new National Research Center on the Gifted and Talented, to be based at the University of Connecticut and operated by a group of four universities, will be established with a $7.5 million grant awarded this month by the Federal Department of Education.
LEAD: Lantern Slides Stories By Edna O'Brien 224 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

LEAD: The Computerland Corporation, a leading personal computer franchise chain based in Pleasanton, Calif., acquired certain assets of the Computer Shoppe Inc., a chain of eight computer stores in the Southeast and Midwest with 1989 sales of about $55 million. The purchase price of the acquisition was not disclosed.

LEAD: ''We voted so that things would change, but nothing has changed. We had hope. Everyone had hope. But look what has become of it. Every day, our lives get worse.'' -Yolanda Navarro Castro, a Nicaraguan food vendor. [A1:4.]
LEAD: As President Bush prepares for his summit meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, Americans no longer worry very much about the Soviet Union as a military threat.
LEAD: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the British soft-drink and candy maker, agreed today to buy most of the non-cola soft drinks business of Source Perrier of France for $211 million.
LEAD: The Mets unveiled a new manager here tonight as Bud Harrelson replaced Davey Johnson, and then the team went out on the field and played like nothing had ever changed.

LEAD: Soldiers and anti-Government demonstrators battled today for control of an oil production center in this West African country, and at least five people were reported wounded, including a soldier.
LEAD: About two weeks ago, something happened that may subtly undermine the recent efforts of antismoking advocates: the tobacco industry raised cigarette prices and most smokers went along.

LEAD: Rickey Henderson broke Ty Cobb's 62-year-old American League record for stolen bases, but the achievement played no part in the scoring tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Oakland Athletics, 2-1.

LEAD: * CS First Boston Inc., New York, the investment banking firm, named Anthony P. Grassi chief financial and administrative officer. Robert M. Raziano was also named head of finance, administration, systems and operations at First Boston Corp., its American operating unit.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Arab meeting in Baghdad misstated the starting date of the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories. It was December 1987, not 1988.

Now there's another chance: ''Steel Wheels,'' the edited version of the broadcast, to be shown tonight at 8 on the Fox network.

LEAD: Justice HAROLD BAER JR. of the New York State Supreme Court was sworn in by his father in December 1982. As a newcomer, he was assigned to one of the small chambers in the state courthouse on Foley Square in Manhattan, where his father, Justice Harold Baer, had served for 22 years before retiring in 1977.
LEAD: Easy Goer came out of his surprising defeat in the Metropolitan Handicap on Monday healthy and uninjured, but his handlers said yesterday they were baffled by the colt's performance.
