LEAD: 10:15 A.M. - Prime Minister Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada lay a wreath at the War Memorial monument just outside Parliament. Shortly before that, Raisa M. Gorbachev and Mila Mulroney start out on a separate itinerary, visiting the National Museum of Natural Sciences and the Museum of Civilization.
LEAD: The New York Republican Party, for the first time in its history, approved an abortion platform today that supports ''reproductive rights for women.''

LEAD: Nearly all the top-ranked players from the New York metropolitan area, together with a few stars from farther afield, are in contention this week in the Reisinger Knockout, perhaps the most prized of all regional team events played anywhere. The defending champions are Henry Bethe, Brian Glubok, Edgar Kaplan, Bill Root, all of Manhattan, Chuck Lamprey of White Plains and Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn.
LEAD: Among the Bemba people, who farm on a high rugged plateau in northern Zambia, sacred clay emblems were traditionally used in initiation ceremonies for women about to be married.
LEAD: If his style as a player is any measure of the man as a manager, don't be surprised if the sluggish and somewhat dispirited 1990 Mets suddenly break out in hustle and elan.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When striking Sandinista workers chained themselves inside state buildings this month and set barricades on fire, forcing the new Government to a halt, Yolanda Navarro Castro came to a bitter conclusion about her country.

LEAD: After months of fighting over where the bank should be situated, who should head it and which countries should be able to receive loans from it, representatives of 40 nations signed a treaty today to establish the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, a $12 billion institution that will provide aid to help revive Eastern Europe's economy.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: As results continued to trickle in today from the first multiparty elections in 30 years in Myanmar, formerly Burma, Western diplomats said the main opposition party had already won at least 66 percent of the seats in a new National Assembly.

LEAD: With astounding courage, the people of Myanmar have defied a bullying military regime and voted overwhelmingly for a pro-democracy movement whose leaders are in jail or under house arrest. Another wall has fallen, and the Burmese did it on their own.
LEAD: The eagerly awaited return of Nolan Ryan to the pitching mound for the struggling Texas Rangers will be delayed an additional six days, team officials said yesterday.

LEAD: More than seven years after it was pronounced dead, a casualty of toxic contamination, Times Beach still haunts the rolling hills southwest of St. Louis. It is a ghost town of empty, tumbledown houses and vacant stores, wildly overgrown with weeds.

LEAD: Six months after accepting an appeal by Citibank in an important international banking dispute, the Supreme Court announced today that it would not decide the case without further review by the lower courts.

LEAD: Picture captions on Sunday with a fashion article about tights omitted the names of stores where they are available. Hue's leggings are at Barneys New York. Roberto Robledo's tights are at Charivari. The Pucci leggings are at Bergdorf Goodman.

LEAD: The Postal Service now estimates that this election year, the House will spend a record $79 million on free mailings to constituents. That's $40 million more than it has just budgeted. And if that's not bad enough, consider the way the House now responds to this embarrassment.

LEAD: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 10.00 10.00 11.50 DISCOUNT RATE 7.00 7.00 7.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 8.25 8.31 9.77 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 7.80 7.75 8.58 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 7.74 7.75 8.44 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 8.64 8.70 8.67 30-YR.

LEAD: Arab leaders seeking a common response to Soviet Jewish migration to Israel and other issues extended a two-day summit meeting here today as Egypt and other nations looked for a consensus of moderation in the face of increasing anti-American sentiment.

LEAD: Giving an expansive interpretation to the Constitution's protection against double jeopardy, the Supreme Court today barred officials from prosecuting a man for homicide after he had pleaded guilty to drunken driving in the accident that caused the death.
LEAD: No matter how grim the situation, the Portland Trail Blazers have kept the poise, maintained the willpower and made the clutch plays to remain unbeaten (9-0) at home during the playoffs.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a formal investigation into at least two contracts obtained by the Todd Shipyards Corporation between June 1985 and August 1987, the company disclosed today.

LEAD: The small circle of confidants with whom President Samuel K. Doe has surrounded himself was notably smaller today with many of the palace regulars having left this capital in the face of an approaching insurgency.
LEAD: DHL International Ltd. said today that Japan Air Lines, Lufthansa and the Japanese trading company Nissho Iwai would acquire a minority stake in the air express service company.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Rev. Paul Nichols, a Baptist minister who was executive director of the Board of National Ministries of the American Baptist Churches, died of a cerebral hemorrhage on Sunday at Mary Washington Hospital in Fredericksburg, Va. He was 50 years old and lived in Richmond and King of Prussia, Pa.
LEAD: After months of intensive negotiation, the United States and the Soviet Union plan to sign a path-breaking agreement this week to slash their arsenals of poison gas.

LEAD: In the four years since his ouster as dictator of Haiti, JEAN-CLAUDE DUVALIER has been living on the French Riviera in a house owned by ADNAN KHASHOGGI, the Saudi Arabian arms merchant. But Mr. Khashoggi, who is on trial in New York with Imelda Marcos over allegations that she stole from the Phillipines treasury, has decided to sell the villa, Mohamedia.
LEAD: At least seven girls and women have been raped in and near Far Rockaway, Queens, since Jan. 31, and the police said yesterday that they believed one man was responsible for the attacks.

LEAD: In its first study of print production costs, the American Association of Advertising Agencies found that color ads are about two and a half times as expensive as black-and-white ones. In 1989, the average four-color, one-page magazine ad cost $15,660 to produce; the average black-and-white ad cost $6,224.

LEAD: The Justice Department announced today that it had requested a broad expansion of a special prosecutor's investigation of Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Housing Secretary in the Reagan Administration.

LEAD: Davey Johnson, who won more games than any other manager in major league baseball over the last six seasons, was dismissed by the New York Mets today and replaced by Bud Harrelson, his third-base coach.

LEAD: Allan S. Huston, moving from pizza to fried chicken, yesterday was named president of Kentucky Fried Chicken's international unit, where he will be responsible for 3,000 company-owned and franchised restaurants in 57 countries.

LEAD: William I. Jovanovich, who slowly built Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. into one of America's great publishing houses before abruptly miring it in overwhelming debt, resigned yesterday as chairman.
LEAD: LEVINE, HUNTLEY, SCHMIDT & BEAVER is out to test one of advertising's hoariest theories: that an agency cannot handle packaged-goods accounts and remain creative.
LEAD: Armenians flew their republic's flag and wore black ribbons today to mourn 24 people killed in clashes between Soviet troops and militants, a local journalist said.
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit were lower for the week that ended yesterday, while money market accounts were mostly unchanged.
LEAD: The Suffolk County Legislature approved a bill today that would require all newspapers with circulations of more than 20,000 in the county to print on recycled paper by the end of 1996.

LEAD: A French judge has dismissed an indictment for receiving a stolen painting that had been brought against the Louvre's chief curator of paintings in a case in which a personal nurse has been accused of swindling an aging heiress.
LEAD: Tektronix Inc., the largest non-government employer in Oregon, said today that it would cut its work force by about 1,300 employees, to about 13,000, by August.

LEAD: The nation's elementary and secondary schoolteachers could be virtually all-white by the end of this decade if measures to push recruitment of minorities are not taken, a group of top educators has warned.

LEAD: Sugar Minott's show at S.O.B.'s on Thursday night took a couple of hours to settle down. And even when it did, not much happened. Mr. Minott, who is one of reggae's better singers, works in a slightly dated style; the thrill that comes from a new and vital genre wasn't there. Backed by a decent band made up partly of Brooklynites and partly of Jamaicans, Mr.
LEAD: Back With an Album
LEAD: * Daniel H. Dolgins has been appointed director of strategy and planning at Baron & Zaretsky Advertising.

LEAD: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the Memorial Day parade in New York misidentified the marchers. They were Chinese-American veterans from the American Legion's Kim Lau Post, not Korean-Americans. Another Memorial Day caption, about women performing folk dances, misidentifed the monument in the picture.

LEAD: A technical expert with the Environmental Protection Agency has raised new questions about the safety of the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant in New Mexico, which is planned as the nation's first permanent nuclear waste repository.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: For 38 years, an old portrait of a jowly person in women's garb has reposed in the collection of the New-York Historical Society, serene in the decidedly unconventional wisdom about its subject.
LEAD: Americans no longer worry about a Soviet military threat very much, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll. Less than 20 percent expect a nuclear war. Page A12.

LEAD: ROSALIND CREASY has made a reputation as a proponent of edible landscaping, using the yard to grow food for the table. Her half-acre in this community near Palo Alto looks like a California epiphany: a gorgeous array of colors, textures and decidedly unorthodox plantings.

LEAD: On a cluttered desk at the office of the Coalition for Traditional Values here, next to a bronze eagle, are photocopies of what the minister who heads the organization calls blasphemous and pornographic images and what some other people call art.
LEAD: Victor Wolfson, a dramatist, died in a fire at his home in Wellfleet, Mass., last Wednesday. A spokesman for the family said he was either 81 or 82 years old.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in Canada today, but it was the problems he left behind in Moscow, not those he came to discuss in summit meetings here and in Washington, that confronted him almost as soon as he set foot on Canadian soil.

LEAD: STRATEGIC ARMS REDUCTION TREATY - This treaty would make overall cuts of about 30 percent in the number of Soviet and American long-range nuclear arms. The agreement would lead to greater cuts in the number of warheads on Soviet ballistic missiles, deemed the most threatening by the United States because of their short flight time and accuracy.
LEAD: Because of Shabuoth, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended today and tomorrow.
LEAD: As the night unfolded below him, the owner of the Yankees sat and watched from a private box on the third level of Comiskey Park, his attention drawn to another unbearable Yankee loss.
LEAD: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it was looking for new partners in Teleport Communications Group, which operates municipal fiber-optic telephone networks for corporate customers.
LEAD: Derek C. Bok announced today that he would step down next spring as president of Harvard University, ending his 20-year tenure in perhaps the most prestigious post in American higher education.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: While members of the House of Representatives have voted to stop accepting speaking fees at the start of next year, many lawmakers are traveling around the world this year, collecting the maximum amounts permitted from corporations and other groups that have interests in legislation.

LEAD: Jonathan S. Linen, named yesterday, as expected, to oversee Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.'s brokerage and investment management divisions, said he was too new to the job to say how the securities firm might be rejuvenated. But imbued with the optimisim that came with his succcess as a top executive at the American Express Company, Mr.
LEAD: ANNE BOGART has resigned after less than a year as artistic director of the Trinity Repertory Company in Providence, R.I. The resignation was announced by JOHN HOWLAND, chairman of the board.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has decided to seek a ban on the investment of public funds in tobacco companies, a move that would make Massachusetts the first state to divest itself of tobacco stocks.

LEAD: ELLA FITZGERALD was named a Commander of Arts and Letters in Paris yesterday, France's top award for excellence in the arts. The bronze medal on a green-and-white striped ribbon was presented by the Culture Minister, JACK LANG. Miss Fitzgerald, 72 years old, is in Paris to give a concert this evening.
LEAD: IT walks like a budget duck, and it quacks like a budget duck. But should next year's outlay of $50 billion to $60 billion for the savings and loan bailout count as part of the Federal budget?
LEAD: Vincent Paletta spends much of his working day thinking of ways to steal tokens from subway turnstiles. But he is no criminal.
LEAD: The Great American Communications Company may sell some but not all of its 18 radio stations, its new president and chief operations officer said at the company's annual meeting last week.
LEAD: WHEN retailing sneezes, the nation's apparel industry reaches for its cold tablets.

LEAD: A Federal district judge today refused a request by Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. that he have two separate trials on 14 drug-related charges he faces, and he ordered a single trial to begin June 4.
LEAD: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from May 22 to 24 with a total of 1,140 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

LEAD: The race is on to develop the complete telecommunications ''mailbox.'' Telephone companies envision a day when customers will receive voice messages, text from computers and facsimile documents in their own private file in a telephone-company computer.

LEAD: Secondhand smoke, it becomes increasingly clear, endangers the second generation. But which generation is that? Yes, there's a strong link between smoking by parents and respiratory damage in their children. But in many families, it's now the young people who are most likely to smoke. That could be called visiting the sins of the children upon the fathers and mothers.

LEAD: The western edge of the continent has never been an ideal place for a highway, what with the pounding surf eroding the shore from below and the cliffs washing down from above. Repair crews of the state Department of Transportation face a Sisyphean labor keeping California Route 1 open under the best of circumstances.
LEAD: Boston University announced yesterday that Bob Brown, an alumnus whose coaching career spans 30 years, had been named head basketball coach.

LEAD: In six seasons as the most successful manager of his time, Davey Johnson gave the Mets the most precious of resources in the marketplace, the same thing that Gil Hodges gave them a generation earlier: credibility.
LEAD: Somewhere along the way, the Detroit Pistons decided to give up the bad-boy image that helped bring them the championship a year ago.
LEAD: A biotechnology company said today that it had developed a drug that helps break up the mucus that clogs the lungs of people with cystic fibrosis.

LEAD: IT will be almost a month before summer starts to ripen. In most parts of the country, tomatoes are still green and stern, herbs are pale and shy, the corn is low, and the charcoal bag is still at significant risk of being drenched by a late spring rain. But on Memorial Day, summer arrives in spirit, if not in fact.

LEAD: The racial diversity of Americans creates a lot of funny language problems, but you can't laugh about them, of course, because it's dangerous these days to laugh about anything that touches on our racial diversity. When the subject is race and somebody laughs, that somebody is inviting denunciation for ''insensitivity.

LEAD: FOR decades, Chicago's Northwest Side has included an enclave of German immigrants, so it is no surprise on just about any weekday afternoon to hear German spoken at the Lutz Continental Cafe and Pastry Shop.
LEAD: Hussein Onn, Prime Minister of Malaysia from 1976 to 1981, died at a California hospital after a second heart attack in six weeks. He was 68 years old.

LEAD: Ammirati & Puris said yesterday that it had completed its buyback from the Omnicom Group, which acquired the agency last year when it bought Ammirati's former parent, the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership. Ammirati had sold itself to Boase Massimi Pollitt in 1987.

LEAD: President Gorbachev looks to his meeting with President Bush to strengthen his position at home, demonstrating that the United States supports his efforts to promote reform in the Soviet Union and reduce conflicts abroad. Conscientiously, Mr. Bush can cooperate; most of Mr. Gorbachev's goals are America's goals too.
LEAD: ''SOME wine labels say that the wine contains sulfites; some don't. How do I find wine without sulfites?''

LEAD: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. yesterday named Richard Previte president and chief operating officer, and a member of its board. Mr. Previte, who was executive vice president and chief operating officer, joined Advanced Micro as chief financial officer in September 1969, four months after the company was founded.
LEAD: A Staten Island man was sentenced yesterday to 33 months in prison and fined $20,000 for harboring a fugitive in the killing of a Federal drug agent on Staten Island in February 1989.

LEAD: After two terms in the United States Senate and years of speculation about running for President sometime, Bill Bradley has gained extraordinary popularity in New Jersey, politicians of both parties say. But as he runs for re-election, he is showing a distinct strain of caution.

LEAD: An article on Monday about the growing number of old inmates in prisons referred incompletely in some copies to Dr. Julia G. Hall, who counsels elderly inmates at Graterford Prison in Pennsylvania. She is an associate professor of sociology at Drexel University.

LEAD: CHARLOTTE BRUNDAGE is on a cash machine line at 73d Street and Madison Avenue. The fellow in front of her, she can't help but notice, is pretty snazzy looking. He is on the far side of 40 - though not too far; his tan is golden; his blond hair curls over his shirt collar and, Ms. Brundage muses, it has been bleached by either the Beverly Hills or Mediterranean sun.
LEAD: A few hours before the 41st commencement at Marymount Manhattan College last night, the main speaker, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, canceled because he was suffering from the flu.

LEAD: SOME call them ''garden bones.'' Others prefer the term ''living furniture.'' Whatever their label, shrubs add structure and texture to the landscape. With the hues of forsythia and azalea now a memory, it is time to ponder some less commonly grown species that experts use to expand their own gardens' diversity.
LEAD: Detroit's tough, aggressive defense, featuring the hard fouls the Pistons are noted for, was back tonight. Missing for the Chicago Bulls were heroics by Michael Jordan.

LEAD: The Institute of Outdoor Advertising awarded Crowley Webb & Associates, Buffalo, the Best of Show Obie Award last night. The agency won for a billboard campaign for Garcia's Irish Pub that featured whimsical personal ads.
LEAD: For the third year in a row and the fourth time in five years, N.J. Transit is raising bus and train fares, this time an average of 9 percent.

LEAD: Barton L. Weller, an inventor and electronics company executive, died on Friday following a fall from a ladder as he inspected a home being built for him and his wife in Cape Breton, Nova Scotia. He was 74 years old and lived in Easton, Conn.

LEAD: ON a day, one of many recently, on which New York was supposed to have blown up and gone to hell, I sauntered forth for the first street fair of the season. At least it was the first street fair of the season in my neighborhood: I am pretty parochial about these events.

LEAD: Amid all the gale-force commencement wind, some members of the Class of '90 already know that they can make a living and make a difference. They are among the first volunteers in Teach for America, a program that, starting in September, will inject new teachers and new energy into American schools.

LEAD: Late-summer sun filtered through the elm trees and historical echoes. The bright flags of Harvard's 26 schools and houses fluttered. It was September 1986, the university's 350th anniversary celebration, and it was time for the closing address from the president of Harvard.

LEAD: After three weeks of negotiations, the John Jay College of Criminal Justice has decided to file disciplinary charges and seek a court order against students who have occupied a campus building since early this month.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The United States and Greece initialed an eight-year military cooperation agreement today insuring the continued operation of American military bases in Greece in exchange for military aid, the Greek Government announced.

LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev used to defy gravity: his power expanded while his policies failed. But no longer. His inability to block the election of Boris Yeltsin as president of the Russian Republic is only one of many setbacks. Political tension in the Soviet Union is, in fact, so high that the summit meeting this week could be the last one the hero of perestroika attends.

LEAD: After a heated clash, the United States and the European Community remained deadlocked today in talks to reduce subsidies in farm trade, raising fears that the stalemate would endanger the success of the current four-year round of world trade talks.
LEAD: General Assembly WORKING GROUP ON MIGRANT WORKERS CONVENTION - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in slow trading yesterday, as dealers began to position themselves for tomorrow's release of May employment data.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today reaffirmed Soviet opposition to a unified Germany being part of NATO. But after likening Western insistence on the matter to ''an old record'' and warning the West against sliding back into ''cold war'' attitudes, he suggested that the two sides may yet succeed in finding a compromise.
LEAD: The Chinese authorities have recently detained at least two democracy advocates, including one who spent a decade in prison for political beliefs, Chinese familiar with the cases say.
LEAD: William T. Overgard, an artist and novelist who drew the ''Steve Roper and Mike Nomad'' comic strip, died of a heart condition on Friday at his home in Stony Point, N.Y. He was 64 years old.
LEAD: Millicent Miller, who worked as Vivien Leigh's stand-in during the filming of ''Gone With the Wind,'' died on Tuesday. She was 81 years old.

LEAD: The Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld a ruling that blocks states from forcing securities brokers to give investors the option of suing, rather than seeking arbitration, to settle alleged broker fraud.
LEAD: In an operation that may open a new era in fetal medicine, doctors have performed lifesaving major surgery on a fetus and delivered a healthy baby seven weeks later.
LEAD: ''You have the same explosive mixture you had in Germany in the 1930's. The humiliation of a great power. Economic troubles. The rise of nationalism.
LEAD: Despite the similarities among Europeans that marketers are now trying to exploit, cultural differences must still be taken into consideration.
LEAD: Gerald Greenwald, vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation and heir apparent to Lee A. Iacocca, resigned today and is expected to become chief executive of UAL Inc., owner of United Airlines.

LEAD: In a ceremony shadowed by a recent incident of sexual harassment and allegations of physical abuse among classmates, the United States Naval Academy today graduated its 140th class of midshipmen, including the largest number of women ever.
LEAD: A strong earthquake killed at least 115 people, injured more than 800 and almost destroyed several towns in Peru's northern jungle, Civil Defense officials said today.
LEAD: Syrian troops raided militia offices and reinforced checkpoints today in an attempt to end a new wave of violence in mainly Muslim West Beirut.
LEAD: Gord Stellick, the assistant general manager of the Rangers last year, will not return next season, according to several people in the organization.

LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has ordered North Carolina State University to pay it $405,756, representing 90 percent of the school's net earnings from men's basketball tournaments during the two seasons in which Charles Shackleford, a former Wolfpack player, admitted accepting money in violation of collegiate rules.
LEAD: Richard Ravitch, who has run through several New York careers in public service, banking, construction, real estate and politics, is beginning a new one - Wall Street investment banker.
LEAD: The Rev. Robert B. Lepley, a United Church of Christ minister, had set out with the idealism of the uninitiated to serve in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

LEAD: Basic electric rates for Con Edison's 2.9 million customers in New York City and Westchester County will remain frozen for the next two years under an agreement announced yesterday by the utility and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

LEAD: Quakes on Two Continents At least 115 people were reported killed in an earthquake in northern Peru. Hours later, a tremor centered in Romania reportedly killed at least 8. Page A3. Running Short of Grain For the first time in years, the nation's wheat and corn reserves have fallen below the levels necessary to offset a severe drought.

LEAD: Stained Tiles Q.Our building is over 60 years old, and the tile on our bathroom floors is stained and has dried plaster on the surface. How can we restore the tile? A.If you want to make the tile look like new again, there isn't much you can do. You should be able to remove the dried plaster by scraping it off with a razor blade held almost flat against the surface, and you should be able to scrub most of the other stains off with a strong detergent.

LEAD: Although the new Chilean Government has agreed to pay compensation for the assassination of former Foreign Minister Orlando Letelier in Washington in 1976, efforts to reopen the criminal investigation of the case here continue to encounter roadblocks.
LEAD: Dwayne Gosso, call your parole officer.
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company plans to offer customer incentives instead of a discount to dealers this fall to spur sales at the end of the 1990 model year, the company said today.

LEAD: It could be a Hollywood script. A group of sheep ranchers, scratching out a livelihood in New Mexico's scenic but dirt-poor Chama Valley, want their flocks to graze on government lands. But state and Federal agencies, joined by an uncommon alliance of hunting and environmental groups, oppose the grazing as a threat to the land and the wildlife.
LEAD: For two months, they have glared at each other and occasionally bickered, the famous defense lawyer and the judge at Imelda Marcos's trial, on the edge of an all-out confrontation.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union arrived in Washington tonight for his third visit to the United States and his second summit conference with President Bush, as American officials searched for formulas to persuade him to accept Western plans for a unified Germany and a restructured Europe.
LEAD: ON Sunday, the third annual Hamilton Heights House Tour once again will offer an unexpected and invigorating glimpse into the lives of some of New York's most energetic homemakers.

LEAD: A rotunda book room that draws heavily on the Doric order stands at the heart of the British Interior Design Exhibition at Chelsea Old Town Hall here. The room has a perfectly proportioned rotunda, fluted columns, a floor design that echoes the dome above and painted panels showing ancient symbols of wisdom and enlightenment.
LEAD: Dimitri de Grunwald, the producer of ''The Millionairess,'' a 1960 film starring Peter Sellers and Sophia Loren, died Saturday at his home. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: Lucy Boston, a leading writer of children's fiction, died on Friday at her home, the Manor, a 12th-century Norman house at Hemingford Grey in Huntingdonshire, England, which provided the inspiration and setting for her influential ''Green Knowe'' books. She was 97 years old.
LEAD: Should the California mountain lion be protected from hound dogs and hunters? Should the state spend $30 million a year to buy and preserve habitat for lions, deer and other wildlife?
LEAD: State Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol declared New York City's school expulsion policy illegal in a ruling released today.

LEAD: A strong earthquake centered about 20 miles east of here killed at least eight people in Romania today and caused hundreds of injuries and property damage along an arc that spanned the Carpathian Mountains from Romania to parts of the Soviet Union and Bulgaria.
LEAD: Prosecutors have postponed the arraignment of two leaders of the radical environmental group Earth First who were arrested Friday after they were injured in the explosion of a pipe bomb.

LEAD: FIFTEEN years ago, when Ned Kellogg was 30 years old and working as a bass soloist, he started selling dollhouse kits, and then making dollhouses, for extra income. Today, he makes more than 3,000 styles, from a pagoda to a 20th-century Queen Anne Tudor.

LEAD: The Government index intended to predict the course of the economy eased two-tenths of 1 percent in April, largely reflecting the third straight decline in the number of permits for new buildings, the Commerce Department said today.
LEAD: Because of his immense talent, Clyde Drexler has grown accustomed to setting high standards for himself.
LEAD: * Herald Center to AC&R Advertising for its shopping mall in Herald Square in Manhattan.

LEAD: Along the border with Pakistan, there are many tales to tell of Punjabi villagers who risked their lives to help India provision its army for three wars between these two countries. The stories have a ring of nostalgia about them now.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Joseph E. Parisi, a State Senator from Brooklyn from 1945 to 1948, died on Tuesday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

LEAD: Several suspected leaders in four crime families were among 15 men indicted yesterday on Federal charges that they skimmed ''tens of millions'' of dollars through a conspiracy to control awarding of window contracts at the New York City Housing Authority.
LEAD: New York State Republicans nominated Pierre A. Rinfret as their gubernatorial candidate today, but the party's disarray continued to spread, this time over abortion.

LEAD: * Amersham International P.L.C., a British health-care and medical research group, said it would pay no more than $45.85 million for Media-Physics Inc., the radio-pharmaceuticals subsidiary of Hoffman-La Roche Inc., instead of the previously agreed $61 million.

LEAD: It is hard to imagine a more quaint setting for an international soccer match. The Sportpark lies nestled alongside the Central Alps and not far from the Rhine and has a seating capacity for no more than 200, Others must stand around a waist-high railing that rings the field.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The 1992 Democratic National Convention will probably be held in New York City, party officials said today.
LEAD: Remembering:

LEAD: It was children'sday at the French Open, a noisy tradition that liberated 8,000 students from the classroom and let them loose to prowl Roland Garros where they howled for their favorites - Michael Chang and the neon-hued Andre Agassi - and hissed at their hero's opponents.

LEAD: Midnight Oil yesterday added a New York show to its three-night stand at Radio City Music Hall - a lunchtime mini-concert on the Avenue of the Americas facing the Exxon Building. Playing in front of a banner reading, ''Midnight Oil Makes You Dance, Exxon Oil Makes Us Sick,'' the Australian band played songs about pollution, exploitation of workers and general defiance; the opener declared, ''Your dream world is about to end.
LEAD: Esther V. Foley, the director of the women's athletic program at New York University from 1951 to 1971, died on Monday at her home in Katonah, N.Y., after a long illness. She was 85 years old.

LEAD: Children are getting involved in competitive sports at ever younger ages. A talent for sports like gymnastics, tennis, skating and dancing is sometimes detected in preschoolers, who may then be pressured by parents and trainers to spend childhood preparing for possible greatness.
LEAD: At first glance, the obscure divorce case the Supreme Court decided this week might have fit more comfortably on daytime television than on the Court's docket.

LEAD: The Battery Maritime Building, on Whitehall Street near the Staten Island Ferry, is to become the home of Dance Theater Workshop and Creative Time in 1995, after the building is renovated. Until then the two companies will present occasional performances and temporary exhibitions there.

LEAD: The Soviet Union's pre-eminent glasnost journalist, VITALY A. KOROTICH, is one of 14 Gannett Center Fellows for 1990-91. He is the editor of the newsweekly Ogonyok and a member of the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies. Fellows work on individual projects at the Gannett Center for Media Studies at Columbia University.

LEAD: THE radio call-in show is a national institution, wellspring of lively political debates and Dr. Ruth. This week a new program will examine different sorts of burning issues in the American psyche - like how aluminum siding compares with vinyl.

LEAD: Despite the nearness in time of the quakes that struck Peru and Romania late Tuesday and early yesterday, one earthquake rarely, if ever, touches off a quake in some other part of the globe, according to Lynne Sykes, an earthquake specialist at Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory.

LEAD: BEYOND the flush of elation shown by victors in takeover auctions are other investors whose entrepreneurial ambitions were doomed because of tenuous financial backing. Lately, company managements attempting leveraged buyouts seem especially prone to this fate.

LEAD: ''What's your favorite 'I Love Lucy?' '' someone asked, for reasons now long forgotten, at a college party in the 1970's. Instantly the room was flooded with answers: ''Lucy meets Harpo Marx,'' ''Lucy stomps the grapes'' or ''Lucy and Ethel in the chocolate factory.'' Everyone could conjure mental images to match episodes more familiar to this generation than Mother Goose rhymes.

LEAD: Frank Lloyd Wright was a charter member of the Cliff Dwellers Club, overlooking Lake Michigan's long horizon. George Ade, the humorist, was a patron and member too, and so were the poets Carl Sandburg and James Whitcomb Riley.
LEAD: Fremont C. Peck, publisher of The Brooklyn Daily Times and The Brooklyn Times-Union in the 1920's and 1930's, died on Tuesday at his home in Locust Valley, L.I. He was 92 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: In his first day as President of the Russian republic, Boris N. Yeltsin put the Kremlin on notice today with an aggressive program to free Russia from ''the dictates of the center.''

LEAD: All panhandlers, including people who are silently extending a cup, would be ejected from the subway system under stringent guidelines announced yesterday by the new chief of the New York City transit police.
LEAD: President Gorbachev plans to meet President Roh Tae Woo in San Francisco, the first such meeting between the countries, which have been adversaries for 40 years. Page A14.

LEAD: LOW-VOLTAGE outdoor lighting is an easy, safe, efficient and inexpensive way to light a yard or terrace - not brilliantly, but enough for nighttime entertaining or extra security. No knowledge of electricity is needed, and kits with all the necessary components and instructions are available at hardware stores, home and garden centers and discount department stores.

LEAD: The Mets do not have a Joe Morgan at the helm, but they wouldn't mind a variation of the ''Morgan Magic'' he brought to the Boston Red Sox in 1988. Nor do they have Cito Gaston, who took over an underachieving Toronto Blue Jays team last season and led it to a division championship.

LEAD: The Louisiana House of Representatives has passed a bill sponsored by David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, to weaken affirmative-action efforts.

LEAD: Frank Robinson, the manager of the Baltimore Orioles, was suspended for three games yesterday as a result of an argument Monday with Drew Coble, an umpire whom Robinson later called a liar and ''a no-good human being.''
LEAD: Baseball
LEAD: Dave Gavitt, architect of the Big East Conference and the leader of amateur basketball in the United States, was named today as the director of basketball operations for the Boston Celtics.

LEAD: RHETT eats only high-protein food, and never considers leftovers. Every week, he visits a salon for a long, soothing bath and to have his hair done. To stay fit, he frolics in a glass-enclosed, air-conditioned exercise area in his roomy Atlanta home. Alternate weekends, he hops into the Jeep and zooms to a mountain cabin in Cashiers, N.C.

LEAD: At the summit meeting, President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will sign a new shipping agreement that will open up 42 ports in each country to ships flying the other nation's flag, restoring widespread ocean traffic between the two countries for the first time since 1981.
LEAD: Wolcott Andrews, a retired New York City landscape architect, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at Miles Memorial Hospital in Damariscotta, Me. He was 87 years old and lived in Wiscasset, Me.

LEAD: Like Juliet playing the balcony scene yet again, Dame Margot Fonteyn sat in the royal box of the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden tonight as the tenor Placido Domingo, a not unlikely Romeo, opened the Royal Ballet's special tribute to her with a serenade.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Four years ago the State of Washington, prodded by its biggest public employee union, struck a celebrated blow for women when it began a program intended to raise the pay for government jobs typically considered women's work.
LEAD: Efforts by large banks to expand into the insurance business were rewarded yesterday as Delaware enacted laws allowing banks in the state to sell insurance nationwide.

LEAD: Born 100 years ago, the Russian poet, novelist and translator Boris Pasternak died in 1960, two years after he was forced by the Khrushchev Government to refuse the Nobel Prize for literature. ''Doctor Zhivago,'' which first appeared in the West in 1957, was finally allowed to be published in the Soviet Union in 1988.
LEAD: The Belzberg family today sold its entire 11.7 percent stake in Armstrong World Industries, according to a family spokesman.

LEAD: Pierre A. Rinfret, the New York City economist who received the Republican nomination for governor today, is so politically anonymous that his name has been spelled phonetically (Rin-FRAY) in party news releases.
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins announced a series of measures yesterday intended to speed up the arrest-to-arraignment process.

LEAD: The single market of 325 million consumers that the 12 nations of the European Community are trying to create is at least two and a half years away, but consumer-products companies are acting as if it were already here.
LEAD: The Nicaraguan rebels agreed today to resume disbanding after the new Government promised to set aside rural areas where they can live, police themselves and join town councils.
LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday announced a series of products and a set of business partnerships aimed at the expanding market for computerized-forms processing.

LEAD: ''A Quiet End,'' Robin Swados's drama of three gay men suffering through the final stages of AIDS, is suffused with an anguished tenderness toward its characters. Unlike other recent plays dealing with the impact of AIDS on homosexual life in New York, it eschews the history and politics of the epidemic to explore at some depth the inner lives of desperately ill men from varying backgrounds.
LEAD: The Burden of Proof By Scott Turow 515 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins has chosen his remaining six appointees to the City Planning Commission, rounding out the new 13-member panel that will review major public and private building projects beginning on July 1.

LEAD: Barely a week after declaring it was ''out of business,'' Mayor David Dinkins has found money to save the ''clean team'' that sweeps and empties litter baskets on New York City's busiest streets.
LEAD: rrIn this Age of Steinbrenner, sacking the manager is so often a frivolous or cruel maneuver that it is refreshing to see a baseball club slow to push the button.

LEAD: Long esteemed on Wall Street as a scrappy little airline that thrived in a business dominated by Goliaths, Midway Airlines Inc. now finds itself in a brutal competitive struggle that has dealt the carrier heavy losses. The outcome, industry experts agree, will be decisive: Either Midway will become a larger and more profitable airline or a badly wounded also-ran.

LEAD: The night was sort of methodical. The Yankees played, lost, packed and left for home, taking with them a five-game losing streak after another disheartening road trip. There are changes coming, but even though it is only May, they may be too late.

LEAD: Jamie Quirk drove in two runs with a double and a triple in only his second start of the season today as the Oakland Athletics defeated the Blue Jays, 8-5, ending Toronto's streak of five consecutive victories.

LEAD: Florence Jessie MacWilliams, a mathematician and a developer of the digital coding used in computers and telecommunications, died of an embolism on Sunday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived in Bernardsville, N.J.
LEAD: Reflecting the growing sensitivity over ethics and the appearance of impropriety, 19 senators refused to accept speaking fees from outside groups in 1989, seven more than the year before.
LEAD: Borden Inc. yesterday named Anthony S. D'Amato as president and chief operating officer, making him the likely next leader of the $7.6 billion company.

LEAD: A seven-year legal battle between two highly successful jeans companies, Guess and Jordache, and the families that run them ended today when the sides reached an out-of-court settlement returning all of Guess to its founders.
LEAD: The list of credits with a television review on Friday about ''Twin Peaks'' reversed two names. Ed Hurley is the character played by Everett McGill.

LEAD: For the first time in years, the nation's wheat and corn reserves have fallen below the levels necessary to offset a severe drought or some other damage to this year's grain crop. The dwindling reserves help to reduce the budget deficit by shrinking farm subsidies, but they leave the nation vulnerable to food price inflation.

LEAD: THREE years ago Eva Thompson, a toy dealer in Dallas, decided it was time to have a convention devoted to G.I. Joe, the dress-up action doll for boys, which Hasbro Inc. introduced in 1964. LEAD: As expected, directors of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday elected Paul E. Lego, a soft-spoken, deliberate career engineer, as chairman and chief executive, effective July 1.

LEAD: The launching of the space shuttle Columbia was delayed at least until early next week, and possibly for weeks, as engineers here worked round the clock today to pinpoint the site of the fuel leak that abruptly halted the countdown on Tuesday.

LEAD: In June, house tour devotees have a choice of visiting historic house museums scattered in the city's five boroughs, Victorian brownstones in Brooklyn, a mansion in Yonkers and 19th-century houses in Roslyn, L.I. There are also a garden tour and a show house in Connecticut.

LEAD: When the 18-day New York International Festival of Lesbian and Gay Film opens tonight at the Biograph Theater, it is expected to be the largest event of its kind yet held in the United States. Over the next three and a half weeks the festival will have 92 shows and 108 films and videos from around the world.

LEAD: Men who have male pattern baldness, with a receding hairline and hair loss at the crown of the head, may also develop higher cholesterol levels and higher blood pressure as they age than men who have more hair, research suggests.

LEAD: Jane Breed Fleming, the founder of Neighbor to Neighbor, a volunteer social-service organization in Greenwich, Conn., died of renal cancer on Tuesday at her home in Greenwich. She was 56 years old.

LEAD: Stock prices edged slightly higher yesterday amid active program trading. Both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index eked out new highs with strong leadership from I.B.M., Procter & Gamble and Walt Disney.

LEAD: The Honda Motor Company said it would nearly double the size of its research and development operations in Marysville, Ohio. The Japanese auto maker said the expansion would provide additional capacity to design and develop new vehicles for the North American market.
LEAD: The 614 delegates to the annual convention of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) elected a layman today to lead the 2.9-million-member denomination for the next year.

LEAD: On the day after he was dismissed, Davey Johnson said that he expected to return to the big leagues, perhaps even this season, and he did not rule out the possibility that he might surface in New York someday in the pinstripes of the Yankees.

LEAD: Though no relation to the long-retired Charles Goren, Joel Goren of Manhattan, returned the name to prominence this weekend by helping defeat the top-seeded squad in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship.

LEAD: WHILE some people were unable to meet the $78.1 million auction price for Pierre Auguste Renoir's ''Au Moulin de la Galette'' a few weeks ago, they can still hang the painting in their living rooms: The Ethan Allen art collection sells a reproduction of it for $885.

LEAD: The Kemper Corporation announced today that a restructuring of its troubled regional brokerage operations would result in a $126.5 million charge against second-quarter earnings. The company plans to reduce the number of its brokerage firm employees by more than 600, or about 12 percent of its work force of 5,200, by the end of the year.

In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Wall to Wall blamed increased costs, expansion expenses, inventory adjustments and disappointing sales for its loss.

LEAD: RISING stock prices and declining interest rates are propelling cash into stock and bond mutual funds at rising rates, setting records for some companies, fund managers say.
LEAD: HONG KONG glows with neon signs that dangle in front of stores and perch on top of roofs, advertising restaurants, hotels and tailors.

LEAD: A performance by the Feld Ballet will open the new season on Oct. 6 at 8 P.M. at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts at Lehman College, Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue, the Bronx.

LEAD: MARTIN FORD was fooled by his 4-year-old son. Every day Dr. Ford or his wife would methodically dress their child, guiding his small arms through shirtsleeves, snapping the snaps and buttoning the buttons. One day he walked into his son's room to discover that the boy had put on all his clothes by himself.

LEAD: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, appointed Zoe Baird vice president and general counsel. She replaces Stephen B. Middlebrook, who was named senior vice president and executive counsel to the office of the chairman.

LEAD: Since 1947, scientists have reckoned the ages of many old objects by measuring the amounts of radioactive carbon they contain. New research shows, however, that some estimates based on carbon may have erred by thousands of years.

LEAD: Prosecutors asked today for dismissal of charges of drug possession, explosives possession and sexual assault against Hunter S. Thompson, saying their case against the journalist and author was not strong enough.
LEAD: Four children, from 3 1/2 to 11 years old, were found stabbed to death in their apartment here today, the police said.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Edward Louie, creator of the fortune cookie folding machine and a line of risque fortune cookies, died on Friday shortly after returning from a visit to his ancestral village in China. He was 69 years old.

LEAD: Israeli forces foiled an attack this morning by Palestinian guerrillas in speedboats on the beaches around this city, killing 4 and capturing 12 of the raiders, the Israeli military said. There were no Israeli military or civilian casualties.

LEAD: After allegations of ''celebrity routing,'' the staff of a Federal regulatory agency has recommended moving the path of a proposed natural-gas pipeline back onto property owned by Dr. Joyce Brothers, the psychologist, and Arnold Fisher, a Manhattan real-estate executive.

LEAD: An article yesterday about Derek Bok's plan to leave the presidency of Harvard misstated the number of the university's presidents who were not graduates of Harvard College. Mr. Bok was the third; the others were Harvard's first two presidents, Henry Dunster and Charles Chauncy.
LEAD: The chess game of prime-time television scheduling reached a new level of intricacy in the last 2 weeks as 4 networks announced 33 new programs for next September.
LEAD: The first campaign for the TDK Corporation's audio tapes from its new agency, HDM New York, looks a bit like the old campaign for Krazy Glue.
LEAD: Rick Aguilera, a Minnesota Twins pitcher, has signed a three-year, $6 million contract extension, which will make him the third-highest-paid player on the team next season.

LEAD: In a major step toward improving relations with South Korea, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has agreed to meet with President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea during his visit to the United States, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Ending a three-day summit meeting here, Arab leaders today denounced Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel as a grave threat to their security and condemned what they called United States support for Israel's policies of ''aggression, terrorism and expansionism.''
LEAD: Four years after it was completed and 14 years after construction began, the Seabrook nuclear power plant has supplied electricity to customers for the first time.
LEAD: A Pennsylvania court ruled yesterday that services that identify the telephone numbers of callers represent an illegal invasion of privacy.

Gorbachev's Soviet Union and Germany after World War I. Once again, they say, a great power's ambitions for world influence lie in tatters.

LEAD: Liberian Government soldiers were reported today to have entered a United Nations compound here and abducted about 40 refugees who had taken shelter there in the face of a continuing advance by rebels toward this nervous capital.

LEAD: Taiichi Ohno, a self-taught engineer who developed the manufacturing system that helped make the Toyota Motor Company one of the most powerful automobile producers in the world, died of heart failure on Monday in Toyota City, Japan. He was 78 years old.
LEAD: The California Angels said yesterday that they had filed complaints against George Steinbrenner over the Yankee owner's comments after the trade of Dave Winfield.

LEAD: Gov. Jim Florio's plan for a major redistribution of state spending for New Jersey's public schools drew sharp opposition today from a key State Senator and statewide representatives of local school boards and teachers.

LEAD: The state-run railroad, recently hit by a crippling strike, will double passenger fares on Friday, the official news agency reported. The increases were planned before the labor strife broke out May 20, a railroad spokesman said today.

LEAD: A Bronx youth was arrested yesterday and charged in the robbery of a Long Island cabdriver who was stabbed eight times and beaten with a submachine gun in the Bronx on Monday night. Christopher Perez, 16 years old, of 870 Morris Park Avenue, was charged with robbery, assault and possession of a weapon.
LEAD: Yields on taxable and tax-exempt money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were narrowly mixed for the week ended yesterday.
LEAD: A Federal grand jury has indicted a flower grower and seven other people on charges of enslaving more than 100 undocumented workers from Mexicobeating them if they tried to escape.
LEAD: Arkansas Republicans have chosen a prominent Little Rock lawyer and businessman to challenge Gov. Bill Clinton this November in his bid for a fifth term.
LEAD: In the Prague Castle, where the sun had lit up the large carpets and golden curlicues on the walls, an official was saying the President's offices at last seemed to be free of electronic bugs.
LEAD: Patrik Boden is a 22-year-old Texas sophomore from Sweden trying to survive a season of highs and lows.
LEAD: Cesar Gaviria Trujillo's victory in Colombia's presidential election sends a brave message to the drug cartels, and to Washington.

LEAD: ALLEN GINSBERG and MILES DAVIS are among the 22 recipients of the 11th annual American Book Awards, announced yesterday in Miami. The winners are chosen by the Before Columbus Foundation for their ''contributions to literary excellence in America,'' a foundation spokesman said.
LEAD: A surprise winner in Colombia's elections on Sunday was a guerrilla group that only two months ago traded in its guns for the ballot box.

LEAD: An 18-year-old man was shot in the head and killed yesterday morning at 152-51 Jewel Avenue in Hillcrest, Queens, the police said. The victim was not identified, but the police arrested a 14-year-old, Henry Moy, of 51-24 97th Street in Elmhurst, Queens, and charged him with second-degree murder and criminal possession of a weapon.

LEAD: Michel Bergeron, who coached the Quebec Nordiques to the National Hockey League's worst record last season, will be replaced by Dave Chambers, the former Minnesota North Stars assistant coach, radio station CJRP of Quebec reported yesterday.(AP)

The man, Jose Rafael Abello Silva. was convicted May 19 on one count of conspiracy to import cocaine and marijuana into the United States and one count of conspiracy to possess drugs with the intent to distribute.

LEAD: The Merrill Lynch Asset-Backed Corporation 1990-1 yesterday priced $622 million in debt securities due in 1995 that are backed by Chrysler Credit Corporation car loans.

LEAD: The Francis Bacon exhibition that opens Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art comprises 59 paintings. Most of them are large, and some are made up of two or three canvases, each measuring 78 by 58 inches. They cover the years from 1945 to 1988. (Bacon was 80 years old last October.) Many of the images in the show acquired classic status long ago and have been regarded by enthusiasts as central to the concerns of our day.

LEAD: GOLF Two Share Kemper Lead Pat McGowan, striving for his first victory in 13 years on the PGA Tour, shot a bogey-free six-under-par 65 in the Kemper Open yesterday at Potomac, Md., to share the first-round lead with Ted Schulz. LEAD: The Republican Party completed its statewide ticket today but remained so divided on the abortion issue that some local leaders said publicly that they would not support the candidate for governor, Pierre A. Rinfret.

LEAD: Brownstone and limestone houses built in the 19th and early 20th centuries are featured in a house tour on Sunday in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Prospect-Lefferts Gardens. The tour, the 21st sponsored by the neighborhood association, will run from noon to 5 P.M. Tickets - $7 in advance, $8 on the day - are on sale at the association's office, 575 Flatbush Avenue, between Midwood and Maple Streets.
LEAD: When a teen-age burglar tried to flee through the front door of a house recently, the owner of the house shot him in the back of the head, killing him.
