LEAD: A failed coup attempt against President Kenneth D. Kaunda early this morning appears to have further weakened his political standing, already shaky after three days of rioting.

LEAD: This year marks the hundredth anniversary of the Dodgers' first season in the National League. I'm observing the occasion by forgiving the late Dodgers owner, Walter O'Malley, for moving the team from Brooklyn to Los Angeles in 1958. Don't laugh; this represents a big step in my life.

LEAD: In the obscure corners of the game of bridge can be found some colorful terms. The geographer can find the Chinese finesse, the Curse of Scotland and the Alcatraz Coup. The historian uncovers Byzantine Blackwood, the Morton's Fork Coup, the Duke of Cumberland's Hand and the Merrimac Coup.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Christina Morris Blossom, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John McLean Morris of Woodbridge, Conn., was married to Peter Dana Raymond, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dana M. Raymond of New York. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.
LEAD: Royal Thomas Guernsey 3d, a partner in Chez Panisse, the highly successful restaurant in Berkeley, Calif., died of AIDS last Friday at his home in Berkeley. He was 42 years old.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

LEAD: ''Ferris Bueller,'' a new NBC situation comedy based on the theatrical movie, has a most unusual opening scene. Charlie Schlatter, the young actor cast as the teen-age hero Ferris, walks over to his closet and removes a life-size cardboard likeness of the actor Matthew Broderick, who played Ferris in the 1986 movie.

LEAD: VIRTUALLY every homeowner who makes regular mortgage payments is charged a monthly amount that covers not only principal and interest but also the cost of real estate taxes and homeowner insurance.

LEAD: Bob Welch became the first 13-game winner in the major leagues and Dave Henderson hit two two-run doubles as the Oakland Athletics beat Toronto, 9-4, today. The loss was the sixth in a row for the Blue Jays.
LEAD: Time Warner Inc. has sued the Pathe Communications Corporation for $100 million in a dispute arising from Pathe's attempt to buy the MGM/UA Communications Company.

LEAD: Golf Johnston Leads by 4: Cathy Johnston shot a 70 yesterday and held a lead of four shots over Patti Rizzo and Patty Sheehan after three rounds of the du Maurier Classic championship at Kitchener, Ontario. Johnston, 26 years old, was at 14-under-par 205 in the second of the Ladies Professional Golf
LEAD: Rory Sparrow learned from a stranger that the Miami Heat had traded him to the Sacramento Kings.
LEAD: Guadeloupe To the Editor: We were so happy to wake up to discover the smiling face of Chef Gerard Virginius (Travel, April 22).

LEAD: Your article on the future of ''Today'' includes an assessment of Deborah Norville's performance by an NBC executive who is quoted as saying, ''She just doesn't get it.'' However, I believe it is the network executive who ''doesn't get it.'' The article points out that the show is losing a portion of the audience that advertisers are anxious to keep, namely younger women.

LEAD: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Bonnie Hope Rattner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Rattner of Wheatley Heights, L.I., was married last evening to Robert Alan Klugman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Klugman of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Jack Bemporad officiated. Mrs. Klugman, 25 years old, graduated from Cornell University and the Benjamin N.

LEAD: As a longtime (and now former) ''Today'' show watcher, I can only agree with the conclusions drawn in your profile of host Bryant Gumbel. His competence has never been in question. But as long as his abilities continue to be overshadowed by his outsized ego, loyal viewers and distinguished colleagues alike will continue to drift away.

LEAD: THREE years ago, during the real estate boom, a professional couple in their 30's sold their ''starter'' house, a small two-bedroom in Harrison, for $150,000. By stretching their budget to the limits, they bought a three-bedroom split level in Rye for $295,000.
LEAD: Nostalgia's superstars took their places today for what promises to be a classic finish Sunday at the 11th United States Senior Open.

LEAD: Q. Our kitchen cabinets are covered with a walnut-tone plastic laminate that we dislike. We would like to paint over it, and were wondering what kind of paint to use. If we do not like the paint after it is applied, will this make it more difficult to remove the old laminate later on if we decide to replace it?

LEAD: Amanda Louise Crandall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Crandall of Boulder, Colo., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Robert Anthony DeMar 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. DeMar Jr. of Lincolnville, Me. The Rev. Cynthia Jarvis officiated at the Nassau Presbyterian Church.
LEAD: The Avenue of the Americas will be closed today from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. from 35th to 50th Streets for the Avenue of the Americas Festival.

LEAD: President Bush's decision last week to limit offshore drilling demonstrates that hardly any politician can risk being seen as anti-environmental. The reason for this is the growth of the environmental consciousness among the American people.

LEAD: WHAT will ultimately seal the fate of the 1857 St. Monica's Church in Jamaica, Queens, is not the decline of the area after World War II, the congregation that left it in 1973, the vandals that have damaged it or even the conflicting city-state jurisdictions that short-circuit its landmark designation.

LEAD: It looks like a space ship and its job is to snoop. The RPV Cypher (above) was designed by the Sikorsky helicopter subsidiary of the United Technologies Corporation to be a pilotless surveillance drone. About six feet in diameter and weighing 300 pounds, the vehicle can take off and land vertically and hover over targets.

LEAD: A weary Nelson Mandela ended a grueling eight-city American tour today, transformed into a popular hero hailed by millions who a few months ago were probably giving scant attention to apartheid in South Africa.
LEAD: It has been decades since most city residents had milk delivered to their homes and longer still since milkmen used horse-drawn wagons.

LEAD: Edward A. Spitz, founder of Guest Informant, a directory of tourist information distributed in 1,400 hotels across the country, died June 23 at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 88 years old and lived in Los Angeles and San Francisco.

LEAD: Got any old bourbon bottles around the house? Empty cigarette packs? Cheap perfume bottles? Any junk left over from the 50's and 60's? Throw it out, quick. Otherwise somebody is likely to convince you that the detritus of popular culture from these two decades is worth saving, worth cataloguing, worth - I hate even to use the word - collecting.

LEAD: Laura Ann Clark, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Clark of Milford, Conn., was married yesterday in Albany to Nicholas Bayard Hamersley, a son of L. Gordon Hamersley Jr. of Southhampton, L.I., and the late Elsey Van Kleeck Hamersley. The Rev. Andrew C. Hamersley, the bridegroom's brother, officiated at St.

LEAD: Travel in a European sleeping car on a train with restaurant service has its own special mystique. A good meal, a bit of fantasy, and a new city to explore in the morning; such are the rewards still to be found. Here is a series of rides enjoyed this past January. Sassnitz Express Stockholm to West

LEAD: After all the wrangling and wangling, the agreement on New York City's $28 billion budget that is to start today came down to twin prerogatives: $40 million in modest new service initiatives for Mayor David N. Dinkins and $40 million in other services saved from cuts by the City Council.

LEAD: Liberty State Park, with its rows of American flags fluttering in the wind, has something very special to offer: an unrivaled view of lower Manhattan. The vista of New York Harbor includes Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, which stands a mere 1,750 feet away and seems close enough to touch.

LEAD: NASA had a calamitous week. First it discovered a fundamental flaw in the Hubble space telescope. Then it had to ground its space shuttle fleet after a second shuttle sprang a mysterious hydrogen leak in pre-launch tests. These events are a setback for astronomy, a warning for other big science projects and their backers in Congress and the White House, and an untimely black mark for the space agency.
LEAD: NEW police officers in Ridgefield will get their initial handgun training in a classroom rather than at a target range.

LEAD: Tax revenue increases. With those three words, President Bush last week ushered in feverish budget negotiations. Proposals that were taboo on Monday - like taxes on Social Security benefits or cuts in Medicare - suddenly became possible on Tuesday. Swinging into action, Congressional leaders promised to cut next year's budget deficit by $55 billion or more.

LEAD: Andrea Clem Krahmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Johannes R. Krahmer of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to David McNeill Cross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. A. Cross of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Jon Walton performed the ceremony at Westminster Presbyterian Church.

LEAD: Jane Lauren Sarkin, the daughter of Elaine S. Zheutlin of Hillside, N.J., and the late Dr. Stanley K. Sarkin, was married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Elizabeth, N.J., to Martin Bradley O'Connor 2d, a son of Mary Louise O'Connor of Elizabeth and the late Judge Richard R.

LEAD: Barbara Lynn Goldberg, a reporter for United Press International in New York, and Mark Xavier Mooney, a reporter for The New York Post, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents in Washington, Conn. Maurice Goldstein, a justice of the peace in New Milford, Conn., officiated.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The currencies and economies of the two Germanys become one today, solidifying the German role as leader of a bloc of European states that are themselves rushing toward economic union and a closer political federation. And next week, the leaders of the seven strongest industrial democracies - the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada - gather in Houston for an economic summit meeting to survey the problems and opportunities of a world changed in subtle and not-so-subtle ways.
LEAD: THIS year marks the 10th anniversary of the adoption of the policy requiring family life education in the New Jersey public schools.

LEAD: Within the next few weeks, Porsche is expected to decide whether to continue its Indy-car program next year. Last week, Derrick Walker, the team's general manager, put very little gilding on his prognosis for 1991.
LEAD: Justice Thaddeus E. Owens yesterday testily explained for the ninth time the legal definition of riot to the jury deliberating the fate of the Bensonhurst defendant John S. Vento.

LEAD: Stacey Gillis, the daughter of Robert Gillis of Lake Wylie, S.C., and Acapulco, Mexico, and Mrs. Stanley Grey of Atlanta, was married last evening to Jeffrey Andrew Weber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Weber of New York. Rabbi Richard K. Rocklin performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Charlotte, N

LEAD: Maura Jane O'Shea, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene K. O'Shea of Bedford Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Matthew John Devey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Devey of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Albertine officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Katonah. Mrs. Devey, 24 years old, graduated magna cum laude from Catholic University.

LEAD: Jane Elizabeth Nusbaum, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Nusbaum of Buffalo, was married there last evening at the Kleinhans Music Hall to Richard Mark Feller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Feller of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Steven Mason officiated.

LEAD: Carolyn Manchester Baker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Baker of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Bristol, R.I., to Douglas Clark Dorsey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Dorsey of Irvington, Va. The Rev. Anne B. Kimball performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: More than four years have passed since the developer Donald Trump unleashed upon the world his first plan for ''Television City,'' a huge development that would put 7,600 apartments, one of the region's largest shopping malls, and the world's tallest building on the site of the former Penn Central rail yards between 59th and 72d Streets on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

LEAD: The hearing Commissioner Fay Vincent will oversee Thursday on baseball's investigation of George Steinbrenner will be based largely on guidelines set last year by A. Bartlett Giamatti for his planned hearing on Pete Rose's gambling activities.

LEAD: For the second time, the Chancellor of the University of California at Los Angeles has scaled back the university's most ambitious long-range development plan in the face of pressure from community advocates and local politicians.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Catherine Ruth Carver and Robert Cuyler McCurrach were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va., by the Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger. Anne Swartz was the maid of honor, and the bridegroom's father was the best man.
LEAD: The Practical Traveler column on June 17 about maps misstated the address for the 14th Street-Union Square business improvement association. It is at 124 East 15th Street, New York, N.Y. 10003.

LEAD: Seven runs should have been enough tonight, but remember, this is the Yankees. In their season of misfortune, they have never done anything easily. And so, after taking a 7-0 lead in the third inning, they went through a typical struggle.

LEAD: THE Charles Ives Center for the Arts in Danbury is ready to open its summer season, on Saturday, with pops and fireworks. The former will be provided by Skitch Henderson and the Ives Symphony Orchestra; the latter will light the skies over the campus of Western Connecticut State University.
LEAD: Robert T. Weltchek, a former municipal judge and mayor of Springfield Township, N.J., died on Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: THE READING CRISIS Why Poor Children Fall Behind. By Jeanne S. Chall, Vicki A. Jacobs and Luke E. Baldwin. 191 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25. EARLY LITERACY By Joan Brooks McLane and Gillian Dowley McNamee. Illustrated. 161 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press.

LEAD: WOODY ALLEN: New Yorker. By Graham McCann. (Polity/Basil Blackwell, $24.95.) Like all great clowns, Allen Stewart Konigsberg wants to be taken seriously, and Graham McCann has granted his wish. In ''Woody Allen: New Yorker,'' the comic invention known as Woody Allen is scrupulously analyzed for what it may reveal about the cosmic tensions of our age.

LEAD: A performer who was to receive a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts said today that she would turn it down because the agency had rejected 4 of 18 grants recommended by its theater peer panel.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A new trade agreement promises to bring Japan some of the greatest products of American culture: wide-open, overbuilt roads, discount shopping and maybe even some American merchandise. Thursday's agreement commits the Japanese to vastly increase their spending on public works, revamp their retailing system and prosecute monopolistic abuses.

LEAD: In mid-June the Eastman Kodak Company introduced a new line of 35-millimeter cameras, featuring compact size, soft-edged styling and easy-to-use controls. But what may be the cameras' most unusual selling point is their instruction books.

LEAD: Tward the end of John Guare's new play, ''Six Degrees of Separation,'' a young man named Rick takes center stage to describe the horrors that have befallen him in New York City. Rick, played by Paul McCrane, is a struggling actor who had hit town from Utah with visions of stardom. But now his eyes fight back tears, his mouth weakens with revulsion.

LEAD: Putdowns of Sonic Youth were being sharpened long before the band's new album, ''Goo'' (DGC/Warner Brothers 24297; all three formats), turned up in record stores. The obvious prejudgment was that Sonic Youth, after a prolific and lauded career on independent labels, was selling out - going pop - because it had moved to a major label, David Geffen's DGC, thus turning its back on all that was feisty and scruffy and true.
LEAD: IT'S THE LEAST WE COULD DO. AFTER ALL , their guy discovered us.

LEAD: Mokoto Namba, a champion yachtsman from Japan, went into the Liberty Cup Regatta this weekend more determined to win than ever. Not only did he have a losing streak in the New York race to improve upon, but also a new and bright yacht-racing image to uphold.

LEAD: What could be more appropriate than for a famous grandmaster to celebrate his 80th birthday with a party in the form of a tournament? That is what Miguel Najdorf did on April 15 in Buenos Aires and it may well have been the first time in his chess career that he appeared as the impresario rather than as a player.

LEAD: ONCE a gracious avenue of low-profile, high-end stores in limestone-clad buildings, the Near North Side sector of Michigan Avenue - known as the Magnificent Mile - has been transformed over the last 15 years by huge mixed-use developments.

LEAD: Mina Gary Ryan, a daughter of Mina H. Ryan and John M. Ryan, both of Norfolk, Va., was married there yesterday to Rocco A. Laterzo 2d, a son of Mrs. and Mrs. Laterzo Sr. of Sherborn, Mass. Bishop A. Heath Light of the Diocese of Southwestern Virginia performed the ceremony at Christ and St. Luke's Episcopal

LEAD: The United States can improve its soccer team for 1994 by declaring a state of war and drafting all exceptionally talented athletes in the college ranks. Send them to boot camp for fundamentals. Then force-feed them pasta and endless films of the Italians' style of play. Finally, hope for divine intervention.

LEAD: A chart last Sunday with an article about Quebec's economy misstated the Canadian province's gross domestic product in 1989. It was $129 billion, not $120 billion. A table with the article also misstated the percentage that Quebec contributes to Canada's gross domestic product. It was 23.6 percent, not 22 percent.
LEAD: After a decade of escalating cocaine use, researchers around the country say evidence is accumulating that the epidemic may have reached its peak.

LEAD: Closings in the week ended June 16 MANHATTAN Chelsea $530,000 436 West 23d Street (Fitzroy Place) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,250-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining area, den, fireplace, south garden; maintenance $268, no tax-deduction (Broker: Wells & Gay-Stribling & Associates)

LEAD: This is the moment of the just-dug tiny new potatoes, which, like tomatoes in season, should be purchased frequently and eaten with gusto. If you cannot find wonderfully sweet corn, it is better to use frozen ears than to suffer with the starchy kernels from old ones. Some crusty Italian country bread completes the meal.

LEAD: Carolyn Patricia Voute, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Voute of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kevin Lawrence Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene C. Murphy of North Chelmsford, Mass. Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

LEAD: James Scheuer Wallerstein, a biochemist and the president of the Sarah S. Ollesheimer Fund, a college scholarship foundation in Mount Kisco, N.Y., died on Thursday at his home in Mount Kisco. He was 79 years old.

LEAD: A sailor who suffered critical burns and internal injuries in the June 20 explosion and fire aboard the aircraft carrier Midway has died, bringing to three the toll of those killed by the accident. The 22-year-old sailor, Robert Shane Kilgore of Simi Valley, Calif., died late Wednesday at Brooke Army Medical Center here.

LEAD: Victoria A. Goss, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Woodrow Goss of Ashburn, Ga., and Judge Dennis F. Harrigan, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harrigan of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., were married yesterday. The ecumenical ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg of the United Church of Christ at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich,

LEAD: After years of spending money on building and improving Long Island's roads, the State Department of Transportation has concluded that the best way to handle the traffic problems here is to also persuade people to drive less.

LEAD: A Northwest Airlines jet with 182 people on board made an emergency landing on Saturday at an airport here after the pilot shut down one engine because of an oil leak. There were no injuries, officials said.

LEAD: Stan Getz was very much the center of attention at his JVC Jazz Festival concert on Friday night at Carnegie Hall. The entire concert was played by his quartet - Kenny Barron on piano; Alex Blake on bass, and Terri Lyne Carrington on drums - or his sextet, which was the quartet with Eddie Del Barrio and Frank Zottoli on synthesizers.

LEAD: The Census Bureau reported yesterday that 99 percent of the households in the United States that did not respond to first mailings of the 1990 census had now been counted, but that several areas, in particular New York State and City, still lagged far behind.

LEAD: Marquis W. Childs, a foreign correspondent, columnist, author and winner of a Pulitzer Prize for distinguished commentary, died Saturday at Children's Hospital of San Francisco. He was 87 years old. The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, where he wrote about Washington and the nation for 47 years, reported that Mr.

LEAD: Beth Clearfield, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald J. Clearfield of Lower Burrell, Pa., was married yesterday at the Westin William Penn Hotel in Pittsburgh to Reubin Simantov, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mayer Simantov of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Morris Landes officiated. The bride, 28 years old and a magna cum laude graduate of Yale University, is the director of programming at BBC/Lionheart Television, a distribution company in New York.

LEAD: The last time these two Wimbledon champions clashed on Centre Court, the one who won did an impersonation of the way the other had missed a volley and then tumbled over the net during their three-set quarterfinal match. When it ended, the loser wore a strawberry blond fright wig to his news conference.

LEAD: James Pomeroy Hendrick, a lawyer who was an adviser to Eleanor Roosevelt and later became deputy assistant secretary of the Treasury, died yesterday in Conway, Mass. He was 88 years old and lived in St. Croix in the Virgin Islands.

LEAD: Although Nancy Wilson has never been the artistic equal of Ella Fitzgerald, Sarah Vaughan or Billie Holiday, since becoming popular in the early 1960's she has exerted a considerable influence on a younger generation of pop-jazz interpreters. And on Saturday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, where she headlined a JVC Jazz Festival benefit concert for Jazzmobile, one was struck especially by her impact on Anita Baker.
LEAD: An article on Saturday about ways in which Canada's constitutional crisis might affect United States-Canadian relations misidentified the Premier of British Columbia. He is William Vander Zalm.
LEAD: On the last evening of his life, Dr. Arkady Novikov and his wife, Galina, acted like typical New York tourists: They ate dinner with friends, then visited Chinatown, SoHo and Little Italy.

LEAD: Global warming poses an uncommon threat to life on the planet, but what can ordinary people do about it? Plant a tree. This requires a shovel, a stake - in the ground and the future - and a seedling. If people live in an urban hardscape, they may want to follow the advice of Andy Lipkis, founder of a growing California organization called TreePeople, who has prompted the planting of a million trees in Los
LEAD: Rebel forces fought a fierce artillery and rocket duel today with Government troops on the northern outskirts of Monrovia, the capital.
LEAD: International

LEAD: Time is the most certain enemy of the Bush Administration's Cambodia policy. The longer the current diplomatic stalemate continues, the closer dreaded Khmer Rouge forces come to battlefield victory, and the worse the prospects grow for free elections and a role for the non-Communist forces led by Prince

LEAD: In cities across East Germany, people greeted economic union without giddy celebration, sobered by its significance and a sense that capitalism would mean hardship for many. But some anticipated fulfilling dreams.

LEAD: For more than five years, Mikhail Gorbachev has preached the gospel of democracy. Starting today, with the 28th Communist Party Congress, he must begin to practice it or risk losing his remaining power base.
LEAD: Raul A. Campanioni, a stockbroker who ran a firm that served gay clients and donated heavily to gay causes, died on Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 34 years old and lived in Chelsea.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The sculpture of LOUISE BOURGEOIS can be provocative and emotional. So can her views. When Ms. Bourgeois receives the 1990 Edward MacDowell Medal this summer at the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N.H., she plans to talk about art education, candidly.

LEAD: WHEN Greg Buttle, who anchored the Jets' linebacker corps, was released in August 1985 after nine seasons, he handed his playbook to the assistant trainer and vowed that he would never play football again.
LEAD: In his seven months as a supernova on the Senior PGA Tour, Lee Trevino has done everything a 50-year-old golfer can do except win one of the tour's major championships and beat Jack Nicklaus.
LEAD: Subway service came to a halt on much of the West Side of Manhattan last night when water gushed from a broken main and flooded the tracks below Central Park West at West 81st Street.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: By 1993, the two cable-television systems in Manhattan - which has perhaps the greatest concentration of producers, network executives and eager-eyed video junkies of any place on the planet - are to carry 70 channels. That is twice as many as they carry now, but fewer channels than are on cable systems in Columbus, Ohio, or Fairfax County,

LEAD: ''American Masters'' begins its fifth season at 9 tonight on Channel 13 (and at 10 tonight on Channel 50 and 4 A.M. tomorrow on Channel 13) with ''Preston Sturges: The Rise and Fall of an American Dreamer.'' Sturges was the first Hollywood screenwriter to also establish himself as a celebrated director.

LEAD: Allison Plesur and Robert D. Lipman, associates in the New York law firm of Jackson, Lewis, Schnitzler & Krupman, were married yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Rabbi Howard Buechler officiated. The bride, 25 years old, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Plesur of Hauppauge, L.I. Mr. Lipman, 29, is the son of Mr.

LEAD: Gary Player had so much trouble with his swing in the final round of the United States Senior Open that he rushed to the driving range shortly after the completion of the tournament today and hit golf balls until dusk.

LEAD: Juliana Kelly, the daughter of Anna Kelly of Southampton, L.I., and Michael J. Kelly of Woodside, Queens, was married yesterday to Jonathan Paul May, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. May of New York and Bridgewater, Conn. Judge Morton I. Riefberg of the Connecticut Superior Court, performed the ceremony at the

LEAD: Tourists sang ''Happy Birthday'' to 89-year-old Dorothy Walker Bush today as she emerged from St. Ann's by the Sea Episcopal Church on the arm of her son, President Bush. ''Thanks for the greeting for my Mom,'' the vacationing President said.

LEAD: The Ziff-Davis Publishing Company magazine PC/Computing has acquired the subscriber list of Personal Computing. The Dutch company VNU will stop publishing Personal Computing after its August issue.
LEAD: At 5:45 A.M. yesterday the New York City Council, weary and a little testy, patted itself on the back and adopted a $28 billion city budget.
LEAD: ''One look is worth a thousand words,'' Fred R. Barnard wrote in 1921 in Printers' Ink, a newspaper industry journal. A few years later, he amended his obscure aphorism.

LEAD: There were cinnamon doughnuts and great rejoicing on one short block of the South Bronx yesterday morning. The rain was over and gone for the moment. This year's municipal budget negotiations were complete, and a firehouse was open again on East 150th Street.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: International A2-9

LEAD: The Beacon Theater on Saturday night was no place for anyone who expects live jazz to sound like recordings. The alphabetically billed quartet of Jack DeJohnette (drums), Herbie Hancock (keyboards), Dave Holland (bass) and Pat Metheny (guitar) tossed out marketing and genre categories along with decorum.

LEAD: Iran's Interior Minister said today that the Government had no desire for better relations with the United States and insisted that Iran had done everything it could to free Western hostages held in Lebanon.

LEAD: The Communist Party of the Soviet Union, divided, demoralized and endangered by democracy, is convening Monday for its 28th congress, where the main issue will be not so much where the party will lead the country but whether it will lead the country at all.

LEAD: Graham Haynes's show at the Equitable Center on Friday afternoon, as part of JVC Jazz Festival's Knitting Factory Goes Uptown series, did a smart thing. By merging participants in the downtown scene -the harpist and keyboardist Zeena Parkins as well as members of the band Bosho, including Chulo on bass and Yuval Gabay on drums and Kumiko Kimoto on percussion - with members of the jazz vanguard, it drew on the strengths of the two camps.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Pittsburgh Pirates hit four home runs, including two-run shots by Barry Bonds, Sid Bream and Jay Bell, to beat the Giants, 8-5, today, and retain a one-game lead over the Mets in the National League East.

LEAD: In recent years the Boston Symphony's Tanglewood Festival in the Berkshires has begun a week early. In other words, in the weekend before the first actual Boston Symphony concert the following Friday night, the festival presents chamber music and other exotica, usually not in the larger shed but in the smaller Theater-Concert
LEAD: Treasury financings this holiday-shortened week are confined to the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills today.
LEAD: ''YOU can't rehearse for this job,'' Bud Harrelson was saying. ''They give it to you, and there it is.''

LEAD: Jessica Lynn Primoff, the daughter of Arlene Kelvin of Bayside, Queens, and the late Melvin Primoff, was married yesterday in White Plains to Gregory Scott Vistnes, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lars Vistnes of Los Altos, Calif. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman and the Rev. Pamela Blair, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Mansion at the Stouffer Westchester

LEAD: EVERY weekend for the last four months, Dan and Donna Doyle picked up debris, cut down trees and cleared paths in a park infested with litter and plagued by vandalism. Their purpose? To renovate the Buzzy Creek disk golf course in New Milford, N.J.

LEAD: Bushspeak is not yet a sufficiently recognized language to explain the President's switch on taxes, which he says was not a switch, or not really a switch. Here is his concise attempt, faithfully reproduced from his news conference last week, to explain what it was instead:

LEAD: Maybe you think you don't need to see ''The Grapes of Wrath'' on Broadway. You probably read John Steinbeck's book somewhere around 10th grade and caught the movie on a rainy Sunday afternoon. Or maybe you've decided that you see too many homeless people on the streets to want to see them on a stage.

LEAD: ''Things over there got better and better. Here they got worse and worse. The reason I'm confident is that I've seen the worst. No matter what comes now with the new money and the economic change, it's got to be better than what we had.'' - Waltraud Feichtinger of East Berlin. [A6:2.]

LEAD: The Supreme Court ended its term last week with a stunning reaffirmation of Congress's power to keep the Constitution's promise of equality. For the sake of diversity, and not merely to remedy past discrimination, Congress may help minorities win a greater share of Federal benefits.

LEAD: James Scheuer Wallerstein, a biochemist and the president of the Sarah S. Ollesheimer Fund, a college scholarship foundation in Mount Kisco, N.Y., died on Thursday at his home in Mount Kisco. He was 79 years old.

LEAD: The spring 1990 reading and mathematics achievement test scores for the New York City public schools show a sharp decline in reading scores among ninth and 10th graders, but otherwise are virtually unchanged from last year.

LEAD: The $100 million lawsuit that Time Warner Inc. has filed against the Pathe Communications Corporation accuses the Italian company of trying to sell the same film distribution and home video rights twice.

LEAD: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland decisively lost a test of strength with Lech Walesa this weekend, exposing his Government's precarious foundation of support and raising questions about whether his Cabinet could survive without changes.

LEAD: For two weeks now, Effi Barry, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s wife of 12 years, has stoically sat in Courtroom No. 2 at the Federal Courthouse here, a front-row spectator in the riveting drug trial of her husband.

LEAD: Justice Leander Shaw today became the first black to be Chief Justice of the Florida Supreme Court, but his position is threatened by anti-abortion groups that are seeking to remove him from the bench because of his rulings on abortion.
LEAD: What goes up must come down, and vice versa. And that is just what happened in the world's stock markets in the second quarter.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The marriage of Allison Cocke, the daughter of Kathryn Peterson Cocke of San Antonio, and Dr. Joseph Garber Cocke Jr. of Orlando, Fla., to Brad Scott Lerner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Lerner of Plainview, L.I., took place yesterday. Rabbi Gary Creditor officiated at the Southwest Craft Center in San Antonio, assisted by Cantor Morris Wolk.
LEAD: IN the magazine industry these days, is the glass half empty or half full?
LEAD: * Dale P. Brown has been named president and chief executive of Sive Associates, a Cincinnati marketing communications firm owned by Young & Rubicam.

LEAD: As though the reputation of Tyrannosaurus rex was not already horrific enough, two paleontologists now propose that the carnivorous dinosaur had powerful forelimbs that could easily grasp 400 pounds of writhing prey.

LEAD: The Tour de France seemed to be thrown up for grabs today after four major riders, none of them favorites, stormed to the finish more than 10 minutes faster than most of the rest of the 198-man field.

LEAD: Ella Fitzgerald's show on Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall, part of the JVC Jazz Festival, started out slowly. Miss Fitzgerald, who had a cold or sinus problem, had a tough time navigating her tunes, and the upper register of her voice wasn't cooperating; it strayed off pitch and sounded uncharacteristically harsh.

LEAD: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Jodi Beth Spiegel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Spiegel of Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Barry Fisher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Fisher of Atlantic Beach. Rabbi Sol Roth performed the ceremony.
LEAD: Credit market participants and analysts say they are optimistic that interest rates can decline further in the final six months of the year.
LEAD: An enigmatic person may be provocatively appealing, but unfortunately for the Xerox Corporation's relations with Wall Street, an enigmatic company is usually seen as just plain annoying.

LEAD: Twenty teen-agers are in Moscow, participating in track meets, basketball games and summer camp. A girls' track team and a boys' basketball team, accompanied by ROBERT M. MORGENTHAU, the Manhattan District Attorney, were picked from Police Athletic League teams from throughout New York City. P.A.L.

LEAD: For a week, the jury in the case of the Central Park jogger listened as Elizabeth Lederer, the prosecutor, led other victims through their recollections of fright and pain that night almost 15 months ago.

LEAD: THE sounds are not very sweet these days at Harman International Industries, maker of such top-of-the-line stereo speakers as Harman-Kardon, JBL and Infinity. Last week, Sidney Harman, the company's chief executive and a former Deputy Secretary of Commerce, told analysts that earnings for the 1990 fiscal year, to be released in August, would be 5 to 7 percent below last year's record high.

LEAD: A network television appearance by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today highlighted the paradox about the Governor's musings on the Presidency - the more Mr. Cuomo protests that he is not running, the more people seem to disbelieve him.
LEAD: Andy Hawkins will likely never forget the no-hitter he pitched today, but to some degree, it will always be one of two dates that will forever mark his 1990 season.
LEAD: AFTER 32 years of officiating in the National Basketball Association, Earl Strom said he finally feels as though he fits in.
LEAD: * Silo Inc., Philadelphia, a subsidiary of the electronics retailer Dixons Group P.L.C., to Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/Pacific, with a budget of $5 million.
LEAD: A mechanical engineer who became exasperated over the frequent loss of bicycle locks and cables belonging to his nine children has created a retractable lock that is fastened to the cycle.
LEAD: On both sides of the crumbling remnants of the Berlin Wall, signs of an economic boom are everywhere, a direct result of the merger of the East and West German economies.

LEAD: East Germans formed orderly lines across the land today to get their West German currency, irrevocably throwing in their lot with the capitalist world and turning into the home stretch toward reunification.

LEAD: Whatever chance New Orleans had to be the site of the 1992 Democratic National Convention has been seriously undermined by the anti-abortion legislation approved by the Louisiana Legislature last week, top party officials say.

LEAD: Forty-five minutes down Interstate 85, researchers are pushing at the boundaries of medical science at the Duke University Medical Center, but there has recently been an epochal breakthrough here: nearly all the residents who had been using old pine outhouses have been able to replace them with indoor bathrooms.
LEAD: In a rough-and-tumble shell of a neighborhood on Detroit's East Side, motorists lunge for the brakes when they get to Heidelberg Street.

LEAD: Commissioner Fay Vincent's investigation into George Steinbrenner concentrates less on the Yankee owner's highly publicized payments to Howard Spira than on Steinbrenner's contentious relationship with his former player Dave Winfield.
LEAD: In the most extended drama of this World Cup soccer tournament, England rallied to defeat Cameroon, 3-2, in overtime tonight, and the tremors could be felt as far away as Turin.

LEAD: Benny Green, the youngest performer this year in the JVC Jazz Festival's solo piano series at Weill Recital Hall, has a traditionalist's pedigree. LEAD: RON REICH barked out instructions to his three teammates as Top of the Line went through its team precision routine. The double lines of the stunt kites crossed, uncrossed and crossed again as the kites flew in formation, following each other through loops, figure-8's and square turns, and then instantaneously broke ranks, looped in different directions and reformed a new line with a new direction.
LEAD: The Israeli Government today approved Housing Minister Ariel Sharon's request for sweeping emergency powers to begin a crash housing construction program for Soviet Jewish immigrants.

There they chanted for the recall of Gov. Jim Florio and threatened to vote out of office all legislators who approved the new taxes last month.

LEAD: Ib Andersen gave what was billed as his farewell performance in New York with the New York City Ballet on Friday night amid standing ovations and expressions of warmth and humor onstage from the company that he joined in 1980.

LEAD: Bobby Wilmot of Australia won the Liberty Cup Regatta yesterday afternoon after the event was cut short by a severe thunderstorm that sent most of the traffic in New York Harbor scurrying for shore.

LEAD: FOR nearly 20 years, their rivalry had simmered in the memories of Merion and Muirfield, but now it's boiling again: the wisecracking grandson of a Mexican gravedigger who has ascended to golf's royalty with a goofy swing against the calculating conglomerate who is considered by most aficionados to be the best golfer in history.
LEAD: With a week remaining in the 1990 World Cup, it seems foolhardy not to expect West Germany in a third consecutive final match when the tournament ends Sunday night in Rome.

LEAD: Golf Johnston Takes du Maurier Event: Cathy Johnston beat Patty Sheehan by two strokes yesterday to win the du Maurier Classic, the second of the four major tournaments on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour. Johnston shot a two-under-par 71 to finish at 276, 16 under for the 6,415-yard course at the Westmount Golf and Country Club in Kitchener, Ontario.

LEAD: Amid efforts by the Soviet Union to liberalize its stagnant economy, a seemingly quixotic movement to adopt a Western-style patent law is gaining momentum.
LEAD: I HAVE just had my first decent night's sleep in seven days. The other six evenings were devoted to the best fly fishing for striped bass I have experienced in more than 35 years.

LEAD: So many new towers are rising on the West Side of Manhattan that it is hard to believe the boom is over. But the construction workers who form lunchtime knots on the sidewalks and gather beneath the scaffolding know better.

LEAD: State lawmakers passed landmark legislation today allowing New Yorkers to designate surrogates to make health-care decisions - including decisions that could end life - if they become incompetent to do so themselves.

LEAD: Strictly speaking, it's not really the center of Manhattan Island. And yet it is, this glorious space reigned over by the most unlikely of couples, the goddess Pomona and Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman. Especially now.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation will raise prices on most of its 1990 passenger cars on Monday. The nation's No. 3 auto maker said suggested retail price increases start at $60 for Dodge Daytona cars, which will have a base price of $9,805, and most Chrysler LeBarons, which will rise to about $12,555. The biggest increases are $160 on the Chrysler Fifth Avenue and Chrysler Imperial models, bringing their base prices to $21,020 and $25,655, respectively.

LEAD: John Franco, the Met reliever, did not realize that the Cincinnati Reds, his former team, could be a source of inspiration for pitching harder, but yesterday, they apparently were.

On Monday, Mr. Mandela will talk with Prime Minister Charles Haughey and address the Irish Parliament before flying to London.
LEAD: While President Bush conceded last week that he was now vulnerable to charges that he had broken his word, his turnabout on taxes appears to have fulfilled public expectations.

LEAD: THE big new scare for the already sluggish American economy is coming from the construction industry, particularly home construction. ''John,'' wails Holly McClane (Bonnie Bedelia), at the end of a second Christmastime showdown involving armed-to-the-teeth terrorists, helpless hostages and her husband (Bruce Willis) in the role of a one-man army, ''Why does this keep happening to us?'' The answer isn't hard to see. John McClane is a streetwise police officer who isn't ashamed to look scared stiff when he feels that way. He's a devoted family man with a great wisecracking sense of humor. He's a crazily reckless fighter capable of making the most impossible feats look easy. And he's a magnetic, cleverly drawn character, a hero neither villains nor audiences seem able to resist. That, along with lean, edgy direction and a number of astonishing stunts, makes ''Die Hard 2'' the fastest, scariest action film of this trigger-happy summer.

LEAD: Five shareholders are suing Fleet Norstar Financial Group Inc. and accusing it of concealing the extent of problem loans at the company's banks. Three lawsuits filed in United States District Court in Providence contend the company's failure to make timely disclosure of its loan problems artificially inflated its profits and the price of its stock.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on June 23 about the Tobu Department Store Company of Japan misstated the value of the assets of the Tobu Railway Group, which owns it. Tobu Railway has assets of more than 700 billion yen, or about $4.6 billion, not $700 million.
LEAD: To Jack Canning, a real-estate man from New Hope, Pa., and his wife, Linda, who raises miniature horses, the seashore is a special place, almost mystical.

LEAD: ''Granted, the guy is walking a tightrope in a hurricane,'' a member of the art world said last week about John Frohnmayer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. ''But he has to take a stronger position.''
LEAD: A blind man today fulfilled his long-held desire to drive but was arrested after he struck a telephone pole after a three-mile ride through the streets here.
LEAD: UNLIKE most foods, when it comes to pasta, fresh is not always better. And with dry, factory-made pasta, imported usually is better than domestic. Until now.

LEAD: Aaron Pryor, armed with an ophthalmologist's report saying he has enough vision to continue boxing, is stepping up his bid to be cleared for bouts in Canada and New York State.

LEAD: It seems only fitting, on Independence Day that we forgo what used to be known as the Old World and set out a few of our own good wines for consideration. Traditionally, this is an occasion to talk about ''picnic wines'' and such. The fact is that even in summer we sit down fully clothed at a table for most meals, and if wine is drunk it is not going to differ markedly from what we drink in winter.

LEAD: A Soviet helicopter pilot who contracted leukemia after trying to douse the fire at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in 1986 has died, a hospital spokeswoman said today.

LEAD: As they pull out of Hungary, Soviet troops are leaving behind a legacy that to Hungarians somehow befits the 45-year occupation - rows of grubby, rundown barracks, shoddy apartment buildings, fields of unexploded artillery shells, oil and other waste dumped directly into the ground.
LEAD: Hundreds of Albanians rushed foreign embassies in that country's capital in recent days in an effort to flee the hard-line Communist country, diplomats said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Connick the Versatile ''I've learned that people latch onto labels and stereotypes,'' Harry Connick Jr. said in a recent conversation. ''There was a period when I was asked in every single interview how I liked being the new Frank Sinatra. It's nice to be compared to him, but with the release of my two new albums, I think people will soon realize that I do a lot more than interpret old songs.
LEAD: China and Indonesia signed an agreement today to restore diplomatic relations next month, ending a 23-year rift between the two most populous nations in East Asia.

LEAD: President Bush has repeatedly supported the idea of youth community service but has not offered to finance such a program. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, for one, is trying to put money behind the concept - $65 million for service programs in the schools -with the National Community Service Act of 1990.
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation has granted some top managers stock options to keep their compensation packages competitive, a company spokesman said on Monday.
LEAD: The National Gallery of Art in Washington is to receive 6 photographs by Paul Strand from a collection of more than 50 held by the Southwestern Bell Corporation.

LEAD: In the long history of the Texas oil industry, there has rarely been a gusher as powerful as either of those that burst to the surface in the aging oil patch southwest of San Antonio last month. In an area regarded as well past its oil-producing prime, the wells surged with 20,000 and 12,000 barrels a day, respectively, in a field where most wells produce less than 500.

LEAD: A mass grave discovered last week in northern Yugoslavia may contain the remains of a large number of people executed by the victorious Communist guerrillas in 1945, a Croatian newspaper reported today.

LEAD: A free outdoor performance of Dixieland jazz is to be given by the Smith Street Society Band at 1 P.M. today in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The museum is to be open today from 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Admission is $6 ($3 for students and the elderly). Information: 879-5500.

LEAD: The Other Burton Novels on the best-seller list are usually written by well-known authors, but the nonfiction list almost always includes books by little-known authors or books that survived small first printings. ''The Closing of the American Mind,'' by Allan Bloom (Simon & Schuster), and ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers,'' by Paul Kennedy (Random House), had first printings of fewer than 10,000 copies.

LEAD: Three players in the St. Louis Cardinals organization have rejected an offer to settle charges of disorderly conduct that were filed against them as a result of a fight in Covington, Ky., the players' lawyer said yesterday.

LEAD: KATHARINE HEPBURN, an amateur painter since the 1930's, has offered one of her paintings to an auction that will benefit a wildlife organization in East Lyme, Conn. Miss Hepburn said it is the only work she has ever permitted to be sold or, for that matter, to be seen by the public.

LEAD: The City University of New York, no stranger to distinction, has a new one: Its undergraduate body yields more corporate executives than any other school.

LEAD: Stocks advanced yesterday for the fourth straight session, but with many traders and investors stretching their Fourth of July holiday, activity continued sluggish and is expected to remain so at least until Monday.

LEAD: MENACHEM BEGIN was recovering yesterday in Shaarei Tzedek Hospital in Jerusalem after an operation to repair a fractured hip. He is expected to make a complete recovery, said the hospital's director, DR. YONATHON HALEVY. It was the former Prime Minister's second hospital stay since May, when he was hospitalized for two weeks with pneumonia.
LEAD: * ABB Asea Brown Boveri A.G., the Swedish-Swiss engineering group, said it had agreed to acquire CCC, a Spanish electrical engineering company that has seven plants and 2,900 employees.

LEAD: Don Mattingly's sore and stiff back showed improvement today, but the Yankee first baseman won't attempt a return to the lineup until Friday and may be asked to wait until after the three-day break for the All-Star Game.
